column13: the average transaction size checks in dollar terms the mean transaction value for an asset on a particular day.  Historically
column14: spikes in this metric signal high user activity—Especially from large investors and institutions. But when it decreases
column15: it implies an absence of institutional interaction. As such

column17: this indicator identifies potential tops and bottoms. From the value mentioned

column23: other metrics need to be considered. As a result of this
column24: AMBCrypto looked at the Ethereum Exchange Net Position Change. According to data obtained from Glassnode
column25: the Exchange Net Position Change has been in the negative region for most of the last 30 days. This metric tracks the 30-day change of the supply held in exchange wallets. A positive value indicates that more coins are in exchanges. On the other hand
column26: a negative value indicates increased withdrawals from exchanges. One thing we noticed was that the metric suddenly became positive on the 18th of May. As of this writing
column27: the ETH net position change was 81
column28: 715. This increase could be a sign that Ethereum participants are taking profits off the 6.50% increase within the last week. If this number continues to increase
column29: then ETH’s price might decrease below $3
column30: 000 before the potential rally happens. Source: Santiment However

column1: 3::https://blockworks.co/news/oklahoma-bill-protects-fundamental-bitcoin-rights::Blockworks::article::Oklahoma passes bill protecting ‘fundamental bitcoin rights’::Oklahoma passed a bill earlier this week that protects state residents' right to self-custody digital assets. ::Oklahoma’s new crypto bill will go into effect in November of this year Oklahoma Governor Kevin Stitt | Gage Skidmore/"Kevin Stitt" (CC license) Oklahoma passed a bill earlier this week that protects state residents’ right to self-custody digital assets. The bill will go into effect on November 1
column2: 2024. OKHB3594 was signed into law by Governor Kevin Stitt. It was sponsored by four Republicans — State Senators Bill Coleman and Dana Prieto and State Representatives Brian Hill and Cody Maynard. Under the bill
column3: Oklahoma bans restricting or outlawing the use “or the self-custody of digital assets using a self-hosted wallet or a hardware wallet
column4: ” a page for the bill said. Oklahomans can also mine crypto both at home and industrially
column5: though they have to comply with local noise ordinances. Read more: Crypto bill update: What legislation is making its way forward? “Anyone engaged in home digital asset mining
column6: or digital asset mining business
column7: staking
column8: or staking as a service shall not be required to obtain a money transmitter license
column9: ” the bill said. Additionally
column10: “discriminatory electricity rates for digital asset mining businesses are outlawed as well.” Residents can use crypto to pay for goods and services and are protected from paying additional taxes. “Digital assets used as a method of payment may not be subject to any additional tax
column11: withholding
column12: assessment or charge by the state or local government that is based solely on the use of the digital asset as the method of payment
column13: ” the bill continued. Satoshi Act Fund CEO Dennis Porter called the bill “groundbreaking” and said it was designed to protect “fundamental bitcoin rights.” Read more: Senate passes resolution to overturn SAB 121 “The idea that ‘We the People’ cannot hold our own assets is antithetical to American values. Without the ability to manage our wealth

column18: it’s critical not to treat the demo account as a perfect substitute for a real trading terminal. It has several downsides that hinder the replication of an authentic trading experience with a real deposit: In sum

Share this article Bankrupt crypto lending company Genesis Global Holdco received court permission to return approximately $3 billion in cash and crypto assets to its creditors as part of its bankruptcy liquidation process on Friday. US Bankruptcy Judge Sean Lane made the decision. In addition
column5: Judge Sean Lane rejected Digital Currency Group’s (DCG)
column6: attempt to challenge the distribution plan for the debtors’ assets in the bankruptcy case. DCG objected to the distribution plan as it believes repayments should be capped at the crypto asset values of January 2023 (at the time of Genesis’ bankruptcy filing). Since then
column7: the value of cryptos like Bitcoin has surged
column8: with Bitcoin’s price jumping from around $21
column9: 000 to a current value of nearly $67
column10: 000. The firm also claimed that the plan provides too much return to creditors at DCG’s expense. Essentially
column11: DCG feels that it is unfairly disadvantaged by how the returns are allocated. However
column12: DCG’s arguments failed. Judge Sean Lane ruled that
column13: as an equity holder
column14: DCG’s financial interest isn’t directly impacted by how the assets are distributed. Equity holders only get paid after all creditors are satisfied. Additionally
column15: given the insolvency and the massive creditor claims
column16: DCG won’t receive any distribution under this plan. The total amount owed to creditors is billions of dollars higher than the debtors’ available assets. These claims have priority over equity holders like DCG
column17: meaning they get paid first in line during bankruptcy. The ruling also considered the substantial $32 billion in claims from federal and state financial regulators
column18: prioritizing them over DCG’s equity stake. Genesis had previously estimated that it could pay up to 77% of the value of customer claims
column19: a figure subject to future market fluctuations. Hit hard by the collapse of Three Arrows Capital (3AC) and FTX
column20: Genesis – along with other lending platforms – faced liquidity issues during the 2022 market downturn. This ultimately led the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in January 2023. Genesis’ creditors include several prominent names
column21: such as Gemini
column22: Bybit’s Mirama
column23: Decentraland
column24: and VanEck. Adding to its troubles
column25: Genesis Global Capital faced a legal lawsuit from the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The SEC accused Genesis and Gemini of selling unregistered securities through Gemini Earn. The company reached a $21 million settlement with the SEC in March this year. column1: 6::https://theconversation.com/bitcoin-is-halving-again-what-does-that-mean-for-the-cryptocurrency-and-the-market-228213::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin is halving again – what does that mean for the cryptocurrency and the market?::There are reasons to believe that the bitcoin halving could keep the value of the currency high.::Bitcoin
column2: the largest and most talked about digital asset
column3: has been on a rollercoaster of a ride since its launch in January 2009. With a market capitalisation that reached a high of more than US$1.4 trillion (£1.125 trillion) this February and volatile swings since
column4: bitcoin has attracted lots of attention recently. Now a hotly anticipated recurring event that happens roughly every four years is taking place: the bitcoin halving. This could have further significant impact on the value of the cryptocurrency. You can listen to more articles from The Conversation
column5: narrated by Noa. To understand what the halving is and what it could mean
column6: we have to understand how bitcoin works. Bitcoin is a digital currency that makes use of what’s called blockchain technology to securely store
column7: record and publicly publish all transactions. It is distinct from fiat currencies
column8: such as dollars or pounds
column9: because it has no central authority and members of the network have equal power. Each transaction is made and recorded with the user’s public address
column10: a code that enables them to remain anonymous. Bitcoins are created by so-called miners who contribute computing power to secure the network and solve complex mathematical puzzles in order to process transaction data. These miners are then rewarded for their work with newly minted bitcoins. The idea for bitcoin was first proposed in a white paper published online in 2008 by a mysterious individual or group using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto. To combat inflation
column11: Nakamoto wrote into the code that the total number of bitcoins will only ever be 21 million. Currently
column12: more than 19.6 million bitcoins have been mined. At the beginning
column13: back in 2009
column14: miners received 50 bitcoins for every block (unit of transaction data) they mined. But after every 210
column15: 000 blocks (roughly every four years)
column16: the reward halves. So in 2012 the reward fell to 25 bitcoins
column17: then to 12.5 bitcoins in 2016 and to 6.25 bitcoins in 2020. The latest halving means the reward will be just 3.125 bitcoins. Nakamoto has never explained explicitly the reasons behind the halving. Some speculate that the halving system was designed to distribute coins more quickly at the beginning to incentivise people to join the network and mine new blocks. Block rewards are programmed to halve at regular intervals because the value of each coin rewarded is deemed likely to increase as the network expands. But this may lead to users holding bitcoin as a speculative asset rather than using it as a medium of exchange. Additionally
column18: the 21 million cap on the number of coins that can enter circulation makes them scarce (at least in comparison to dollars or euros)
column19: which for some people is enough to make them valuable. So what impact does the halving have on the price? After the halving
column20: the number of new bitcoin entering circulation shrinks. Demand should
column21: in theory
column22: be unaffected by this event and therefore the price should go up. “The theory is that there will be less bitcoin available to buy if miners have less to sell
column23: ” said Michael Dubrovsky
column24: a co-founder of PoWx
column25: a crypto research non-profit. While the first halving happened in 2012
column26: when bitcoin was less well known and quite hard to buy and sell
column27: we can learn from the subsequent two halvings. The second halving on July 16 2016 was highly anticipated. The price dropped by 10%
column28: but then shot back up to where it had been before. Although the immediate impact on the price was small
column29: bitcoin did eventually respond and some argue that the 2017 bull run when the market boomed was a delayed result of the halving. Beginning the year around US$900
column30: by the end of 2017 bitcoin was trading above US$19
column31: 000. The third halving in 2020 happened during a bullish period for bitcoin and it continued to rise to more than US$56
column32: 000 in 2021. These few data points are not enough however to offer any concrete causal relationship or trend. But we do know that instantly miners’ rewards are halved
column33: meaning their revenue immediately halves and their profit margins are severely affected. Consequently
column34: unless there is a price appreciation
column35: many miners may become unprofitable and could cease the practice. Bitcoin’s scarcity is arguably one of its most significant characteristics
column36: especially in a time of high inflation
column37: quantitative easing and high interest rates. With the real value of fiat currencies falling
column38: bitcoin’s limited supply is an attractive feature and can be reassuring for investors. Bitcoin hit an all-time high in February following the approval of bitcoin exchange-traded funds
column39: which effectively make it easier for retail investors and big banks to invest in bitcoin. This
column40: coupled with a more favourable regulatory environment on the horizon and the fact that it is becoming more integrated in the financial system
column41: means bitcoin may continue on the rise it has experienced in 2024 so far.::2024-04-19T15:10:52Z::Audio narrated

column1: 7::https://www.coindesk.com/policy/2024/04/05/new-york-jury-finds-do-kwon-terraform-labs-liable-for-fraud-in-sec-case/::CoinDesk::article::New York Jury Finds Do Kwon
column2: Terraform Labs Liable for Fraud in SEC Case::The SEC accused Kwon and his company of misleading investors about the stability of their so-called “algorithmic stablecoin” Terra USD.::NEW YORK – A Manhattan jury has found Terraform Labs and its co-founder
column3: Do Kwon
column4: liable on civil fraud charges brought by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) in connection with the $40 billion implosion of the Terra ecosystem in May 2022
column5: according to a Friday statement from the SEC. The SEC accused Terraform Labs and Kwon of misleading investors about the stability of its so-called “algorithmic” native stablecoin
column6: Terra USD (UST)
column7: and the use cases for the Terra blockchain. The jury delivered the verdict on Friday
column8: just two hours after lawyers for both the SEC and the defendants gave their closing arguments at the end of the nine-day trial in New York. Jurors agreed with the SEC that Kwon and
column9: under his direction
column10: Terraform Labs deceived everyday investors about the nature of the supposed algorithm that kept UST pegged to the U.S. dollar. Though Kwon insinuated that it could “automatically self-heal” in the event of a de-peg
column11: it actually relied on continuous trading activity
column12: including large-scale trading done by institutional investors. “We are pleased with today’s jury verdict holding Terraform Labs and Do Kwon liable for a massive crypto fraud
column13: ” Gurbir Grewal
column14: SEC Division of Enforcement director
column15: wrote in a statement. “The defendants caused devastating losses for investors and wiped out tens of billions of market value nearly overnight. For all of crypto’s promises
column16: the lack of registration and compliance have very real consequences for real people. As the hard work of our team shows
column17: we will continue to use the tools at our disposal to protect the investing public
column18: but it is high time for the crypto markets to come into compliance
column19: ” Grewal added. SEC attorney Laura Meehan told the jury during her closing arguments on Friday that one of those institutional investors – Jump Trading – had made a secret deal with Kwon and Terraform Labs to rescue UST during a de-pegging event in May 2021
column20: stepping in and buying millions of dollars of UST off-chain to reinflate its value and bring it back to parity with the dollar. Meehan added that
column21: after Jump’s intervention
column22: Kwon and his company intentionally kept the firm’s rescue mission quiet
column23: wanting instead to use the re-pegging as evidence of the algorithm’s effectiveness. Lawyers for Terraform Labs and Kwon attempted to wave Jump’s involvement away as a regular part of their relationship with Terraform Labs as a market maker. They said that all “reasonable” investors knew that the algorithm that kept UST pegged to the dollar was not a “magical machine” or “computer that functioned on its own” but instead
column24: minting and burning done by market participants. The jury
column25: as evidenced by their verdict
column26: did not agree. A spokesperson for Terraform Labs told CoinDesk: “We are very disappointed with the verdict
column27: which we do not believe is supported by the evidence. We continue to maintain that the SEC does not have the legal authority to bring this case at all
column28: and we are carefully weighing our options and next steps.” Kwon was not in Manhattan for his civil trial; instead
column29: he was stuck in Montenegro
column30: where he had been since his arrest in March 2023. Kwon was caught en route to Dubai attempting to use fake Costa Rican travel documents after months on the run. Kwon also faces criminal charges in the U.S. and his native South Korea
column31: which are tied to the implosion of the Terra ecosystem. Both countries are currently vying for his extradition
column32: but his final destination remains unclear as Montenegro's Supreme Court weighs the competing requests. UPDATE (19:10 UTC April 5): The story was updated to include a comment from a Terraform Labs spokesperson. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column5: BeInCrypto is not responsible for any personal financial loss or gain incurred based on our content.  To learn more on how we evaluate each piece of content
column6: please proceed to our verification methodology page As traders navigate the fluctuations between bullish and bearish forces in the crypto market
column7: they often use indicators like the Relative Strength Index (RSI) and volume analysis to time their trades. However
column8: in an unpredictable field
column9: it is useful to have a tool that analyzes the behavioral phases of crypto trading instead of the price and trend confirmations. This is where the Gator Oscillator comes in handy. This guide dives into the Gator Oscillator
column10: examining its practical applications
column11: calculation method
column12: and analytical benefits. Here’s why it’s an essential oscillator for those seeking precise trading signals without the overload of multiple indicators. The Gator Indicator
column13: also termed the Gator Oscillator
column14: is a derivative or a sourced version of the famous Alligator Indicator. While the alligator indicator is made of moving averages
column15: the Gator Oscillator is made of histograms. This tool helps users visualize and interpret the market’s behavior
column16: helping them make sense of the various phases leading to or following a trend. Did you know? The Gator Oscillator was created by Bill Williams
column17: a 1932-born trader who also created the trend-following Alligator Indicator
column18: the Market Facilitation Index (MFI)
column19: and price pattern-evaluating Fractals. The Gator Oscillator relies on histogram analysis and features two histograms to work with. The histograms above the zero line and below the zero line can be all red
column20: all green
column21: or a mix of both
column22: depending on the state of the market or the cryptocurrency you are analyzing. The Gator Oscillator is a simplified version of the Alligator indicator. The former doesn’t directly identify the trend’s direction but only captures the mood. It helps the traders make sense of market phases by dividing moves into the sleeping
column23: awakening
column24: eating
column25: and weakening phases. These phases
column26: when viewed in combination with the Alligator Indicator’s moving averages and the price action
column27: help you with decision-making and even risk management. The idea is to look for the histogram analysis patterns to turn green and red from all red before you can consider entering a long position. The risk management element is taken care of when you start closing your open position
column28: and all the green bars turn green and red
column29: hinting at a sating phase. The Gator Oscillator is still a lagging indicator
column30: showcasing the trend’s strength rather than the direction unless you use it to analyze the trading divergence. The calculation principle of the Gator Oscillator is based on how the Alligator Indicator moves. Therefore
column31: it is necessary first to understand the elements of the latter: Note: These are the lines and moving average levels set by Bill Williams. The TradingView Gator Oscillator settings
column32: like any other TradingView Indicator
column33: could have slightly different values for the moving average. Notice how in the above TradingView Gator Oscillator and Alligator Indicator representation
column34: the 5-period line is green
column35: and the 13-period Jawline is red. In this case
column36: the teeth are the blue line and smoothed as 9-period instead of 8-period of showcase mid-term trends instead of short-term. Each moving average is shifted forward by 8-period
column37: 5-period
column38: and 3-period to reduce the effects of the lagging indicator and make the Gator indicator more forward-looking. Now that the base is all set
column39: let us focus on the calculation: As mentioned earlier
column40: the Gator Oscillator comprises dual histograms comprising upper and lower bars. Each upper bar is the absolute difference between the 13-period and 8-period/9-period smoothed averages. Each lower bar is the difference between the 8-period/9-period and 5-period moving averages. The bars can be green and red
column41: depending on the nature of the trend. We shall look into this while reading a gator oscillator. Reading the Gator Oscillator is all about understanding the elements. Notably
column42: while this oscillator helps with the entry and exit points
column43: it can signal the trend direction
column44: provided you know how to read the trading divergence. The easiest way to read is to understand the phases of the Gator Oscillator
column45: along with the colors. If both the histogram bars are red
column46: expect the price action to be in the sleeping phase. This shows the market is in a consolidation phase
column47: not rife for entry. If one histogram is in green and the other is in red
column48: or are there multiple green-red bars
column49: you might be looking at the awakening phase. This might reveal clear entry points and the potential start of a forming up trend. If both the histogram bars are green
column50: expect the market to be in the eating phase. This is where traders take most of the profit
column51: capitalizing on the momentum. When
column52: after the eating phase
column53: the bars again start showing mixed colors — red and green
column54: you can expect the trend to lose momentum. This is where most traders exit positions and book profits. The size of the bars also reveals a lot in terms of price action. For instance
column55: if the green and red bars in the awakening phase are smaller than the sleeping phase
column56: you might want to look at other indicators and wait for a different entry point. If the price action and the formation of bars (bar size even) move in different directions
column57: you might be looking at trading divergence. For instance
column58: check the chart below. Despite the formation of red and green histogram bars
column59: the price of BTC corrected instead of rising
column60: as the bars were smallish and not aligned with the price action. Important: If the bars in the awakening zone are smaller than the ones encountered in the previous phase
column61: the trend is not solid
column62: and the price action might trade sideways for a while. Now that we know how to read this indicator
column63: let’s take the BTC price chart and try to use the Gator Oscillator in real-time crypto trading. We shall now look at the historical chart of Bitcoin
column64: starting in 2021 and following all the way till the peak formed towards the end of that year. The first encircled zone hints at a consolidation or sleeping phase with all-red
column65: smallish bars. Then came the awakening phase with the broadening green bars and occasional red here and there. After this came the price surge
column66: taking BTC to a new high of almost $58
column67: 000. Immediately after this high
column68: the Gator indicator started showing green and red bars
column69: hinting a correction and space for traders to exit the trade. The entire short-term journey is depicted by the A to D pathway. Note that these phases were between January and February 2021
column70: and BTC embarked on several such journeys to reach a peak of almost $69
column71: 000 by the end of the year. In 2024
column72: the price of BTC seems to be trading in the sleeping zone
column73: slowly transitioning to the awakening zone. Yet
column74: it is noticeable that the bars in the awakening zone aren’t as big as the ones in the last sated phase. This shows that BTC might keep moving in a range for now
column75: making short-term highs and lows only from the trading perspective. Notice how the weekly BTC chart reveals a more accurate formation of the Gator Oscillator. The ellipse highlighting the oscillator’s specific zone reveals the eating zone
column76: after which the sated zone arrives quickly with sizeable green and red bars. Based on the historical analysis
column77: we expect the price action to be muted for a while before BTC enters the sleeping zone. After that
column78: we need to look for the color and size of the bars
column79: per the histogram analysis
column80: to locate the next leg of the trend. However
column81: besides the technical analysis
column82: broader crypto market sentiments also plays a key role in determining BTC’s price action. “Technical analysis is massively important and should not be ignored. Sentiment is a great way to gauge markets too
column83: and news does move the market in unexpected ways sometimes. But more often than not we can at least get some early indications in the charts. I.e
column84: Bitcoin at 73k saw seven months of green candles
column85: a near historic run
column86: a correction was coming if you could think without greed and euphoria clouding your mind. A MACD bear cross came the day after hitting the high; an early warning sign of trouble to come. But while this was happening the market was wildly euphoric
column87: Blackrock ETF buyers bought a billion that day. So
column88: yes
column89: sentiment is important but it works as a counter indicator. Try to think against the herd.” The Gator Oscillator is best read with the Alligator Indicator. This means it is imperative to locate the oscillator’s awakening phase when the Alligator Indicator’s moving averages start diverging in the following order — 5-period
column90: 8-period/9-period
column91: and 13-period. At its heart
column92: the Alligator Indicator is all about finding the golden crossover patterns in relation to the price action. The Gator Oscillator helps validate these patterns. The Gator Oscillator is a secondary indicator you pair with the Alligator moving averages. column1: 10::https://blockworks.co/news/wisdomtree-gets-ny-charter::Blockworks::article::New York gives regulatory green light to blockchain-focused asset manager::WisdomTree’s charter sets up a path for it to offer certain stablecoins on public blockchains
column2: firm’s digital assets head tells Blockworks.::WisdomTree’s charter sets up a path for it to offer certain stablecoins on public blockchains
column3: firm’s digital assets head tells Blockworks rafapress/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks WisdomTree has gained clearance to offer its “blockchain-enabled” financial app to New York users via a charter expected to also extend its digital assets offerings more broadly. The New York State Department of Financial Services (DFS) cleared the fund group — managing $106 billion in assets — to operate as a limited purpose trust company under the state’s banking law
column4: WisdomTree said Friday. The charter allows the firm to custody digital assets
column5: as well as issue
column6: exchange and manage the reserves of DFS-approved stablecoins. The newly formed WisdomTree Digital Trust Company intends to issue its gold and dollar tokens and maintain reserves for those assets
column7: the company noted. The company is also set to make its WisdomTree Prime app available to New York customers in the coming weeks
column8: the firm said in a news release. The app
column9: which launched in 21 states in July
column10: offers bitcoin and ether
column11: as well as dollar and gold tokens. It also allows users to access digital funds that have share ownership records kept on the Stellar or Ethereum blockchains. Read more: WisdomTree extends reach of Prime app
column12: plots new features Will Peck
column13: WisdomTree’s head of digital assets
column14: is now also the CEO of WisdomTree Digital Trust Company. The charter sets up a roadmap to offer products
column15: such as DFS-approved stablecoins
column16: on public blockchains outside of WisdomTree Prime
column17: Peck told Blockworks. “We believe long-term legislative and regulatory trends are likely to favor or require the use of highly regulated organizations
column18: like New York limited purpose trust companies
column19: for issuing tokenized products and providing related services
column20: ” he added. The latest regulatory clearance comes after WisdomTree executives have reiterated their vision to bring fixed income
column21: equities and commodities into the digital world via digital funds and tokenized exposures. Read more: WisdomTree triples down on future blockchain focus WisdomTree Prime’s tech stack integrates software from DTCC Digital Assets and Fireblocks’ Multi-Party Computation (MPC) wallet technology for security related to private keys management. “Crypto’s interesting
column22: but the real opportunity is blockchain-enabled finance
column23: ” Chief Operating Officer Jarrett Lilien said during an October 2022 earnings call. “It’s a mistake to confuse crypto
column24: which is a use case for the blockchain…with the broader opportunity we’re pursuing.” WisdomTree launched one of the 10 US spot bitcoin ETFs cleared to start trading in January. “We have no plans to incorporate the trust company into our ETF franchise
column25: ” Peck told Blockworks on Friday. “But over time

column1: 13::https://theconversation.com/protecting-the-right-to-be-forgotten-in-the-age-of-blockchain-104847::The Conversation::article::Protecting the ‘right to be forgotten’ in the age of blockchain::Blockchain data is unchangeable
column2: which is a problem when privacy laws require companies to delete data once it’s served its purpose.::There’s been a lot of hype about blockchain over the past year. Although best known as the technology that underpins Bitcoin
column3: blockchain is starting to disrupt other industries
column4: from supply chains to energy trading. One of the key selling points of blockchain is that once data is added to the chain
column5: it can’t be changed or removed. This makes blockchain trustworthy. But this same immutability makes blockchain problematic in a world where privacy laws require companies to delete your data from databases once it has served its purpose. This is known in some jurisdictions as the “right to be forgotten”. We have designed a blockchain in which users can remove their data from the database without violating blockchain’s consistency. Read more: Blockchain is useful for a lot more than just Bitcoin There is currently a growing market of Internet of Things devices
column6: from smart homes and self-driving cars to voice assistants and smart energy meters. These devices continuously collect digital biographies of our lives. As this data is increasingly being stored on blockchains
column7: the tension between blockchain and the right to be forgotten will only increase. Our tool could help. At its core
column8: blockchain is a database that is jointly managed by a distributed set of participants. Whenever new data is added to the database
column9: all the participants must agree to verify it. In this way
column10: blockchain removes the need for a third-party
column11: such as a bank
column12: to verify transactions. The blockchain ledger is organised into blocks
column13: where each block is linked to the previous block through cryptographic hash functions. These functions create a short code based on the content of the previous block
column14: and it is not possible to guess this code without trying all possible codes. Chaining the blocks in this manner ensures that the data stored in them cannot be altered
column15: as any changes made would break the blockchain consistency. This makes blockchains immutable. It also makes blockchain data easy to trace and audit
column16: particularly for large networks like the Internet of Things. These features are highly attractive for organisations operating across organisational boundaries
column17: and in environments where participants may not fully trust each other. The European Union’s recent General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a significant piece of legislation that is at odds with a digital economy underpinned by blockchain. The GDPR requires companies that hold people’s data to erase that data once the original purpose they needed it for is complete. That means that people must be able to remove their data from third party databases after a certain period of time. Blockchain – being unchangeable – presents an obstacle to exercising that right. Read more: What Wikipedia can teach us about blockchain technology Let’s say you live in smart home that uses sensor data to monitor your home security. You have a home insurance policy and
column18: in order to receive lower premiums
column19: you allow your smoke alarm and security sensor data to be recorded on a blockchain. The blockchain data can be accessed by the police
column20: the fire department and the insurance company so they can audit any smoke alarm or security events. Once your insurance period has ended
column21: you should be able to remove your security data from the blockchain to enhance your privacy. If you left your data on the blockchain indefinitely
column22: that would increase the risk of your data being identified as yours
column23: and your activities being tracked by any entity with access to the blockchain. A blockchain participant typically uses one or more public keys as its identities. The transactions in blockchain are stored anonymously
column24: as there is no direct link between the public keys and the real participant identity. But a breach in identity in any of the transactions
column25: for instance by linking the transaction content to other known data about the user
column26: leads to all interactions of the users’s devices
column27: stored in blockchain
column28: to be tracked by all blockchain participants. So being able to the remove data from the blockchain without “breaking the chain” would be beneficial for user privacy. It would also be beneficial to save storage space on the servers that store blockchain ledgers. But currently
column29: removing data from a blockchain is not possible without breaking the blockchain’s consistency. We have come up with a solution that makes it possible to remove your detailed transaction data from a blockchain database
column30: without removing the auditable trace that the transaction took place. As described in our peer-reviewed publication this month
column31: Memory Optimised Flexible Blockchain allows you to temporarily store
column32: summarise
column33: or completely remove your transactions from blockchain
column34: while maintaining the blockchain’s consistency. The remaining trace of the data (its hash) on the blockchain can still be used in the future
column35: in case disputes over what happened arise. For instance
column36: if a home owner wanted to verify that a break-in took place at their house under a previous insurance policy
column37: they could provide a private copy of the data with its associated hash. A legal authority could then compare the hash of the person’s data with the hash that is still stored on the shared blockchain and thereby validate the authenticity of the person’s claim. This approach provides you with full administrative control of your blockchain-stored data. It makes it possible for you to remove or summarise this data
column38: without sacrificing the ability to audit the data in the future. Read more: Using blockchain to secure the 'internet of things' It is important to note that our published approach can run atop any existing blockchain solution
column39: and does not affect the blockchain consistency. The links among blocks through hash functions are preserved
column40: even as specific blocks are removed or summarised from the chain. In other words
column41: the link of any blockchain entry remains
column42: but the bag containing some data can be cut loose. In fact
column43: as long as the removed content is stored privately outside of the blockchain
column44: the data’s authenticity can be independently verified at a later time by comparing it against the hash in the blockchain. In this way
column45: you can reclaim control of any previously shared data and exercise your right to be forgotten in the age of blockchain.::2018-10-30T18:56:34Z::Blockchain

column1: 20::https://theconversation.com/blockchains-wont-fix-internet-voting-security-and-could-make-it-worse-104830::The Conversation::article::Blockchains won’t fix internet voting security – and could make it worse::The stability and integrity of democratic society are too important to be relegated to inherently flawed computer systems that are vulnerable to malfunctions and malicious attacks.::Looking to modernize voting practices
column2: speed waiting times at the polls
column3: increase voter turnout and generally make voting more convenient
column4: many government officials – and some companies hawking voting systems – are looking to an emerging technology called a “blockchain.” That’s what’s behind a West Virginia program in which some voters serving abroad in the military will be able to cast their votes from their mobile devices. Similar voting schemes have been tried elsewhere in various places around the world. As researchers in the Initiative for CryptoCurrencies and Contracts
column5: we believe in the transformative potential of blockchain systems in a number of industries. Best known as the technology behind bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies
column6: blockchains can do much more than allow anonymous strangers to send each other money without fear of fraud or tampering. They have created new ways for people to invest in technology ventures that have attracted billions of dollars
column7: and may someday store records that make educational credentials
column8: land ownership and food origins more transparent and harder to forge. Blockchains might sound like an ideal remedy for the trust problems caused by internet voting. Data can only be added to a blockchain – not deleted or changed – because multiple copies are stored on computers owned by different people or organizations and perhaps spread across different countries. Strict controls can be placed on a blockchain’s contents
column9: preventing unauthorized data from being added. And blockchains are designed to be transparent – with their contents often readable by anyone’s computing device anywhere in the world. Yet as scholars who have studied traditional and blockchain-based voting
column10: we believe that while blockchains may help with some specific issues
column11: they can’t fix the basic problems with internet voting. In fact
column12: they could make things worse. For years
column13: experts on election security have warned that the internet is too dangerous for such socially crucial and time-sensitive functions as voting. Renowned cryptographer Ronald Rivest
column14: for instance
column15: has remarked that “Best practices for internet voting are like best practices for drunk driving” – there’s no safe way to do either one. The stakes are enormous. Democracy requires widespread public trust – not just that a declared winner actually received the largest number of votes
column16: but in the integrity of the system as a whole. People need to trust that the votes they cast are the ones that are counted
column17: that their neighbors’ votes are totaled accurately and not the result of bribery or coercion and that local tallies are communicated safely to state election officials. Even advanced computing devices today cannot provide such assurances. Most hardware and software are rife with hidden security flaws
column18: and are not regularly updated. Devices are vulnerable
column19: and so are networks. Internet outages – even caused by trivialities like gamers trying to get a leg up on their competitors – could prevent people from voting. Intentional
column20: targeted attacks against internet traffic could cause major disruptions to democratic institutions on a national scale. The stability and integrity of democratic society itself are too important to be relegated to flawed computer systems. Hackers – backed by foreign governments or not – are always looking for new targets and fresh ways to sow social discord. They’ll find – and fully exploit – any technical weaknesses available to them. Without a paper trail
column21: the very possibility that someone could have secretly changed votes will further erode public trust in democratic elections.  A key method by which blockchain voting could worsen election integrity is by claiming to increase trustworthiness without actually doing so. It’s easy to imagine a voting system in which only authorized voters could cast ballots
column22: with those ballots indelibly recorded on a blockchain. The blockchain would act as a single authoritative election record that could not be erased or tampered with. For all intents and purposes
column23: the record would be hack-proof. However
column24: tallying votes on a blockchain doesn’t magically make a voter’s phone or computer secure. A vote may be securely recorded
column25: but that means nothing if the vote was cast incorrectly to begin with. If your phone is infected with malware that switches your vote from Candidate R to Candidate D
column26: it doesn’t matter how secure the rest of the voting system is – the election has still been hacked. In some cases
column27: blockchains may be able to help voters detect that sort of tampering – but only if the hack-detection software itself hasn’t been hacked. In addition
column28: some companies’ business practices undermine the potential to trust their blockchain systems. The manufacturer of the system West Virginia will use in November – like many companies manufacturing physical voting machines – is refusing to embrace the transparency that is central to the security industry
column29: the blockchain community
column30: and democracy itself. They are not providing public access to the cryptographic protocols at the heart of their systems
column31: leaving the public instead to rely on the manufacturer’s promises of security. There’s no way for an independent auditor to be truly certain that the systems are free of subtle bugs or security flaws – or even massive holes that would be obvious to experts. Another way blockchain voting could worsen existing voting problems is by increasing the likelihood of vote buying. Sometimes a glass of beer is all that’s needed to bribe a voter. Vote buying is happily rare in large-scale U.S. elections
column32: in part because the secret ballot makes verifying a bought vote very difficult and because there are serious criminal penalties. Internet voting could completely negate both of these protections. Putting votes on blockchains eliminates the secrecy of the voting booth. Encryption doesn’t help: Software can prove mathematically to a vote buyer that a voter’s device encrypted the name of a particular candidate. In addition
column33: foreigners who might try to influence people’s votes are very hard to prosecute. Some voting companies contend that their systems publicly identify voters only by random numerical identifiers
column34: so they aren’t subject to vote-buying or intimidation. But in many of these systems
column35: voting identities can be linked to accounts in cryptocurrency systems – where a voter could receive a bribe
column36: potentially without revealing who was paid
column37: how much or by whom. Officials and companies who promote online voting are creating a false sense of security – and putting the integrity of the election process at risk. In seeking to use blockchains as a protective element
column38: they may in fact be introducing new threats into the crucial mechanics of democracy.::2018-10-18T10:34:12Z::Blockchain
column39: Cybersecurity
column40: Democracy
column41: Election integrity
column42: Online voting
column43: Public trust
column44: Voting

column2: DOT's decreased volume suggests market disinterest.::Despite a 6.61% weekly increase
column3: DOT’s decreased volume suggests market disinterest.  A significant decrease in its daily trading volume has put Polkadot [DOT] at risk of another decline. Volume is not necessarily an indicator of a price increase. If the trading volume increases
column4: it means that there is a lot of exchange going on with a token. Conversely
column5: a decline in the metric suggests that interest in a cryptocurrency has decreased. For Polkadot
column6: data from Artemis.xyz showed that the volume was $137.80 million. This was one of the lowest the project has seen since the second quarter of the year began.  However
column7: the price of DOT has increased by 6.61% in the last seven days. But a massive decline in the volume could be a stumbling block to that hike. Source: Artemis Previously
column8: there have been predictions that DOT could ride back to $10. If the volume pumps as the price increases
column9: then this forecast might become a reality. But that was not the case
column10: as rising prices and decreasing volume indicate weakness in the trend. As such
column11: DOT could swing between $7.15 and $7.60 in the short term. Furthermore
column12: AMBCrypto looked at Polkadot’s development activity as this was one aspect the project has dominated. According to Santiment
column13: development activity on the network was 2.92. Two days ago
column14: the reading of the metric was 2.20
column15: indicating that more codes have been committed to ensure that Polkadot functions properly For some projects
column16: a rise in development activity is a bullish sign for the price. But for DOT
column17: it is not always the case. Sometimes
column18: DOT’s price rises with the metric. Other times
column19: the price does not follow. Therefore
column20: this network improvement cannot be said to be a propeller to drive the token’s value higher. Apart from this
column21: AMBCrypto checked the social volume. When social volume increases
column22: it implies that the search for a project is increasing. On the other hand
column23: if the social volume dwindles
column24: it suggests that arbitrary text linked to DOT is on the decline. Source: Santiment At press time
column25: Polkadot’s social volume jumped on the 17th of May. On the 18th
column26: the metric fell. For the price
column27: this means that demand for DOT was low. Hence
column28: a 25%+ price increase might be unattainable in the short term. Meanwhile
column29: the metrics discussed here are not the only one that has the potential to influence DOT’s price. Is your portfolio green? Check the Polkadot Profit Calculator To get a full understanding
column30: other on-chain indicators like network growth can also impact the value. If the network growth rises

column33: indicating that DOT’s potential to hit double-digits might not be an option this month.   Disclaimer: AMBCrypto's content is meant to be informational in nature and should not be interpreted as investment advice. Trading

column1: 24::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchain-better-middlemen-swift::Blockworks::article::Blockchain really is better than middlemen::Opinion: The SWIFT system's forays into blockchain hint that one day the technology can replace intermediaries.::SWIFT’s forays into blockchain hint that one day the tech can replace intermediaries Soumyabrata Roy/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks The need for an organization connecting all banks is clear in today’s hyper-globalized economy where funds
column2: goods and services are sent across every corner of the globe. So as globalization expanded
column3: our deeply interconnected and centralized financial system triggered the development of SWIFT (Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication) in 1973
column4: a member-owned messaging network for financial institutions to send secure communications as well as verify and settle inter-bank transactions. SWIFT connects more than 11 thousand financial institutions across 200 countries and territories — long serving as a unified and stable institution amid a complex and volatile world order. But recently
column5: the exclusion of many sanctioned Iranian and Russian banks from SWIFT prompted China and other nations to launch competing alternative intermediaries. This has led to the wide-scale rethinking of how to structure international finance. While barring certain institutions from SWIFT due to connections with state-sponsored violence
column6: terror or other criminal activity is appropriate
column7: fractionalizing centralized entities into siloed
column8: competing groups poses a long-term threat to global finance. Changing attitudes toward centralized finance and innovative fintech applications further undermine the current financial system and highlight its shortcomings. Meanwhile
column9: the rise of blockchain-based trading solutions has led those in the traditional financial sector to question the role of intermediaries. There is a growing consideration into how this technology can enhance the speed and frequency of interbank transactions. After all
column10: the primary goal of Bitcoin and the broader crypto movement was to eliminate what seemed to be an unjust financial order. This order
column11: dominated by large banks and financial institutions
column12: wielded censorship and control over the world’s population
column13: particularly in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. Despite being largely opposed to crypto and blockchain until only a few years ago
column14: financial institutions are now embracing blockchain as a technology
column15: crypto as an investment opportunity and DeFi as a sandbox for innovative financial products. Read more from our opinion section: Bitcoin ETFs in conservative portfolios is good for crypto — and Wall Street This recognition of blockchain’s upside showcases its capability and effectiveness at removing the middleman. Further validating this were recent announcements that SWIFT
column16: in collaboration with more than 12 major financial institutions
column17: is experimenting with interoperable on-chain token transfers and tokenization. Together with SWIFT’s messaging technology
column18: Chainlink’s Cross-Chain Interoperability Protocol (CCIP) and a public Ethereum testnet are facilitating the routing of messages between legacy banking systems. This alone should legitimize the idea that digital assets and blockchains are legitimate infrastructure components that banks should and will adopt. But it’s not totally clear where this adoption could go from here
column19: as SWIFT’s use of CCIP simply gives an intermediary a new capability in the form of blockchain. It’s widely acknowledged that blockchain technology has the potential to significantly enhance the financial industry’s efficiency by diminishing its reliance on intermediaries. But this current practicality is hindered by the intricate nature of reforming a deeply entrenched
column20: centuries-old system. Rather than pursuing an immediate overhaul
column21: the emphasis should instead shift towards making gradual strides in reducing dependence on these financial intermediaries. The path to replacing intermediaries with blockchain technology necessitates the development of use cases
column22: along with achieving interoperability among various blockchains and traditional banking systems. This requires not only demonstrating the blockchain’s technological benefits — notably its security and cost-effectiveness — in an enterprise setting
column23: but also facilitating interoperability between dozens of unconnected blockchain networks. As siloes of data by design
column24: blockchains are unable to share data or transfer assets among each other. Common mechanisms to boost blockchain interoperability including bridges
column25: sidechains and cross-chain platforms all come with their fair share of complexities
column26: security vulnerabilities and potential compliance challenges. Ensuring limited interoperability and relying on susceptible smart contracts to link diverse blockchain networks pose significant barriers to embracing the technology for financial transactions. The prospect of all financial institutions unanimously adopting the same blockchain network seems unlikely
column27: given the decades-long history of technological infrastructure adoption. Consequently
column28: the necessity for intermediaries
column29: exemplified by the establishment of SWIFT for facilitating cross-bank transactions
column30: becomes evident. But that means the fintech industry
column31: which sits squarely between the finance and blockchain worlds
column32: must develop solutions and protocols to link these isolated data silos. A SWIFT report from August 2023 stated that “firms prefer to leverage their existing infrastructure
column33: manage implementations and proven business processes to connect to blockchain ledgers
column34: where tokens are recorded in a way that is both compliant and secure.” Since financial institutions
column35: understandably
column36: don’t want to abandon their existing infrastructure
column37: the key is to integrate new technologies between systems that use various blockchains. Efficient
column38: loosely coupled integrations among entities and the establishment of a “trusted network” to facilitate the secure exchange of value and data can enable institutions to engage in affordable and convenient transfers. Atomic-swap transactions play a significant role in ensuring that transactions occur smoothly and without errors
column39: especially when dealing with different blockchains and older legacy systems. They help maintain consistency and reliability throughout the transaction lifecycle. Moreover
column40: they also contribute to enhancing overall asset transfer security
column41: especially against threats like unauthorized access attempts and manipulation of data. They do this by establishing a secure communication network that supports essential operations like authentication and encryption. This means that the information and transactions within the system are better protected from potential risks. It’s unlikely that SWIFT’s dominance over the transfer of financial information and messages will be broken soon
column42: but its research into interoperable blockchains and tokenization provides major hope toward reducing the inefficiencies caused by intermediaries — such as delays in transactions
column43: additional costs and fees
column44: dependency risks
column45: lack of transparency and compliance challenges. Recognizing SWIFT as a legitimate and necessary financial institution while building the necessary infrastructure to do what it does but more efficiently
column46: affordably and securely provides the best short-term path toward a future free from middlemen. Regardless of what comes from SWIFT’s experiments with blockchain
column47: institutional adoption of blockchain technology will continue to grow as 97% of institutional investors believe tokenization will revolutionize asset management. Meeting this demand and bridging these two disconnected ecosystems can only be done through interoperability and automation
column48: which can do what intermediaries do but cheaper and faster. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column1: 25::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-news/worldcoin-foundation-unveils-new-open-source-biometric-security-system-19081/::Coinatory::article::Worldcoin Foundation Unveils New Open-Source Biometric Security System::Explore how Worldcoin Foundation is setting new benchmarks in data security with its innovative open-source biometric system
column2: designed to enhance protection and address global regulatory concerns.::The Worldcoin Foundation has recently launched an innovative open-source system
column3: aimed at bolstering the security of sensitive data
column4: including biometric information. This strategic initiative emerges at a time when digital security is under intense scrutiny
column5: particularly concerning the handling of personal and biometric data. The newly introduced system is designed to enhance data security through the use of Secure Multi-Party Computation (SMPC)
column6: a method that protects data by dispersing it across multiple locations. Hosted on Github
column7: this system exemplifies the Foundation’s commitment to transparency and community-driven development. As detailed in the Foundation’s blog
column8: this advanced SMPC technology splits a single secret into several parts
column9: distributing these amongst various stakeholders to fortify protection. This method is particularly crucial for safeguarding biometric data collected during user registration for the Worldcoin (WLD) project through Orb devices. These devices
column10: pivotal in the registration process
column11: perform iris scanning to verify identities and facilitate the distribution of WLD tokens. In a significant move towards enhanced data privacy
column12: the Worldcoin Foundation has also transitioned to this new system
column13: simultaneously erasing old iris codes that were accumulated previously. This step not only elevates the standard of data protection but also aligns with global best practices amidst growing regulatory scrutiny over data collection methods. The collaboration with TACEO and Tools for Humanity has been instrumental in overcoming the scalability and cost barriers associated with SMPC technology. Tools for Humanity
column14: co-founded by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman
column15: has been at the forefront of developing this project
column16: taking significant measures to alleviate concerns surrounding its data handling practices. This development is timely as demands for biometric verification are increasing across various sectors. With its new system
column17: the Worldcoin Foundation is leading the way in setting higher standards for data security and addressing the critical needs of digital identity verification in today’s interconnected world. source Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency

column1: 27::https://theconversation.com/blockchain-based-property-registries-may-help-lift-poor-people-out-of-poverty-98796::The Conversation::article::Blockchain-based property registries may help lift poor people out of poverty::Without secure records of property ownership
column2: many poor people around the world have trouble improving their economic situations. Several countries are already trying blockchain-based land registries.::Many developing countries don’t have a working system of tracking property rights
column3: and what they do have can be fragile and incomplete. In Haiti
column4: for instance
column5: a large earthquake in 2010 destroyed all the municipal buildings that stored documents confirming many small farmers’ ownership of the land they worked. Even years later
column6: many farmers didn’t have proof that they were landowners. People are still fighting over their land. This sort of problem – caused by natural disasters or not – is widespread
column7: causing financial hardship for families in the developing world. Without an official
column8: enforceable legal title to their property
column9: people can’t resolve disputes over who can use which land for what – like who can farm where. They also can’t borrow against their existing assets to invest in their homes
column10: businesses or communities. The value of those properties
column11: and the lost economic opportunities for owners of assets without formal documentation
column12: has been estimated at US$20 trillion worldwide. From researching blockchains and cryptocurrencies for the past three years
column13: I have become convinced that these technologies have the potential to fight root causes of poverty – including by securely recording property ownership. I’m far from alone: Blockchain-based land registries have started up in Bermuda
column14: Brazil
column15: Georgia
column16: Ghana
column17: Honduras
column18: India
column19: Russia and Rwanda. The problems these efforts are addressing are significant. Across the world
column20: land registries are inefficient and unreliable – or even downright corrupt. In Honduras
column21: some government officials altered the country’s land ownership database
column22: stealing property for themselves – including beachfront getaways. In many African countries
column23: more than 90 percent of rural land is not registered. In Ghana
column24: 78 percent of land is unregistered
column25: and the country’s courts have a long backlog of land dispute cases. In India
column26: millions of rural families lack legal ownership of the land they live and work on. The lack of secure land ownership is a bigger cause of poverty in the country than the caste system or a high illiteracy rate. Brazil has no single centralized land registry. Instead
column27: about 3
column28: 400 private agents – called “cartorios” – register and check land ownership. The system is confusing
column29: with many different documents created in different historical periods. Most land documents lack specific geographic references on property boundaries. Little wonder
column30: then
column31: that the system is plagued by corruption and double allocations – two formal documents each saying someone else owns a piece of land. These fragile and incomplete property rights systems in the developing world can affect the entire planet. In Brazil’s Amazon rainforest
column32: illicit land grabbers forge deeds and use violence and bribery to falsely claim ownership of property
column33: often under fake names
column34: which the locals call “fantasmas
column35: ” or “ghosts.” Then they clear-cut the rainforest
column36: which has serious environmental effects. Having “improved” the land by converting it to pasture
column37: these land thieves then are eligible to register as the formal owners of the land they stole. This cycle has repeated for years
column38: contributing to widespread Amazon deforestation. Using a blockchain system to record transactions could help solve these problems. A blockchain is a secure database that’s stored in a distributed – but connected – set of computers around the internet. It’s not susceptible to tampering
column39: and every addition to the database must be digitally signed
column40: making clear who’s changing what and when. So instead of a system with multiple conflicting documents
column41: some of which may have been forged or altered
column42: there’s only one record with a clear history of modifications
column43: including who did what when. Blockchain transactions can include all kinds of information
column44: including geographic boundaries or serial numbers and an owner’s identity. In Ghana
column46: the nonprofit Bitland runs a blockchain-based land registry system with a written description of each parcel of land as well as GPS coordinates of boundary points and satellite photos of the area. A collaboration between a U.S.-based blockchain startup and a Brazilian real estate registry has created a record-keeping system for land in the southern coastal municipalities of Pelotas and Morro Redondo. Its blockchain database contains details like the property’s address
column47: the owner’s name and contact information
column48: zoning rules and a unique identification number for the property itself. Blockchain can provide other advantages too. For instance
column49: when transferring land in the republic of Georgia
column50: the buyer and the seller go to a public registry house and pay a fee between $50 and $200. Moving this process onto a blockchain could drop the costs to no more than 10 cents. Just starting a blockchain-based database isn’t enough to solve these problems
column51: though. Data must be accurate when it’s entered
column52: and records must include enough information to be authoritative about the properties they’re referring to. A new technological system won’t fix much in countries where it’s hard to determine the legitimate owner in the first place. Also
column53: bureaucrats may object to new record-keeping systems that reduce their power
column54: status and privileges. However
column55: in places where governments or others who create the systems are viewed as fair and impartial and run a transparent process
column56: blockchain-based land registry systems could give many of the world’s poorest people their first real asset. Once they have straightened out complex
column57: corrupt and contradictory registry systems
column58: people can safely invest in
column59: borrow against and truly improve their properties
column60: helping lift themselves out of poverty.::2018-06-28T10:36:30Z::Blockchain

Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are baskets of investments that are designed to mimic the performance of an index or sector. They are similar to mutual funds because they pool investors’ assets and use professional fund managers to invest the money. ETFs are bought and sold on an exchange like any other listed stock. ETFs can hold a variety of asset types
column8: including: ETFs are typically considered low-risk investments because they are low-cost and hold a basket of securities or other assets
column9: which is great for diversification. They also attempt to replicate the performance of a specific market. As a result
column10: many ETFs own the same assets as the index they track. Institutional investors can create additional ETF shares or redeem them for a basket of the underlying assets. This procedure helps to match the ETF’s market price with its net asset value (NAV). If an ETF’s price differs from its NAV
column11: traders can buy or sell the ETF while simultaneously holding opposing positions in the underlying assets or a linked derivative (e.g.
column12: futures or options). This arbitrage can help bridge the price gap
column13: ensuring the ETF price closely reflects its intended index. It also enables traders to profit from market inefficiencies. Lastly
column14: in the context of cryptocurrency and Bitcoin ETFs
column15: ETFs allow investors to gain exposure to Bitcoin and crypto without the risk of actually holding the asset. ETF fund managers are subject to rigorous regulations on the custody of the underlying assets. Therefore
column16: they are required to appoint a custodian to hold their underlying assets. The custodian is usually a reputable bank or financial institution. Did you know? Coinbase Custody secures the majority of spot Bitcoin ETFs in the U.S. Recently

column1: 31::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchain-lost-decentralized-spirit::Blockworks::article::Blockchain has lost its decentralized spirit::Opinion: I often hear
column2: “We will start out centralized
column3: and we will become more decentralized later” — but this is nonsense!::Decentralization must be the cornerstone
column4: not a mere aspiration
column5: of blockchain’s journey Midjourney modified by Blockworks A narrative has taken root in the realm of blockchain technology
column6: one that champions the gradual transition from centralized control to a decentralized future. Yet this story
column7: often recited by those at the helm
column8: overlooks a fundamental truth about power: Once seized
column9: it is rarely surrendered without a struggle. This belief that a centralized beginning can smoothly transition to a decentralized ethos is more myth than reality
column10: akin to convincing a child to relinquish their tight grasp on a coveted sweet. The intention here isn’t to cast venture capitalists or early stakeholders as adversaries — it’s to advocate for a balance
column11: for fairness that underpins the very foundation of blockchain. I often hear
column12: “We will start out centralized
column13: and we will become more decentralized later.” But I believe this is nonsense! One of the hardest things to give up is power. This notion is vividly illustrated by the French Revolution
column14: a historical event that epitomizes the struggle to redistribute power from an entrenched monarchy to a democratic governance structure. Despite the promise of liberty
column15: equality and fraternity
column16: the revolution faced immense resistance from those unwilling to cede control
column17: leading to a turbulent period of conflict and transformation. This historical episode serves as a poignant reminder that once power is acquired
column18: relinquishing it is a far more formidable challenge than many anticipate. As blockchain ventures flourish
column19: the grip of those in control tightens
column20: with early investors and builders basking in the success their influence has wrought. Conversely
column21: during tumultuous times
column22: these same figures embark on campaigns of reassurance
column23: painting over cracks while strategically planning their exits. This stark duality reveals a profound flaw in the prevalent “centralize now
column24: decentralize later” mantra
column25: significantly underestimating the seductive allure of power and the inherent challenges in relinquishing it once established. The promise of distributed authority is at the heart of the blockchain revolution. The reimagining of governance where innovation serves not just the circulation of capital
column26: but empowers and amplifies a multitude of voices (not just those traditionally heard in the corridors of wealth). Yet
column27: a troubling reality overshadows this ideal: A staggering concentration of over 80% of blockchain assets in the hands of a mere 1% of wallets. Regardless of whether these assets make up projects that aim to fully decentralize or not
column28: the fact of the matter is that early stakeholders and VCs often hold the largest piece of the pie for new blockchains simply because they come in first
column29: when it’s riskiest. This imbalance transcends mere issues of fairness
column30: striking at the very viability of blockchains as engines of innovation and inclusivity. It’s a travesty that the vast majority of value creation does not come from this 1%
column31: underscoring a critical disconnect. Those who contribute the most to the ecosystem often have the least say in its direction and the smallest share in its success — those early VCs holding all the tokens do provide impact with their initial investments
column32: but their participation usually stops there. And because the protocol’s governance is based on the ownership of the token
column33: the new builders don’t have the weight to make major decisions by the major token holders. Read more from our opinion section: The worst kind of decentralization is none at all This stark discrepancy isn’t just unfair; it’s fundamentally counterproductive
column34: eroding the incentive for innovators
column35: developers and community members to pour their energy and creativity into the ecosystem. By sidelining the very individuals who are the lifeblood of innovation
column36: blockchain ecosystems risk stagnating
column37: as the centralized accumulation of benefits stifles the diverse input and collaboration essential for breakthroughs and resilience. Such a structure threatens the long-term sustainability and incentive for valuable contributors to remain engaged and invested in these projects. The long-term viability of blockchain technology depends on its ability to foster a genuinely inclusive environment where contributions are recognized and rewarded appropriately
column38: ensuring that all participants have a stake in the ecosystem’s success. Where do we go from here? I believe that many of the first-generation blockchains
column39: the foundational layers that have been the bedrock of the industry
column40: have veered too far off course. Their structures have solidified around centralization to a point where a return to true decentralization might no longer be feasible. This isn’t to say they’re doomed for failure; far from it. The potential of blockchain technology is vast
column41: its future inherently multichain
column42: promising a landscape rich with diverse and interconnected networks. However
column43: we need to start afresh if we want to harness this potential fully. This proposition might seem daunting
column44: yet considering the broader timeline of technological evolution
column45: we’re still in the nascent stages of blockchain development. The beauty of this space is its foundation in open source principles. Almost all blockchain technologies are open to being studied
column46: modified and repurposed. This openness paves the way for new projects to emerge — i.e
column47: reboots of existing chains
column48: each carrying a distinct mission and fostering a unique culture. Embarking on this path isn’t merely about technological innovation; it’s about reimagining the ethos that guides blockchain development. By initiating new projects with decentralization as a core principle
column49: we stand a chance to correct the course. This approach doesn’t merely replicate what came before
column50: but builds upon it
column51: learning from past missteps to create blockchains that are truly from the people
column52: by the people and for the people. To visualize the potential paths of blockchain
column53: consider two atomic reactions: fusion and fission. A blockchain driven by a diverse
column54: invested community is akin to a fusion reactor. It’s efficient
column55: sustainable and produces a continuous outflow of energy. This model represents a decentralized ecosystem where power and rewards are evenly spread
column56: fostering innovation and participation from all stakeholders. The result is a robust and vibrant network
column57: capable of long-term growth and adaptation. In contrast
column58: a network dominated by a few mirrors the principles of a fission bomb: initially powerful
column59: but ultimately leading to destruction. This reflects a centralized blockchain ecosystem
column60: where concentrated power leads to rapid gains that are not sustainable over time. Such a structure can stifle innovation and lead to a fragile system
column61: prone to collapse. This analogy underlines the crucial choice blockchain faces between sustainable growth and short-term gains
column62: emphasizing the need for a decentralized approach to ensure the technology’s long-term viability and success. Decentralization must be the cornerstone
column63: not a mere aspiration
column64: of blockchain’s journey. It’s about democratizing power
column65: fostering a community where everyone’s voice matters and every contribution is valued from the outset. At this pivotal juncture
column66: the trajectory of blockchain hinges on our resolve to anchor it in decentralization from the very beginning. By prioritizing decentralization as our foundational principle
column67: we chart a course toward a future where blockchain serves as a bedrock for equitable growth and democratic engagement. Let’s seize this opportunity to redefine the landscape
column68: ensuring blockchain remains a tool for empowering the many
column69: not just the few. In doing so
column70: we not only realize the full potential of blockchain technology but also contribute to the creation of a fairer
column71: more inclusive world. This is not just the path to technological innovation
column72: but a step towards a more equitable and collaborative ecosystem. We are still early. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana
column73: in your inbox
column74: every day. Subscribe to daily Solana news from Jack Kubinec and Jeff Albus. Newsletter Blockworks Daily  Upcoming Events Permissionless III WED - FRI
