column1: 34::https://theconversation.com/after-bitcoin-are-you-ready-for-the-next-generation-of-cryptocurrencies-37927::The Conversation::article::After Bitcoin
column2: are you ready for the next generation of cryptocurrencies?::With the Bank of England mooting the idea it might get involved with digital currencies
column3: you might think it was good news for Bitcoin.::The Bank of England believes that cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin could be big news and even UK chancellor George Osborne is tweeting about it. But it is important to note the detail in the central bank’s comments. It is talking about forming its own digital currencies in a trend which could yet see Bitcoin take a back seat in the future it helped to create. At a recent meeting of the Social Media Leadership Forum in London on the theme of Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies
column4: we watched a short film that portrays Bitcoin as a kind of moral alternative to traditional banks. Not only is Bitcoin the new
column5: cool choice of Generation Z
column6: but it is also a way to render third party profiteering from financial transactions irrelevant. Bitcoin is the answer! Bitcoin is the future. Bitcoin is the best way of transferring value digitally without a third party. No pal needed to pay … There was a straw poll in the audience. Who
column7: of these leaders of (mostly) large corporations in the UK
column8: had any direct experience of Bitcoin? Three hands went up – and they belonged to three young terrier-like Bitcoin entrepreneurs who chatted freely and articulately about their wares and painted the Bitcoin story as a huge
column9: unstoppable business opportunity. Two contrasting views emerged at that meeting. One is of Bitcoin as a kind of moral revolution
column10: setting us free from corporate greed
column11: interference and snooping. The other is a more prosaic view
column12: of Bitcoin as a new means of making money in a leaner and smarter way. (There is also a subsidiary view of course: of a below-the-radar gambling den
column13: a shadow money-changing table for the Dark Web) The unscientific poll in that meeting room would appear to support findings elsewhere. One online survey found that only 8% of US retailers were planning to accept Bitcoin within the next 12 months. None was currently accepting Bitcoin. Another survey found 65% of people polled were not at all familiar with Bitcoin. Of those that were even slightly familiar
column14: 80% had never used it before. There has been a significant decline in the value of bitcoins
column15: and questions have been raised about whether 2015 is Bitcoin’s make or break year. Whatever the prophets of doom say
column16: there remain bullish young entrepreneurs
column17: buoyed by the recent announcement that Dell will be the first major retailer to accept Bitcoin
column18: as well as a survey that suggests lower income populations may well embrace it. The Bank of England is understandably circumspect about the feasibility and advantages of creating its own digital currency
column19: but the simple fact of the discussion adds to the feeling that Bitcoin may be the “first draft” of something with broader application. Digital value doesn’t only have to mean money and the popular view of Bitcoin might just emphasise the “coin” a little too much. At the meeting in London much discussion centred around the “blockchain”. This public ledger of all Bitcoin transactions effectively creates continuity for Bitcoin users
column20: a context in which the currency can exist. According to technology writer Nozomi Hayase: So
column21: let’s say that Bitcoin is a good example of decentralisation and people power
column22: but it is only a first example
column23: and we will move on to using and innovating the underlying technology. It is no longer about cryptocurrencies really but about the potential of third party-free transfer. That can involve entirely different cultural interactions than just seeing value as meaning money. For example
column24: we could see voting and collective decison-making without the use of third-party control. The future can involve all kinds of creative exchange between human (and even digital) beings that are direct
column25: private when wanted
column26: and totally in the hands of sender and receiver. You might enact your will without lawyers. You might even ensure your driverless car isn’t mediated by Google but is just a direct relationship between you and the vehicle’s operating system. We will transfer all kinds of digital value and assets without third party control. Our artistic creations: our music
column27: our digital art. With the advent of drones
column28: even physical things. One of the issues that Bitcoin has is its split personality. It is touted as a place of personal empowerment and direct
column29: honest transacting that is private and yet also potentially seedy and criminal. It is billed as a moral reaction to greedy banks that
column30: at the same time
column31: offers ways to gamble in a money market not dissimilar in terms of underpinning ethics. It suggests freedom from governance even as that very lack of governance may throw up all kinds of social problems. That puts our choice of future at a crossroads. For
column32: even as we cut a direct channel from sender to receiver
column33: between sharers of different kinds of meaning and value
column34: we also potentially cut out the moral force that third parties have usefully played. Most users of Bitcoin are shocked to discover that if they are scammed into sending Bitcoins to a fake web site
column35: their money is gone for good
column36: with no way of getting it back. Currently
column37: there’s redress in the realm of conventional banking. If insurers spring up in the Bitcoin arena with hundred dollar excesses
column38: aren’t we heading back into the realm of third party involvement again anyway? And if central banks start issuing their own digital currencies? Yet the opportunity is there to take Bitcoin away from a collusion of mediocrity around money metaphors and evolve into genuinely new and exciting ways to allow the sharing of value in ways that empower individuals
column39: regardless of income. As Hayase
column40: also points out: “Bitcoin makes possible open source governance. The power to decide the course of one’s own destiny is now in the hands of ordinary people.” That huge claim implies the way crypto-value exchange is viewed and deployed is going to change significantly. Without third party governance
column41: we will have to build ethical awareness and behaviour into new versions of the platform
column42: and also research and educate ourselves in the new moral challenges and risks associated with it. The technology promises much
column43: but the whole thing may end up parked in wiring cash and simply buying and selling more stuff online. Yet it could be so much more. Blockchain technology could underpin the internet of things
column44: safeguarding our privacy
column46: and ensuring the next wave of change in the digital realm puts real control in the hands of people
column47: not corporations. Whether it does will depend not on enthusiastic Bitcoin entrepreneurs
column48: or opportunistic corporations like Dell
column49: but on the users. You and me. And maybe the odd central bank.::2015-02-26T14:46:15Z::Bank of England

column1: 38::https://blockworks.co/news/what-is-fully-homomorphic-encryption::Blockworks::article::What is fully homomorphic encryption and how will it change blockchain?::Fully homomorphic encryption differs from zero-knowledge tech
column2: as it can compute on top of encrypted data without revealing data points.::FHE differs from zero-knowledge technology
column3: as it can perform computation on top of encrypted data without revealing data points Artwork by Crystal Le In today’s digital world
column4: the need to decrypt data for computational tasks exposes it to security risks. This is a significant problem in privacy-sensitive sectors like Web3
column5: where decentralized applications and finance at times rely on both confidentiality and integrity in data processing to maintain trust and security on chain. Fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) offers a potential solution by enabling the processing of encrypted data without needing to decrypt it first
column6: thus preserving confidentiality. This advancement not only enhances data security and privacy
column7: but also extends the potential for secure data analysis and decentralized services. Guy Itzhaki
column8: CEO and co-founder of Fhenix
column9: says that in the context of blockchain
column10: FHE enables developers and users to control which assets they want to maintain privately and confidentially on-chain. This means that it will enable developers to “create a new set of use cases
column11: ” and “unlock the way for true on-chain gaming
column12: voting
column13: and auctions
column14: ” Itzahki said. Read more: Encryption startup Fhenix raises $7M for private computation Although there are some similarities between FHE and zero-knowledge (zk) technology
column15: the major difference is that FHE technology can perform computation on top of encrypted data without having to reveal or know the data points to obtain the end result. Liam McDonald
column16: head of growth at blockchain privacy startup Fairblock
column17: explained that with zk technology
column18: a prover turns necessary data into a secure code called a polynomial commitment to show it’s accurate. “In order to do this
column19: the data itself is turned into polynomial hashes and is aggregated into a polynomial equation of the hashes that represents the encoded data
column20: ” McDonald told Blockworks. This equation is then sent to a verifier
column21: who determines whether the function is true. If the function is proven
column22: a proof is generated
column23: confirming that the information inside is accurate. Peyman Momeni
column24: co-founder of Fairblock
column25: mentioned that while zk proofs allow users to validate ownership of data or correct computation
column26: they fall short in supporting computations on encrypted data
column27: especially when it involves merging private information from multiple users. “Zk is more relevant for scalability with some degree of security and limited privacy applications like shielded transfers
column28: where FHE unlocks wide range of applications coupled with higher levels of data security and privacy
column29: ” Momeni said. When combined with the benefits of the blockchain
column30: FHE provides enhanced privacy
column31: which is a core component that is missing in the existing blockchain ecosystem
column32: said Kaal Dhairya
column33: a Shiba Inu developer. “Apart from true end-to-end encryption of data
column34: this opens up a variety of use cases
column35: including supply chain/food chain to blockchain
column36: private voting for DAOs
column37: efficient prediction markets
column38: on-chain casino games
column39: hidden items in on-chain games
column40: and many more
column41: ” Dhairya said. Momeni notes that in most crypto use cases
column42: it is necessary to combine private inputs from multiple users
column43: compute over them and decrypt the results
column44: meaning that there would be a “shared private state.” “As an example in private governance or sealed-bid auctions
column45: all users encrypt their votes or bids
column46: we perform on-chain computing over encrypted data
column47: then in the end we need to decrypt the actual results
column48: ” he said. “In this case we don’t actually decrypt the individual bids/votes/trades
column49: just the updated state or the result of computation.” Read more: Fully homomorphic encryption rollups are one step closer to reality To ensure no single user has exclusive access
column50: a system of multiple validators should share this decryption key
column51: and decrypt the information collaboratively at the appropriate time. According to Momeni
column52: current FHE technologies face the technical hurdle of creating a decentralized system for managing these decryption keys. Fairblock
column53: however
column54: is developing a solution with a decentralized network for key generation
column55: aiming to make FHE technology more accessible and practical for developers and various platforms. It’s worth noting that FHE isn’t the only privacy solution being developed on the blockchain today; there are several other solutions that might be more beneficial for developers building different tools. “There are different solutions with different trade-offs
column56: so we’re trying to enable developers to use them correctly without passing a cryptography course
column57: ” Momeni said. Read more from our opinion section: Privacy is going mainstream In the case of Fairblock
column58: the company sees itself as being similar to Axelar
column59: Eigenlayer
column60: or Celestia
column61: where a network facilitates and accelerates other builders. “Instead of cross-chain messaging
column62: shared security
column63: and data availability
column64: we’re abstracting away all of the bandwidth overhead
column65: onboarding and maintenance costs of running the network in a secure and decentralized way
column66: ” he said. The company recently rolled out its public testnet
column67: which is designed for developers of select layer-2 networks to tailor how they integrate encryption and decryption into applications. It currently enables users to leverage identity-based encryption (IBE)
column68: witness encryption (WE) with integration of fully homomorphic encryption still under development. Updated March 13

column2: 2015 has seen the continued fall in value of the currency that was supposed to fuel the digital age. In the last 10 days alone
column3: it…::Bitcoin was dubbed the worst investment of 2014. As predicted however
column4: 2015 has seen the continued fall in value of the currency that was supposed to fuel the digital age. In the last 10 days alone
column5: it has lost 26% in value. If 2014 was a bad year for the digital currency
column6: 2015 looks like it will be even worse. Barely days into the year
column7: UK-based Bitcoin exchange Bitstamp was “hacked” and 19
column8: 000 Bitcoin stolen. At the time
column9: this loss was valued at US $5 million. Bitstamp has since come back online
column10: with revamped security from BitGo. It may however
column11: all be a bit too late. Hacks of Bitcoin exchanges have come to characterise the Bitcoin world. It isn’t something that is necessarily inherent in Bitcoin itself
column12: but more of a feature of the types of companies that have sprung up around the troubled technology. At best
column13: the hack of one-time leading Bitcoin exchange Mt Gox
column14: was a result of sloppy coding and business practices. At worst
column15: it was an inside job
column16: defrauding its customers of $487 million. A more ominous problem has cast its shadow on the future of Bitcoin. Bitcoin relies on people to engage in “mining” to validate every exchange of the virtual currency. Miners
column17: do some agreed calculations
column18: and if they are fast
column19: or lucky
column20: enough
column21: will succeed in winning some newly produced Bitcoin in exchange for adding the transaction onto the Bitcoin ledger called the Blockchain. The strategy of mining has become Bitcoin’s achilles’ heel. The design of Bitcoin dictates that the difficulty of mining will increase as more Bitcoins are produced and more miners get involved. This has led to mining being dominated by companies that can scale to the point where they can guarantee to earn a certain percentage of Bitcoins created each day. As Bitcoin’s value has dropped
column22: the economics of the mining operation have changed
column23: to the point that mining ceases to be economically viable. Cloud mining company CEX.io suspended their mining operations this week
column24: declaring that it needed the price of Bitcoin to be at least $320 before it would be able to resume its operations. Unfortunately for them
column25: the price has dropped even further since and the likelihood of it climbing back to $320 seems slim. Another mining company
column26: CoinTerra
column27: is being sued by a data centre provider for $5.4 million for unpaid fees. The cost of power alone to run CoinTerra’s services was $12
column28: 000 a day. The underlying protocol of Bitcoin does allow for the relative difficulty of mining to be eased if it becomes to hard for miners to stay in operation. In fact
column29: this happened last month for the first time since 2012. It could theoretically continue to become easier as the Bitcoin price drops. The issue is however
column30: that this wasn’t supposed to happen. Bitcoin’s price was supposed to keep increasing as more Bitcoins came onto the market. Bitcoins value relies purely on the belief of the people who buy and sell it. There is no central bank or government around to support it in the case of its value crashing to zero. Once that belief is questioned
column31: Bitcoin becomes unsustainable. Even if the price of Bitcoin doesn’t go to zero
column32: the chances the Bitcoin community convincing the wider public
column33: governments
column34: and industry that Bitcoin really represents the future of the world’s digital economy will become extremely unlikely. For the time being
column35: Bitcoin still has enough devotees who believe that the currency will eventually recover and still claim the crown as the future enabler of all digital commerce. However
column36: even they are having their doubts that this grand technological experiment may have run its course.::2015-01-13T14:24:08Z::N/A::David Glance::Business

column1: 43::https://ambcrypto.com/shiba-inus-q2-price-prediction-will-shib-retest-0-000030/::AMBCrypto::article::Shiba Inu’s Q2 price prediction: Will SHIB retest $0.000030?:: The golden cross suggests potential bullish trend for SHIB. But it also depends on the money and exchange flow.::The golden cross suggests potential bullish trend for SHIB. But it also depends on the money and exchange flow.  Shiba Inu [SHIB] posted an 11.69% increase in the last seven days. However
column2: the token has been struggling to maintain that momentum over the last two days. Irrespective of that
column3: some technical indicators suggest that the price could get back to its rally. One of the signals AMBCrypto observed was the golden cross on the 4-hour SHIB/USD chart. To get a golden cross
column4: traders look at the Exponential Moving Average (EMA). This pattern forms when the shorter EMA crosses above the longer EMA.  At press time
column5: the 20 EMA (blue) had crossed over the 50 EMA (yellow)—A golden cross
column6: indicating a bullish trend. Furthermore
column7: SHIB’s price had not slipped below the 50 EMA
column8: meaning the thesis has not been invalidated. However
column9: the Money Flow Index (MFI) was down to 30.21. This decrease indicates that a lot of capital has flowed out of the SHIB market. In a bearish situation
column10: this could lead the price to $0.000022. However
column11: the MFI might likely hit the oversold point
column12: which could be around 20.00 or below. Should this be the case
column13: the price of the Shiba Inu native token might rebound. Sustaining the golden cross if (when) this happens could take the price higher. Source: TradingView The likely first stop could be $0.000027
column14: after which
column15: SHIB’s value could rise to $0.000030
column16: which was close to the ceiling it hit in March. For this
column17: considering the technical aspect alone might be enough. Hence
column18: AMBCrypto took things from the state of the token on-chain. In doing this
column19: we assessed the exchange inflow and outflow. If the exchange inflow is higher than the outflow
column20: it means that the token involved could face selling pressure
column21: and the value could drop. On the other hand
column22: a higher exchange outflow favors a price increase. As of this writing
column23: SHIB’s exchange outflow was 53.20 billion. The inflow
column24: at the opposite end
column25: was 50.55 billion. Historically
column26: the 3 billion difference between the metrics might not be enough to support a one-directional movement. As such
column27: SHIB’s price might consolidate in the short term. Source: Santiment From our outlook
column28: the price might move between $0.000023 and $0.000025. Going forward
column29: traders might need to keep an eye on the netflow. In a case where the outflow doubles the exchange inflow
column30: then we might see SHIB’s price move upward slowly. If sustained
column31: a breakout to $0.00030 could be achieved. Read Shiba Inu’s [SHIB] Price Prediction 2024-2025 A summary of the analysis suggested that this rise could come to pass before the end of May. However
column32: there is a likelihood that this prediction could be invalidated. Thus
column33: traders might need to watch for changes in the status of Shiba Inu on-chain
column34: and from the technical perspective.   Disclaimer: AMBCrypto's content is meant to be informational in nature and should not be interpreted as investment advice. Trading

column1: 45::https://blockworks.co/news/nirvana-alternative-to-google-cloud-aws::Blockworks::article::Nirvana Cloud debuts as blockchain-optimized alternative to AWS and Google Cloud::Nirvana Labs is debuting its Nirvana Cloud computing service meant to work specifically with blockchain workloads.::The startup’s cloud service uses hardware optimized for blockchains Nirvana Labs and Adobe Stock modified by Blockworks Nirvana Labs is debuting its Nirvana Cloud computing service meant to work specifically with blockchain workloads. CEO Dan Burke told Blockworks that the startup raised $1.7 million in pre-seed funding
column2: and counts blockchain platforms like Chainlink and Avalanche as clients. According to Burke
column3: the company is hoping to lure Web3 projects away from more general purpose cloud providers like Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Google Cloud
column4: which are widely used across many industries
column5: including the crypto space. But Nirvana is not building a decentralized computing platform
column6: a la Golem
column7: nor a decentralized storage solution like IPFS. Rather
column8: it’s taking the centralized status quo and specializing it for Web3. Read more: Researchers use blockchain network to simulate the dawn of life on Earth AWS and Google Cloud provide public cloud services that enable the purchase of resources such as servers and storage via the internet. This arrangement is often cost-effective
column9: as it eliminates the need for companies to maintain their own physical hardware. Blockchain applications tend to be compute-intensive though
column10: which drives up the costs Web3 that companies are paying to public cloud providers. Crypto is big business for Amazon in particular
column11: which hosts 35% of all Ethereum nodes
column12: according to the website ethernodes. Nirvana Cloud says it can offer much reduced costs and better efficiency for blockchain workloads compared to AWS by doing away with unnecessary virtualization. In computing
column13: virtualization allows for the creation of virtual machines (VMs) that operate independently from their underlying physical hardware. This essentially turns one physical computer into many virtual ones
column14: allowing each to run its own tasks as if it were a separate machine. In short
column15: virtualization makes it possible to run many different applications and processes without needing multiple physical computers. This lets cloud service providers offer a more efficient and flexible service to customers. But traditional services like AWS and Google Cloud
column16: while versatile
column17: often adopt a general-purpose approach that may not be as cost or resource-efficient for specific applications
column18: like the energy-intensive ones found in Web3. Read more: Cloud computing is operated by an anti-competitive oligopoly
column19: says Osuri Nirvana Labs addresses this by reducing the virtualization layer. It slims down the middleman software and focuses its hardware on the specific needs of Web3 technologies
column20: like cryptocurrency transactions or smart contracts. The result is a setup that’s not just faster and more reliable for these tasks
column21: but also more cost-effective. A Nirvana Labs document reviewed by Blockworks suggests that
column22: for a setup with two virtual CPUs and 8 gigabytes of RAM
column23: Nirvana Cloud costs about 19.5% less than AWS and 26.91% less than Google Cloud Platform per month. According to the company
column24: Nirvana Cloud distinguishes itself by offering a “bare metal” cloud service. Unlike typical cloud environments where server resources are shared among multiple consumers
column25: each Nirvana server is dedicated to a single client. This approach
column26: where hardware resources are not pooled
column27: is meant to ensure superior performance for computation-heavy tasks
column28: like blockchain validation
column29: by maximizing the efficiency and reliability of the service. Read more: Google Cloud eyes more involvement in fast-evolving Web3 segment However
column30: some would argue that solutions like Nirvana’s don’t go far enough — and that computing resources will always be a risk for crypto unless the base layer is decentralized. “We have decentralized payments. We have decentralized storage. We have to have decentralized compute or else this whole decentralized world isn’t really decentralized
column31: ” Tom Trowbridge
column32: co-founder of decentralized computing platform Fluence
column33: said. But in the interim
column34: increased scrutiny on the cloud layer couldn’t hurt. Burke said that the Web3 development world often doesn’t think enough about what’s happening at the tech’s layer zero. He jokingly added
column35: “I mean
column36: we have a company in the space called LayerZero that’s literally built on Google Cloud.” Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana
column37: in your inbox

column1: 46::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-news/crypto-developer-alexey-pertsev-receives-five-year-sentence-amid-tornado-cash-19047/::Coinatory::article::Crypto Developer Alexey Pertsev Receives Five-Year Sentence Amid Tornado Cash Controversy::Alexey Pertsev
column2: developer of Ethereum-based Tornado Cash
column3: has been sentenced to 64 months in prison for abetting money laundering
column4: setting a legal precedent for crypto privacy tools.::In a landmark ruling on May 14
column5: Dutch courts have sentenced Alexey Pertsev to 64 months in prison due to his involvement with Tornado Cash
column6: a controversial Ethereum privacy application accused of facilitating $2.2 billion in illicit transactions. The conviction comes after a trio of judges upheld allegations that Pertsev aided in laundering funds through the crypto mixer
column7: which has been under scrutiny for its role in high-profile cybercrimes
column8: including a $600 million heist affecting the Ronin Bridge
column9: linked to the notorious Lazarus Group from North Korea. Defense arguments posited that holding developers accountable for the potential misuse of decentralized platforms sets a dangerous precedent
column10: a sentiment widely supported in the cryptocurrency sector. However
column11: the court dismissed these defenses
column12: emphasizing that the design of Tornado Cash was inherently aimed at supporting illegal activities and that technological innovation does not absolve individuals from legal responsibilities. Pertsev’s arrest in August 2022 followed shortly after the U.S. Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) imposed sanctions on Tornado Cash for its alleged roles in laundering and financing illicit activities. Initially detained for eight months
column13: Pertsev was later placed under house arrest. The court has decided that his time served will be deducted from the total sentence
column14: effectively reducing his remaining prison term to approximately four years and six months. This case could significantly influence how global legal systems interpret and manage decentralized privacy technologies and crypto mixers. While Pertsev’s co-founders
column15: Roman Storm and Roman Semenov
column16: face similar charges in the United States
column17: broader regulatory challenges persist. In the U.S.
column18: the debate intensifies as lawmakers and enforcement agencies clash over the regulatory framework for digital assets and decentralized finance (DeFi)
column19: highlighting a critical need for clarity and consensus in digital currency governance. Recent inquiries by U.S. Senators into the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network’s (FinCEN) approach to prosecuting crypto mixers as illegal money transmitters underscore the ongoing legislative and judicial complexities surrounding cryptocurrency operations. As the sector continues to evolve
column20: the outcomes of such cases will likely have profound implications for the development and regulation of privacy-focused technologies in the financial landscape. source Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency

column1: 48::https://theconversation.com/ethereum-what-is-it-and-why-has-the-price-gone-parabolic-153733::The Conversation::article::Ethereum: what is it and why has the price gone parabolic?::While bitcoin is only a currency
column2: the second-largest cryptocurrency is at the heart of a platform that aims to transform the internet.::The price of the world’s second largest cryptocurrency
column3: ether
column4: hit a new all-time high of US$1
column6: 050) on January 19. This breached a previous high set three years ago and gave ether a total value (market capitalisation) of US$160 billion
column7: although it has since fallen back to around US$140 billion. Ether
column8: which runs on a technology system known as the ethereum blockchain
column9: is worth over ten times the price it was when it bottomed during the COVID market panic of March 2020. And the cryptocurrency is still only five years old. In part
column10: this remarkable rise in the value is due to excess money flowing into all the leading cryptocurrencies
column11: which are now seen as relatively safe store-of-value assets and a good speculative investment. Ether/US$ price But ether’s price rise has even outstripped that of the number one cryptocurrency
column12: bitcoin
column13: which “only” had a seven-fold increase since March. Ether has outperformed partly due to several improvements and new features being rolled out over the next few months. So what are ether and ethereum and why is this cryptocurrency now worth more than corporate giants such as Starbucks and AstraZeneca? Blockchains are online ledgers that keep permanent tamper-proof records of information. These records are continually verified by a network of computer nodes similar to servers
column14: which are not centrally controlled by anyone. Ether is just one of over 8
column15: 000 cryptocurrencies that use some form of this technology
column16: which was invented by the anonymous “Satoshi Nakamoto” when he released bitcoin over a decade ago. The ethereum blockchain was first outlined in 2013 by Vitalik Buterin
column17: a 19-year old prodigy who was born in Russia but mostly grew up in Canada. After crowdfunding and development in 2014
column18: the platform was launched in July 2015. As with the bitcoin blockchain
column19: each ethereum transaction is confirmed when the nodes on the network reach a consensus that it took place – these verifiers are rewarded in ether for their work
column20: in a process known as mining. But the bitcoin blockchain is confined to enabling digital
column21: decentralised money – meaning money that is not issued from any central institution unlike
column22: say
column23: dollars. Ethereum’s blockchain is categorically different in that it can host both other digital tokens or coins
column24: and decentralised applications. Decentralised applications or “dapps” are open-source programs developed by communities of coders not attached to any company. Any changes to the software are voted on by the community using a consensus mechanism. Perhaps the best known applications running on the ethereum blockchain are “smart contracts”
column25: which are programs that automatically execute all or parts of an agreement when certain conditions are met. For instance
column26: a smart contract could automatically reimburse a customer if
column27: say
column28: a flight was delayed more than a prescribed amount of time. Many of the dapp communities are also operating what is known as decentralised autonomous organisations or DAOs. These are essentially alternatives to companies and seen by many as the building blocks of the next phase of the internet or “web 3.0”. A good example is the burgeoning trading exchange Sushiswap. Ethereum has evolved and developed since its launch six years ago. In 2016
column29: a set of smart contracts known as “The DAO” raised a record US$150 million in a crowdsale but was quickly exploited by a hacker who siphoned off one- third of the funds. However
column30: since then
column31: the ethereum ecosystem has matured considerably. While hacks and scams remain common
column32: the overall level of professionalism appears to have improved dramatically. Financial interest in ether tends to follow in the wake of bitcoin rallies because it is the second-largest cryptocurrency and
column33: as such
column34: quickly draws the attention of the novice investor. All the same
column35: there are other factors behind its recent rally. The first is the pace of innovation on the platform. Most activity in the cryptocurrency space happens on ethereum. In 2020
column36: we saw the emergence of decentralised finance (DeFi). DeFi is analogous to the mainstream financial world
column37: but with the middleman banks cut out. Users can borrow
column38: trade
column39: lend and invest through autonomous smart contracts via protocols like Compound
column40: Aave and Yearn Finance. It sounds like science fiction
column41: but this is no hypothetical market – approximately US$24 billion is locked into various DeFi projects right now. Importantly
column42: DeFi allows users to generate income on their cryptocurrency holdings
column43: especially their ether tokens. The second factor behind the ether surge is the launch of ethereum 2.0. This upgrade addresses major concerns impacting the current version of ethereum. In particular
column44: it will reduce transaction fees – especially useful in DeFi trading
column45: where each transaction can end up costing the equivalent of tens of US dollars. Ethereum 2.0 will also eliminate the environmentally wasteful mining currently required to make the ethereum blockchain function (the same is true of many other cryptocurrencies
column47: ethereum should be able to drop the need for vast industrial mining warehouses that consume huge amounts of energy. Instead
column48: transactions will be validated using a different system known as “proof-of-stake”. The sense that ethereum addresses problems like these quickly rather than letting them sit could prove a major differential from the sometimes sluggish and conservative pace of the bitcoin development culture. A final factor is the launch of ethereum futures trading on February 8. This means that traders will be able to speculate on what ether will be worth at a given date in the future for the first time – a hallmark of any mature financial asset. Some analysts have said the recent bitcoin rally has been fuelled by traditional investment firms
column49: and the launch of ethereum futures is often touted as opening the doors for the same price action. However
column50: as every seasoned cryptocurrency user knows
column51: both currencies are extremely volatile and are as liable to crash by extremes as rise by them. Bitcoin’s price fell 85% in the year after the last bull market in 2017
column52: while ether was down by 95% at one stage from its previous high of US$1
column53: 428. Whatever the valuation
column54: the future of ethereum as a platform looks bright. Its challenge is ultimately external: projects such as Cardano and Polkadot
column55: created by individuals who helped launch ethereum itself
column56: are attempting to steal ethereum’s crown. But as bitcoin has shown
column57: first-mover advantage matters in cryptocurrency
column58: and despite bitcoin’s relative lack of features it is unlikely to be moved from its dominant position for some time. The same is most likely true for the foreseeable future with ethereum.::2021-01-21T19:41:57Z::Bitcoin

column1: 52::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchain-transparency-bug::Blockworks::article::Blockchain transparency is a bug::Opinion: Blockchain transparency is making Web3 the surveillance tool it was meant to free societies from.::Blockchain transparency is making Web3 the surveillance tool it was meant to free societies from Artwork by Crystal Le Blockchain transparency is a bug. Transparency isn’t a feature of decentralization that is truly needed to perform on-chain transactions securely — it’s a bug that forces Web3 users to expose their most sensitive financial data to anyone who wants to see it. Several blockchain marketing tools have emerged over the past few years
column2: allowing marketers and salespeople to use the freely flowing on-chain data for user insights and targeted advertising. But this time
column3: it’s not just behavioral data that is analyzed. Now
column4: your most sensitive financial information is also added to the mix. Web3 will never become mainstream unless we manage to solve this transparency problem. Blockchain and Web3 were an escape from centralized power
column5: making information transparent so that centralized entities cannot own one’s data. Then 2020 came
column6: Web3 and NFTs boomed
column7: and many started talking about how free flowing
column8: available-to-all data is a clear improvement from your data being “stolen” by big data companies as a customer. Some may think if everyone can see the data
column9: transparency will empower users to take ownership of and profit from their own data. Yet
column10: transparency does not mean data can’t be appropriated nor that users are really in control. The fact that data is transparent and flowing freely doesn’t mean it cannot be appropriated; in fact
column11: data appropriation is already happening in Web3. Many are taking advantage of all of this open data to simplify on-chain data analysis and monetize it for anyone interested in learning the behavioral patterns of Web3 users. With the immense number of transactions and wallets
column12: the large volume of data becomes a goldmine for those skilled enough to understand it. Transparency opened doors for Web2’s profiling practices to enter Web3. Tools like Nansen or Addressable help agencies and advertisers gather transactional and asset-held data to analyze consumer behavior and holdings to understand trends
column13: create potential customer profiles and launch targeted advertising programs. Privacy projects will argue that total privacy as a given is the only way to protect users. Yet
column14: they aren’t right either. Users already need — and increasingly will need — to use their on-chain data to verify holdings and transactions for regulatory purposes and verifications. If everything is private and cannot be selectively encrypted
column15: there is no way to verify the funds and their origins. Many such privacy solutions have already been sanctioned by governments. Read more from our opinion section: Ethereum L2s are a bug masquerading as a feature At the same time
column16: users might want to proudly showcase some of their assets (like NFTs). But this doesn’t mean they want to allow everyone else to peek into all their other crypto holdings and transactions (which they do
column17: since an address holding a certain NFT can be checked). Take 50 people holding NFTs for one project
column18: analyze their other holdings and trends across transactional patterns
column19: and you have a pretty accurate user profile you can target. Web3 needs to shift from the appropriation of freely flowing data to a data ownership model
column20: where users get full control over what data gets shared
column21: with whom
column22: when and how. Vitalik Buterin addressed this transparency problem
column23: posing a similar solution in his September paper on blockchain privacy and regulatory compliance. He argued that transparency is a security issue and showed there is a way to allow Web3 to be compliant and transparent only when needed. The solutions and the technology to make this shift are here. What is now needed is a change in user mindset and awareness that this transparency bug exists. Blockchain transparency is making Web3 become the surveillance tool it was meant to free societies from. It poses a growing concern
column24: especially as the popularity of community rewards platforms increases and more and more users are combining their wallet addresses with social media accounts. The Web3 crowd needs to be educated about the risks of keeping all their data out in the open. In the decentralized world
column25: the change needs to happen bottom-up as people realize how their blockchain transactions are being monetized for uses they have no control over. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column5: has announced the restoration of some services following a significant system-wide outage that temporarily halted trading activities across its website and mobile application. The issue

column1: 54::https://cryptobriefing.com/senators-question-crypto-transmitter-laws/::Crypto Briefing::article::Senators question DOJ for 'unprecedented interpretation' over Samourai Wallet and Tornado Cash::Senators say that the crypto mixer services under scrutiny don't meet money transmitter definitions.::Join the hunt for $12
column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Senators Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) and Cynthia Lummis (R-Wyo.) have sent a letter to Attorney General Merrick Garland
column4: questioning the Department of Justice’s (DOJ) “unprecedented interpretation” of the law in its pursuit of cryptocurrency software services
column5: such as Samourai Wallet and Tornado Cash
column6: as unlicensed money-transmitting businesses. The senators argue that the DOJ’s approach contradicts previous guidance from the Treasury Department’s Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)
column7: which held that non-custodial crypto services should not be treated as money transmitters. The lawmakers express concern that the DOJ’s interpretation could treat software developers as criminals for “merely writing and publishing code” used by others
column8: setting a dangerous precedent that contradicts settled law and raises First Amendment concerns. The letter specifically addresses the DOJ’s recent pursuit of Samourai Wallet
column9: a crypto privacy business
column10: last month. The senators argue that subjecting developers of non-custodial crypto asset software to potential criminal liability as unregistered money transmitters goes against the well-established interpretation of the law. The DOJ has also argued in a court filing that FinCEN’s guidance on crypto mixers did not address the idea of “control
column11: ” a stance that the senators’ letter takes issue with. The lawmakers maintain that the rule actually requires the service to take control of the funds to be treated as a transmitter. Senator Lummis emphasized the importance of the issue
column12: stating: “I’m concerned the DOJ’s interpretation would treat software developers as criminals for merely writing and publishing code used by others […]” The letter comes as Congress grapples with establishing comprehensive digital assets legislation
column13: including money-laundering protections. A legislative piece called FIT21 (Financial Innovation and Technology for the 21st Century Act) is expected to go up for deliberation by the House of Representatives soon. However
column14: such a legislative piece would only be specific to the governance of crypto markets and would not
column15: as such
column16: establish clearer definitions of what constitutes illicit transactions or the facilitation of such exchanges through open software. Share this article The information on or accessed through this website is obtained from independent sources we believe to be accurate and reliable

column1: 55::https://theconversation.com/decentralised-finance-calls-into-question-whether-the-crypto-industry-can-ever-be-regulated-151222::The Conversation::article::Decentralised finance calls into question whether the crypto industry can ever be regulated::It is near impossible to regulate currencies and financial services that were built to avoid regulation – but it is increasingly necessary::As stock markets around the world struggle through the pandemic
column2: Bitcoin has seen a steady rise in its price. The cryptocurrency is steadily climbing back towards its all time high of US$20
column4: 000) in 2017. While this growth can be partially explained by investors being spooked by stock markets during the pandemic and looking for better investments
column5: it is also influenced by the new
column6: but evolving
column7: decentralised finance market
column8: also known as DeFi. DeFi allows people to engage in financial services such as borrowing
column9: lending and investing but without intermediaries such as banks using blockchains and cryptocurrencies. Blockchains store digital records of transactions. Individual records
column10: called “blocks”
column11: are linked together in a single list
column12: which creates the “blockchain”. Blockchains are used in DeFi to create “smart contracts”
column13: which are automated
column14: enforceable agreements that don’t need intermediaries
column15: such as banks. The DeFi market is one to watch. It has grown to become worth US$14.61 billion – an increase of almost 700% since the beginning of 2020. DeFi has enormous potential in international trade by making payments more efficient. It could do away with the need to use intermediaries such as correspondent banks
column16: which are financial institutions that offer services to a customer on behalf of another bank
column17: usually in a foreign country. DeFi could also potentially help with the availability and equality of opportunities to access financial services. There is
column18: however
column19: a difficulty holding any particular person or entity accountable for any technological failure in this market. This can be anything from security failures
column20: when the system is hacked and digital assets are stolen
column21: to the collapse of the entire system. Read more: While coronavirus rages
column22: bitcoin has made a leap towards the mainstream Unlike traditional banks
column23: which can be sanctioned or shut down
column24: there is nobody who can be held accountable or take responsibility when something goes wrong. This is because the applications in DeFi are built on decentralised systems
column25: which distribute functions and power away from a central location or authority. Every node (computer
column26: IP
column27: server) connected to the system makes its own decision
column28: and the final behaviour of the system is a collection of the decisions of these individual nodes. This is further complicated by the fact that DeFi transactions typically operate globally
column29: and when regulatory standards are created for this sector in one country
column30: platforms may gravitate to countries with less strict ones. There is also the challenge of global coordination
column31: especially as countries are at varying stages of financial regulatory development. While advanced economies such as the UK and US have stronger regulatory frameworks
column32: most in developing economies do not. DeFi platforms are also subject to hacks and cyberattacks and are growing platforms for money laundering. These factors raise the question of whether decentralised platforms can ever be regulated
column33: or if the rules for the crypto industry set by the Financial Actions Task Force (FATF)
column34: the global anti-money laundering watchdog
column35: is robust enough. FATF only covers centralised systems or virtual assets service providers such as cryptocurrency exchanges. These are licensed businesses that allow customers to trade crypto or digital currencies for other assets
column36: such as fiat currencies like the pound sterling
column37: US dollars and euros. Such exchanges must adhere to FATF’s “know your customer” requirements
column38: where the platforms are expected to know the parties transacting on them. FATF requirements do not cover financial activities occurring on decentralised systems. The idea of regulating centralised platforms and cryptocurrency exchanges – where people purchase crypto to use to transact on DeFi platforms
column39: but leaving DeFi platforms unregulated – limits the overall effectiveness of the regulation of the whole crypto industry. Unless it is built into the source code of a decentralised application
column40: it is difficult to see how regulation can be achieved. This would require cooperation with blockchain software developers. However
column41: this may be placing too much power in their hands as they could manipulate the code to circumvent regulatory oversight at any time they choose to. Regulators may not want to do this. They could try to ban such activities instead. In the EU and the US
column42: legislation has been proposed that could potentially ban the operation of DeFi. These include the Markets in Crypto-Assets (MiCA) Regulation proposed by the EU and the US Stable Bill proposed in December 2020. Although it is not impossible to shut off a decentralised system
column43: it is very difficult to achieve and it would require heavy reliance on government or regulatory authorities. It would also require getting access to IP addresses
column44: cooperating with local internet service providers
column45: identifying or tracing the physical location of people using the system and using the police to effectively shut down such platforms or activities. Locating and then prosecuting anyone within one jurisdiction would not be an easy task. Although this would potentially deter people from using these services and slow down the number of people using them for illegal means
column46: it would be difficult to achieve on a global scale – which would threaten international standards. What is clear is that regulators need to acquire technological expertise and be willing to engage with a wider group of stakeholders
column47: including software developers
column48: to effectively regulate DeFi. It is worth noting that DeFi has been built mainly on the Ethereum blockchain
column49: just as initial coin offerings (ICOs) were in 2017. ICOs eventually fizzled out due to their links with fraud. Whatever its future
column50: DeFi is a fast-growing industry and deserves urgent regulatory attention.::2020-12-11T14:59:16Z::Bitcoin

This guide dives into the essential information about Tezos staking. We explain what it means to stake your XTZ holding and examine the various methods available. We explored multiple options over several weeks to identify the top platforms for buying Tezos (XTZ). Our selection criteria focused on the core elements that make the buying/trading experience reliable and efficient. Our evaluation was largely based on key metrics such as security
column9: fees

column12: and compliance. Here’s a quick look at the reasons why we chose the following platforms: Kraken Kraken stands out as a goliath in the crypto space
column13: having earned the trust of users across the world with its stringent security measures and exceptional market liquidity. The exchange deploys features like cold storage options
column14: 2FA
column15: and encrypted data storage to ensure that your transactions remain under lock and key. Kraken caters to new and seasoned traders by offering a giant pool of trading information and competitive transaction fees. Coinbase As one of the world’s largest and most popular exchanges
column16: Coinbase commands the kind of trust you expect from your go-to crypto trading platform. It offers an intuitive interface that suits crypto newcomers particularly well. However

column3: away from widespread Web3 adoption.::What could come next for Web3 is grounded in history — and completely unpredictable Artwork by Crystal Le There’s plenty going on with crypto and blockchain right now. But the biggest news of the year is still the Securities and Exchange Commission’s approval of spot bitcoin ETFs — with $4.5 billion in trading volume in the first 24 hours
column4: all eyes are on how this new investment vehicle will impact public engagement with crypto and blockchain. Because even though blockchain technology has been in use (and in the public discourse) for over a decade
column5: it’s still accurate to compare its progress to the early days of the internet. Its nascent point in evolution — and clear potential for eventual disruption — echoes Clayton M. Christensen’s disruptive innovation theory
column6: a theory which highlights how technologies overturn established markets. No matter how revolutionary or unique
column7: fresh innovation remains intrinsically tied to the past. By learning lessons from pioneering technologies that are now accepted as core to life and society
column8: we can navigate the complexities of this next great technological shift. While there will be challenges in acceptance and utility along the way
column9: I believe blockchain’s path to imminent mass adoption closely mirrors the innovation cycles of past technologies with humble
column10: then astronomical trajectories. And the SEC’s spot bitcoin ETF approval is a moment that signals both validation and acceleration. Let me explain. Like the nascent stages of both the internet and cloud computing
column11: blockchain’s initial phase was marked by enthusiasm tempered with challenges. Early blockchain adopters — akin to pioneers of cloud infrastructure — faced skepticism
column12: technological hurdles and a lack of clear market fit. Data from the early 2010s reflects a burgeoning interest in blockchain but also reveals the struggles for finding practical applications and widespread adoption. It was during this period that the cryptocurrency space became the primary use case for blockchain technology. Bitcoin’s rise sparked curiosity and fueled on-chain experimentation. But while the promise of decentralized
column13: trustless systems captivated innovators
column14: its practical implementation faced numerous obstacles. Scalability issues
column15: regulatory uncertainties and the association of blockchain with volatile cryptocurrency markets hindered its broader adoption. Blockchain technology was truly in its infancy in the early 2010s. And as with every groundbreaking innovation
column16: overcoming the initial challenges required time
column17: perseverance and a commitment to refining the technology’s capabilities. Within two to three years
column18: blockchain technology expanded from testing labs and hackathons to real world business applications used by global giants like IBM and Maersk. In making the leap relatively quickly
column19: the tech entered a phase akin to the dot-com era’s consolidation — where performance
column20: utility and UX took out the first wave of providers failing to meet enterprise
column21: developer and user expectations. During this period
column22: blockchain gained crucial market recognition and investment growth
column23: and its solutions began to demonstrate real-world utility. The industry also witnessed the emergence of alternative blockchain platforms like Ethereum
column24: each offering unique features and addressing the limitations of earlier iterations. The mid-2010s also marked a turning point for blockchain
column25: with a surge in enterprise adoption and a notable influx of tech industry attention anchored largely by progressive larger companies and startups. Although regulatory frameworks began to take shape around the world
column26: country-specific dynamics remained in the path of providing a more stable environment for businesses to explore and implement blockchain technology. In both the dot-com era internet and blockchain during this phase
column27: viable business models emerged — and along with them
column28: substantial investments that lay the foundation for long-term sustainability. Like dot-com
column29: blockchain was experiencing cracks at the seams as the underlying infrastructure and technology transitioned swiftly from a speculative concept to a legitimate technological innovation vulnerable to system failures
column30: user sentiment and industry scrutiny. In other words
column31: the enterprise
column32: commercial and potential user spotlight was on
column33: but the backend infrastructure remained painfully slow and the frontend UX remained noticeably lacking. Blockchain’s current phase mirrors the cloud computing industry’s evolution from nascent testing group populated with startups and risk-taking enterprises into a market staple with room to improve. While there’s still significant progress to make in terms of adoption and onboarding
column34: processing
column35: security
column36: interoperability and UX
column37: the advancements happening on blockchain today are nearing web grade and web scale. Today
column38: blockchain technology underpins applications across industries
column39: from finance to supply chain management — and this is only the beginning. Recent market analyses highlight blockchain’s expanding footprint
column40: indicating its transition from an emerging technology to an integral part of the global digital infrastructure akin to cloud in Web2. In my opinion
column41: we’re months and years
column42: not decades
column43: away from people around the world using Web3 to make financial transactions
column44: scroll social media and play games at Web2 speeds — with UX at a level where users might not realize their digital experience is made possible by blockchain. Blockchain’s growth is already reshaping traditional business processes and models. In the financial sector
column45: blockchain facilitates faster and more secure transactions. Supply chain management benefits from increased transparency and traceability
column46: ensuring the authenticity and integrity of products. Smart contracts automate and streamline complex agreements
column47: minimizing the risk of fraud and error. And in addition to sparking rising trading volumes
column48: the SEC’s approval of spot bitcoin ETFs sent a global signal of validation to governments reviewing the viability of blockchain applications in both the private and public sectors. Importantly
column49: the evolution of blockchain has given credence to — and bestowed practicality upon — the concept of decentralized finance (DeFi). We’re already in a reality where traditional financial services are replicated
column50: and even improved
column51: using blockchain technology. This is transformative because it will eliminate the need for intermediaries
column52: opening the door to financial participation for virtually anyone with internet access. This democratization of finance has the potential to provide financial services to underserved populations and redefine the global financial landscape. Today (literally today)
column53: blockchain technology sits at the brink of a new era of the internet — one fueled by decentralized ecosystems at web scale. As we move forward
column54: businesses
column55: policymakers and builders will increasingly search out responsible
column56: interoperable and secure blockchains that have a proven ability to scale and meet the needs of millions worldwide who will be using it daily. Most importantly
column57: we can build a more transparent
column58: efficient and inclusive digital world in the process. Mo Shaikh is the Co-Founder & CEO of Aptos Labs. column9: Runes catalyzed an investor frenzy following its launch on April 19

column11: with miners collecting over $135 million in the first week alone. The Runes protocol quickly dominated Bitcoin transactions
column12: reaching a peak transaction share of 81.3% on April 23. However

column14: with significant declines noted particularly on May 10. The analytics from Dune

column20: Runes extends this innovation by facilitating the creation of fungible tokens. This development promised enhanced tokenization capabilities over the existing BRC-20 standard

column22: Runes displayed a brief recovery in early May
column23: with transaction shares rebounding above 60% on May 4 and 5. However
column24: this was not sufficient to sustain the earlier levels of engagement
column25: and overall miner revenue on the Bitcoin network fell to below $30 million per day in May. The Runes protocol
column26: despite its early success and the creation of several high-value Rune collections as reported by Magic Eden
column27: faces the challenge of maintaining traction in a volatile market. Further innovation remains on the horizon

column12: bitcoin has climbed from just over US$7
column13: 000 to the low US$10
column14: 000s. Few asset classes can boast a rise of about 40% in six weeks
column15: though bitcoin enthusiasts like to point out that bitcoin is the best performing asset of the past decade – however choppy the journey along the way. Having said that
column16: bitcoin is certainly not where you would have made most money if you had bought cryptocurrencies at the start of January. There have been even greater price gains from leading altcoins such as ethereum (+119%)
column17: ripple (+58%)
column18: bitcoin cash (+109%) and bitcoin SV (+222%). So what explains their superior performance? These four altcoins are the largest cryptocurrencies on the market after bitcoin
column19: representing an aggregate US$51 billion market capitalisation (the value of each coin multiplied by the number of coins on the market). This is still fairly small compared with bitcoin’s US$178 billion market cap
column20: but clearly the gap has been narrowing. Cryptocurrency aficionados compare bitcoin and the altcoins in terms of bitcoin dominance. This refers to bitcoin’s market size compared with the rest of the altcoins put together. During the early weeks of 2020
column21: it fell slightly from 68% to 64%. As the chart below shows
column22: this is a shift from what has happened for most of the past couple of years. Bitcoin dominance For years
column23: there has tended to be a statistically significant correlation between the performance of bitcoin and the altcoins: when bitcoin rises or falls in price
column24: most altcoins tend to do likewise. You can track this using online tools
column25: such as Coinpredictor.io. Despite this correlation
column26: altcoins have tended to underperform bitcoin ever since the previous bull market petered out in winter 2017-18. Bitcoin dominance was only 39% at the beginning of 2018
column27: whereas it had risen to 70% by July 2019 and stayed around that range for most of the rest of the year. This suggests that bitcoin has acted as a safe harbour for many investors still smarting from the bubble and pop of 2017
column28: which was fuelled by an explosion of initial coin offerings or ICOs from new currencies entering the market. Those who didn’t get out of cryptocurrencies altogether probably felt the need to consolidate around an asset they trusted. Bitcoin was the obvious choice as the longest established and most widely traded asset in this class
column29: and also the gateway cryptocurrency for many investors – their first dip of a toe in the water en route to an altcoin purchase. Other writers have pointed out that during 2019
column30: the price correlation between bitcoin and the altcoins declined. As many other cryptocurrency projects failed to live up to the heady expectations of a year or two before
column31: investors perhaps traded them for bitcoin in a “flight to quality” – a little like traditional investors switching to the likes of gold when the stock market dives. The tilt back towards altcoins in the first weeks of 2020 may be the start of another bull-run
column32: driven by a renewed confidence or understanding in the space. Recent favourable commercial developments have bolstered prices
column33: such as JP Morgan’s positive progress with the interbank payments system that it runs on the ethereum network. The rise of the altcoins is also possibly being fuelled in part by an increasing number of coins entering the market. According to coinmarketcap
column34: it now staggeringly numbers over 5
column35: 000. All other things being equal
column36: this should reduce bitcoin dominance – this may be feeding through now that confidence has risen in the sector as a whole. There has also been a sector-wide boost from Coinbase
column37: the largest cryptoasset exchange in the US. Coinbase is making a play for institutional investors by expanding its ability to store digital coins on their behalf outside the US. Known in the jargon as custodial solutions
column38: Coinbase’s offering has just received two major industry kitemarks from leading accounting firm Grant Thornton
column39: so may be attracting more institutional money into the sector. Another factor may be eagerly awaited initiatives from leading players such as the ethereum 2.0 launch
column40: which looks set for July 2020. This major upgrade to the second-largest crypto network
column41: which underpins many cryptocurrencies and enterprises in this space
column42: is expected to make a big difference to transaction speeds among other things. One big question is whether bitcoin will start outperforming the altcoins again thanks to the so-called “halvening”
column43: which is expected in May. This is the moment roughly every four years when the reward to bitcoin miners is halved
column44: thereby reducing the number of new bitcoins available to sell on the market. Writers such as Jemima Kelly in the Financial Times make a strong case that this won’t raise the bitcoin price because the number of coins in circulation will still be rising and the event is built into the system so should be accounted for in the price already. Yet in a young market
column45: which is comparatively thinly traded and has no uniform global regulation
column46: the positive sentiment around this event may have more effect on the price than the fundamentals. We have previously argued in The Conversation that the chances of bitcoin replacing the global financial system have probably ended
column47: now that many countries and multinationals
column48: such as Facebook
column49: are planning to launch cryptocurrencies of their own. All the same
column50: the latest bull market is more evidence that bitcoin is likely to persist on the peripheries
column51: probably along with the cream of the altcoins. Whether those altcoins can continue to outperform their bitcoin matriarch is a difficult question to answer
column52: but they are showing encouraging signs of life. Naysayers who have predicted their steady demise may have spoken too soon.::2020-02-19T15:56:49Z::Bitcoin

column1: 66::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchain-ai-misleading-narrative::Blockworks::article::What can blockchain do for AI? Not what you’ve heard.::Opinion: AI and blockchain put together aren’t actually that good at combating misinformation and improving privacy just yet.::In reality
column2: many of the oft-touted uses for bringing blockchain and AI together aren’t actually all that useful Stokkete/Modified by Blockworks Industries everywhere are asking “What can AI do for us?” But the blockchain industry
column3: known for challenging norms
column4: is also asking the opposite question: “What can blockchain do for AI?” While there are some compelling answers
column5: three narratives have emerged around this question that are frequently misleading and
column6: in one case
column7: potentially even hazardous. An expert panel at a recent Coinbase event concluded that “blockchain can counter misinformation with cryptographic digital signatures and timestamps
column8: making it clear what’s authentic and what’s been manipulated.” This is true only in a very narrow sense. Blockchains can record digital-media creation in a tamper-proof way
column9: i.e.
column10: so that modification of specific images is detectible. But this is a far cry from clarifying authenticity. Consider a photo of a flying saucer hovering above the Washington Monument. Suppose that someone has registered its creation in
column11: say
column12: block 20
column14: 000 of the Ethereum blockchain. This fact tells you one thing: The flying saucer image was created before block 20
column16: 000. Additionally
column17: whoever posted the image to the blockchain — let’s call her Alice — did so by digitally signing a transaction. Assuming that Alice’s signing key wasn’t stolen
column18: it’s clear that Alice registered the photo on the blockchain. None of this
column19: however
column20: tells you how the image was created. It might be a photo that Alice snapped with her own camera. Or Alice might have gotten the image from Bob
column21: who Photoshopped it. Or maybe Carol created it with a generative AI tool. In short
column22: the blockchain tells you nothing about whether aliens were touring Washington
column23: D.C.—unless you already trust Alice to begin with. Some cameras can digitally sign photos to authenticate them (assuming their sensors can’t be fooled
column24: which is a big if)
column25: but this isn’t blockchain technology. Model training is a data-hungry operation. The bigger and better the training data set
column26: the better the resulting model. For many applications
column27: training on private user data is essential. For instance
column28: creating a good machine-learning model to diagnose medical conditions requires data from a population of real patients. Handling such highly sensitive data securely is a challenge. Some are trumpeting blockchain technologies as a solution. Blockchains
column29: however
column30: are designed for transparency — a property at odds with confidentiality. Proponents point to privacy-enhancing technologies advanced by the blockchain industry to address this tension — especially zero-knowledge proofs. Zero-knowledge proofs
column31: however
column32: don’t solve the problem of privacy in AI model training. That’s because a zero-knowledge proof doesn’t conceal secrets from whoever is constructing the proof. Zero-knowledge proofs are helpful if I want to conceal my transaction data from you. But they don’t enable me to compute privately over your data. There are other
column33: more relevant cryptographic and security tools with esoteric names
column34: including fully homomorphic encryption (FHE)
column35: secure multiparty computation (MPC) and secure enclaves. These can in principle support privacy-preserving AI (specifically
column36: “federated learning”). Each has important caveats
column37: though. And claiming them as blockchain-specific technologies would be a stretch. Jeremy Allaire
column38: CEO of Circle
column39: has noted that bots are already performing transactions using cryptocurrency and tweeted that “AI and Blockchains are made for each other.” This is true in the sense that cryptocurrency is a good match for the capabilities of AI agents. But it’s also worrisome. Many people fret about AI agents escaping human control. Classic nightmare scenarios involve autonomous vehicles killing people or AI-powered autonomous weapons going rogue. But there’s another vector of escape: The financial system. Money equals power. Give that power to an AI agent and it can do real damage. This problem is the topic of a research paper that I co-authored in 2015/6. My colleagues and I examined the possibility of smart contracts
column40: programs that autonomously intermediate transactions on Ethereum
column41: being used to facilitate crime. Using the techniques in that paper and a blockchain oracle system with access to LLMs (Large Language Models) such as ChatGPT
column42: bad actors could in principle launch “rogue” smart contracts that automatically pay bounties for committing serious crimes. Read more from our opinion section: How a smart contract gets away with murder: A review of ‘The Oracle’ Happily
column43: rogue smart contracts of this kind aren’t yet possible in today’s blockchains — but the blockchain industry and crypto enthusiasts will need to take AI safety seriously as a future concern. They will need to consider mitigations
column44: such as community-driven interventions or guardrails in oracles to help enforce AI safety. The integration of blockchains and AI does hold clear promise. AI may add unprecedented flexibility to blockchain systems by creating natural language interfaces to them. Blockchains may provide new financial and transparency frameworks for model training and data sourcing and put the power of AI in the hands of communities
column45: not just enterprises. It’s still early days
column47: and as we wax lyrical about AI and blockchain as an enticing mix of buzzwords and technologies
column48: we need to really think — and see — things through. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana
column49: in your inbox
column50: every day. Subscribe to daily Solana news from Jack Kubinec and Jeff Albus. Newsletter Blockworks Daily  Upcoming Events Permissionless III WED - FRI
column51: OCTOBER 9 - 11
