column6: please proceed to our verification methodology page Vitalik Buterin has played a major role in the crypto space as the co-founder of Ethereum. Buterin’s vision and technical expertise have not only brought success to the Ethereum network but also helped to shape the entire blockchain landscape. Read on to learn about Buterin and his contributions and visions for the future of Ethereum. Vitalik Buterin is the co-founder of the Ethereum network
column7: a decentralized blockchain and development platform. Born in Kolomma
column8: Russia
column9: on Jan. 31
column11: Vitalik’s family left for Canada to seek better employment opportunities. At the time they left
column12: he was six years old. Vitalik Buterin’s skills saw him enrolled in a gifted program in the third grade at a Canadian primary school. He had distinct programming skills and an early interest in economics. Buterin demonstrated remarkable mathematical prowess. Despite his academic talents
column13: he was distant from social events and extracurricular activities
column14: earning him the reputation of a math prodigy. Outside academics
column15: Buterin enjoyed playing World of Warcraft from 2007 to 2010. However
column16: his experience with the game was altered when the game’s developer
column17: Blizzard
column18: nerfed his highly prized favorite character. That was when he realized flaws in centralized systems
column19: prompting him to quit. Following high school
column20: Buterin enrolled at the University of Waterloo
column21: pursuing advanced courses and serving as a research assistant for Ian Goldberg
column22: a known cryptographer. Goldberg
column23: known for co-creating Off-the-Record Messaging and his involvement with the Tor Project
column24: mentored Buterin during this time. In 2012
column25: Buterin achieved further recognition by winning the bronze medal at the International Olympiad in Informatics held in Italy. Vitalik’s net worth primarily stems from his cryptocurrency holdings
column26: which reportedly exceed $866 million at the current market value. Notably
column27: most of his wealth is attributed to his ETH holdings. Buterin holds a substantial amount of ETH
column28: totaling 278
column29: 426 ETH and 248 WETH ($919K). This makes him one of the largest holders of ETH
column30: constituting approximately 0.23% of all ETH in circulation. However
column31: determining Buterin’s exact net worth is challenging due to undisclosed non-crypto assets and potential undisclosed crypto holdings. Vitalik Buterin has achieved a lot throughout his career. In 2014
column32: Buterin was awarded the Thiel Fellowship
column33: a prestigious grant that allowed him to focus on developing Ethereum. The following year
column34: Buterin’s groundbreaking work on Ethereum earned him the World Technology Award in the IT Software category. This award celebrated his contributions to technology and innovation
column35: solidifying his reputation as a visionary within the industry. In addition
column36: Buterin was included in Fortune magazine’s esteemed “40 under 40” list in 2016
column37: acknowledging his leadership and impact as a young innovator. In June 2017
column38: Vitalik Buterin met with Russian President Vladimir Putin during the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum. The meeting was aimed at discussing the economic significance of Ethereum for Russia. In 2018
column39: Buterin received further recognition for his achievements. Forbes featured him in its “30 under 30” list
column40: highlighting his exceptional accomplishments and potential across various industries. He was also honored with an honorary doctorate from the University of Basel for his contributions to blockchain and Ethereum. Buterin’s influence in the cryptocurrency and blockchain sector was further underscored by his inclusion in Fortune’s “The Ledger 40 under 40” list. His impact also went beyond industry boundaries
column41: as evidenced by his inclusion in Time magazine’s prestigious Time 100 list in 2021
column42: which honored him for his contributions to technology and cryptocurrencies on a global scale. In 2018
column43: the Ethereum community celebrated Buterin’s dedication and contributions with the Vitalik Buterin Community Award. This acknowledgment recognized his unparalleled commitment to advancing the Ethereum ecosystem and fostering its growth and development. Vitalik Buterin’s philanthropic efforts have been quite transparent. In October
column44: Buterin clarified on his social platforms that when articles suggest that he is selling ETH
column45: the transactions are made by charities
column47: or other projects to cover fees associated with his donations. He added that he has not sold any ETH for personal gains since 2018. In 2021
column48: Buterin donated over $1 billion in crypto to various charities
column49: including the India Covid Relief fund. The funds came from selling dog-themed meme coins he was gifted by the creators of Akita Inu (AKITA)
column50: Shiba Inu (SHIB) and Dogelon (ELON). Buterin established Kanro
column51: his charitable entity
column52: to combat pandemics
column53: focusing on addressing the challenges posed by COVID-19. Currently
column54: Kanro’s publicly known address holds approximately 75 million USDC stablecoins. Vitalik Buterin donated USD 1.5 billion in cryptocurrency According to Jutel this was a demonstrative gesture of the legitimacy game that encompasses crypto-speculators
column55: blockchain humanitarians and technology solution developers. https://t.co/btR0rodtgj pic.twitter.com/bktHOqJf5u In addition to Kanro
column56: Buterin has made donations
column57: primarily in ether. Some recipients were 13
column58: 292 ETH to GiveWell
column59: a charity evaluator
column61: 000 ETH
column62: and 430 billion ELON tokens to the Methuselah Foundation
column63: which is focused on extending the human lifespan. He also donated 1050 ETH to the Machine Intelligence Research Institute
column64: which aims at safe AI technologies. Vitalik Buterin is primarily known as the co-founder of Ethereum
column65: the second-largest crypto by market cap. Since launching Ethereum
column66: Vitalik has remained a central figure in its development. He is the platform’s public face
column67: contributes to its technical direction
column68: and advocates for its adoption. Buterin also has a background in computer science. His programming skills were instrumental in building Ethereum
column69: and he continues to be a thought leader and advisor in blockchain technology. Apart from that
column70: as outlined above
column71: Vitalik has been involved in charitable contributions
column72: particularly medical research and global health initiatives. Vitalik Buterin is important for co-founding Ethereum. Ethereum introduced smart contracts
column73: which are self-executing agreements that have opened doors to various applications beyond just crypto. Beyond Ethereum
column74: Buterin is a prominent figure in blockchain and crypto. His technical knowledge and vision for the future of the technology are widely respected. At 30
column75: Buterin has become a significant figure in the crypto industry
column76: often compared to Satoshi Nakamoto in significance. His contributions have solidified his position as a key player in shaping the future of the crypto space. In 2011
column77: seeking a new direction
column78: Buterin stumbled upon Bitcoin. Initially skeptical due to its lack of physical backing
column79: he gradually became intrigued as he looked deeper into its workings and potential. Desiring to participate actively in this sector
column80: Buterin looked to acquire Bitcoin but lacked the resources to mine or purchase them outright. Instead
column81: he turned to online forums
column82: where he began writing articles for a blog
column83: earning approximately 5 BTC per piece. ➫ Vitalik Buterin created $ETH at 19
column84: and now his net worth is over $1.2B
column85: making him the youngest crypto billionaire according to Forbes He is one of the most influential people in crypto
column86: so knowing his views can help predict the future I've watched ~100 hours of his… pic.twitter.com/cPDw6W8JwE Buterin explored crypto’s economic
column87: technological
column88: and political dimensions. His writings caught the attention of Mihai Alisie
column89: a fellow Bitcoin enthusiast based in Romania. This led to the creation of the Bitcoin Magazine
column90: which Buterin co-founded in late 2011. Juggling writing
column91: travel
column92: and crypto work for over 30 hours weekly
column93: Buterin decided to leave university. Buterin traveled the world researching various altcoins. He deduced that existing projects were too narrowly focused and lacked versatility. Buterin believed that a successful blockchain should have more applications and more adaptability. He recognized the potential for generalizing the protocols already in place and used Turing-complete programming languages to develop the idea of Ethereum. Despite initial rejections from existing projects
column94: he created the network and wrote the Ethereum whitepaper. In early 2014
column95: Buterin collaborated with a group of visionaries
column96: including Gavin Wood
column97: Anthony Di Iorio
column98: Charles Hoskinson
column99: and Joseph Lubin
column100: to establish Ethereum. Together
column101: they initiated an initial coin offering (ICO) campaign to finance the platform’s development
column102: offering ETH coins in exchange for contributions. The campaign exceeded expectations
column103: raising over $18 million in Bitcoin. With the funding
column104: Ethereum began developing the platform
column105: focusing on enabling smart contracts and decentralized applications. Ethereum introduced Solidity
column106: a new programming language for writing smart contracts. In July 2015
column109: the ETH ecosystem has undergone multiple upgrades
column114: enhancing its capabilities and scalability. Vitalik Buterin has encountered several technical challenges throughout Ethereum’s development. Ethereum is a complex
column116: and scalable platform that has had technical challenges. Some of these that Buterin has addressed are ensuring smart contract security
column117: achieving scalability in handling high transaction volumes
column118: and balancing decentralization with efficiency. Since everything on a public blockchain is transparent
column119: user privacy has also been a major point of discussion. Balancing the need for transparency with the desire for anonymity has been an ongoing effort. The Ethereum blockchain developed use cases such as decentralized applications (DApps) and decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs). However
column120: it faced a significant setback with the launch of the DAO in April 2016. Intended to revolutionize crowdfunding
column121: the DAO quickly raised around $150 million in ETH. However
column122: vulnerabilities in its codebase led to an exploit
column123: resulting in the theft of 3.6 million ETH
column124: roughly $50 million at the time. In response
column125: Vitalik Buterin decided to fork the Ethereum network to stop the hack and restore the stolen funds. The inability to reconcile these differences led to the Ethereum blockchain splitting into two separate chains: Ethereum (ETH) and Ethereum Classic (ETC). Ethereum moved forward with the fork to recover the stolen funds
column126: while Ethereum Classic remained on the original blockchain. ETH became more popular over time and attracted the support of the Enterprise Ethereum Alliance
column128: including JP Morgan and Citigroup. Vitalik Buterin recognized that Ethereum’s proof-of-work (PoW) version led to soaring Ethereum gas fees
column129: making transactions too expensive for many users. This delay prompted Buterin to acknowledge that Ethereum’s transition to a proof-of-stake (PoS) consensus mechanism would take six years instead of the projected one. To address the need for improved transaction throughput and congestion management
column130: Ethereum adopted sharding as part of the Ethereum 2.0 upgrade (Merge). Sharding divides the network into shard chains
column131: distributing the load and aiming to boost transaction throughput and relieve congestion. The Merge integrated Ethereum’s original mainnet with its new proof-of-stake Beacon Chain. This transition eliminated energy-intensive mining and enabled the network to be secured through staked ETH. However
column132: Buterin and his team’s adoption of a more centralized approach has departed from the decentralized strategy previously favored by Ethereum community members. In addition
column134: viewing ETH as an investment asset rather than a decentralized currency. Did you know? The name Ethereum was inspired by a medieval theory about an invisible
column135: all-pervasive substance called “ether.” In a student testimonial at Abelard School
column136: Vitalik Buterin reiterated his experience working on Ethereum and in the crypto industry in general: “I am truly grateful to have the opportunity to work in such an interesting and interdisciplinary area of industry
column137: where I have the chance to interact with cryptographers
column139: and economists prominent in their fields to help build software and tools that already affect tens of thousands of people around the world and to work on advanced problems in computer science
column141: and philosophy every week.” Buterin’s involvement in blockchain projects beyond Ethereum
column143: signals his interest in contributing to the emerging metaverse. In a July 2022 post on X
column146: suggesting corporate attempts to create the metaverse might fail. Buterin believes it’s too early to define the metaverse and that any current attempts may misfire. Given Ethereum’s role as the foundation for various developments such as DeFi
column149: it’s unsurprising that Buterin expects the network to lead in the metaverse space. The "metaverse" is going to happen but I don't think any of the existing corporate attempts to intentionally create the metaverse are going anywhere. https://t.co/tVUfq4CWmP Buterin also sees the Ethereum Name Service (ENS) ecosystem as providing web3 usernames for crypto addresses and decentralized websites and enabling cross-platform identities for users and items. He believes ENS offers solutions that many people overlook. Buterin is fascinated by Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge (zk-SNARKs)
column150: a cryptographic proof allowing a party to prove possession of specific information without revealing it. This eliminates the need for interaction between the prover and verifier. Buterin predicts zk-SNARKs will become the most widely used privacy-preserving technology in the next three decades. He calls it a potential revolution as it becomes mainstream in the next 10-20 years. Buterin has outlined future plans for Ethereum
column151: such as implementing sharding for scalability (the Surge)
column152: introducing Verkle trees for efficiency (the Verge)
column154: and enhancing quantum resistance (the Splurge). Ethereum operates as a decentralized blockchain platform built by developers worldwide. No single entity controls it. While the Ethereum Foundation was important in creating the initial infrastructure and continues to support development
column155: control over the network has shifted to the larger Ethereum community. Ethereum’s decentralized governance model ensures that no single entity or individual can unilaterally change the platform
column156: including the Ethereum Foundation or Vitalik Buterin. Instead
column157: decisions are made collectively by the community
column160: and ETH holders. The network’s success relies on the participation of the community members. They perform activities such as staking and securing the network through node operations and ETH holdings. With hundreds of thousands of developers contributing to the platform’s ongoing development
column161: Ethereum remains a decentralized and collaborative ecosystem. Ethereum Improvement Proposals
column163: allow the community to propose improvements to the network. Any crypto community member can submit EIPs via GitHub. Once proposed
column164: they undergo discussion and review by the Ethereum community
column167: forum members and Ethereum enthusiasts engage in discussions
column168: providing feedback to the proposal’s author. EIPs can cover various aspects of the Ethereum network. An example of is changes to the ERC-20 technical standard
column169: which governs Ethereum transactions. Vitalik Buterin has played a significant role in Ethereum’s development and evolution. As co-founder and leader
column170: he has spearheaded updates such as Ethereum 2.0
column171: which transitioned the network to proof-of-stake and propelled Ethereum to the forefront of the blockchain revolution. Beyond Ethereum contributions
column172: Buterin’s commitment to innovation has been a driver in transforming the blockchain space.  Vitalik Buterin’s inspiration for Ethereum started when the developer changed his character in World of Warcraft
column173: highlighting the downsides of centralized control. In addition
column174: while impressed with Bitcoin and other projects in the crypto industry
column175: he envisioned a platform that would be adaptable and have more applications.Hence
column176: Ethereum was created as a blockchain that facilitates the creation of decentralized applications (DApps) using smart contracts
column177: among other use cases. Vitalik Buterin introduced Ethereum
column178: which opened doors for decentralized finance (DeFi)
column180: and other applications beyond digital currencies. Vitalik’s ongoing research
column182: and public speaking have also shaped the conversation around blockchain technology. Vitalik Buterin’s awards include recognition for his technical contributions (Thiel Fellowship
column184: leadership in the tech industry (Fortune 40 under 40
column186: and influence within the blockchain space (Honorary Doctorate
column188: Vitalik Buterin Community Award). Time Magazine even recognized him for his global impact on technology and cryptocurrency. Vitalik remains a prominent figure in Ethereum’s development. He is key in shaping its roadmap and proposing solutions for technical challenges like scalability and privacy. His ideas and research papers on scalability solutions (sharding) and Proof-of-Stake consensus mechanisms influence conversations around the blockchain space. Vitalik Buterin’s future vision for Ethereum includes implementing sharding for scalability (the Surge)
column189: introducing Verkle trees for efficiency (the Verge)
column191: and enhancing quantum resistance (the Splurge). Vitalik Buterin is most famous for co-founding Ethereum
column192: a leading blockchain platform that introduced smart contracts. He is also recognized for his philanthropy and advocacy for decentralization in the blockchain space. In May 2024

column1: 130::https://blockworks.co/news/crypto-blockchain-not-synonymous::Blockworks::article::Crypto and blockchain are not synonymous::Opinion: In other words
column2: one should not judge the merits of an entire technology based on how much BONK they lost.::In other words
column3: one should not judge the merits of an entire technology based on how much BONK they lost Artwork by Crystal Le Crypto — like any speculative asset — experienced its fair share of volatility this year. After plummeting to lows of $16
column4: 000 following the collapse of FTX in November 2022
column5: bitcoin surpassed $43
column6: 000 in December 2023 as part of a rally that some say is just beginning. But my hope is that crypto’s persistent reputation for volatility doesn’t tarnish the perceived value of blockchain’s underlying technology. As we go into 2024
column7: I’m optimistic that the inherent capabilities of distributed ledger technology will extend beyond mere market action. Assessing blockchain’s worth solely through the lens of profit performance overlooks the broader utility and transformative potential of Web3. In other words
column8: one should not judge the merits of an entire technology based on how much BONK they lost. In September
column9: blockchain data company Chainalysis released its 2023 Global Adoption Index. The purpose of this report was to recognize “leaders of grassroots crypto adoption
column10: ” and to identify the countries where average
column11: everyday people are putting the greatest share of their wealth into cryptocurrency. The results were promising. Of the 20 countries listed
column12: many belong to emerging market economies transitioning from lower incomes and rates of development toward rapid expansion of trade and investment flows. Personally
column13: I’d like to believe that the growing adoption of digital currencies reinforces the technology that underlies it. What’s all the hype about? You lean into it. You go from having a MetaMask wallet and visiting a Bitcoin ATM to reading a few articles and understanding the properties of blockchain that afford secure
column14: public transactions of data and information. You learn about Satoshi’s motivations behind digital assets not as a way to make the rich richer
column15: but to disrupt power-hungry institutions standing in the way of autonomy and democratic financial access. Yes
column16: blockchain is typically associated with its range of financial use cases. But the decentralized
column17: permissionless and non-sovereign technology has
column18: at its core
column19: a social and reformist potential. My hypothesis is that greater grassroots adoption and understanding of crypto assets generates room for uses that capitalize on blockchain to effect change beyond the strictly financial realm. In looking beyond bitcoin rallies and new exchange offerings
column20: other dynamic applications of blockchain come to life. Chainalysis’ 2023 index signals the presence of audiences keen to engage and capture the broader social value that blockchain offers — highlighting Web3 projects that are exceeding blockchain’s financial boundaries to drive cultural and socioeconomic transformations around the world. Nigeria: Akowe
column21: meaning “clerk” in Yoruba
column22: is a one-man Lagos-based startup using blockchain to issue and verify academic records. Almost all certificates issued by Nigerian tertiary institutions are physical hard copies. Coupled with high unemployment rates
column23: certificate forgeries have become increasingly commonplace. Employers and HR firms bear the brunt of high verification costs needed to ensure the credibility of academic records
column24: resulting in verification processes taking anywhere between two weeks to six months. Akowe’s mission is to introduce digital certificates to educators and Nigerian learning institutions
column25: using blockchain to facilitate a tamper-proof and easily verifiable system of digital academic records. While Akowe previously operated using permissioned blockchain Hyperledger
column26: Agboola is now exploring Amazon’s new ledger database solution QLDB
column27: which allows organizations to create centrally managed records. The startup has piloted its project with two institutions and is actively engaged in discussions with 15 other universities
column28: indicating a growing interest in the blockchain-based verification solution to reduce complexities within the current education sector. India: Web3 middleware SaaS start-up Airchains is partnering with West Bengal’s New Town Kolkata Development Authority (NKDA) to digitize land ownership using NFTs. The presumption of land ownership in India is complicated by different jurisdictional processes. Conflicting title investigations and lost paperwork creates glaring inconsistencies in the maintenance of land records
column29: impeding the Indian real estate market and often making land the subject of long and tedious litigation. Airchains uses blockchain to develop unique NFTs that serve as land ownership proofs under NKDA’s jurisdiction. This system allows property registration certificates and land records to be digitally recorded and traced
column30: eliminating tedious paperwork and promising to facilitate the lifetime tracking of ownership. Physical copies of NFTs are available in card format
column31: while digital QR code certificates are used to ensure quick access after relevant authentication processes. Digitizing proof of land records in this way is also crucial to counteract ownership often made on the basis of customary claims. Airchains’ agenda is testament to the blockchain revolution to “steadily penetrat[e] and disrupt a plethora of traditional sectors.” Crucially
column32: the project remains uninvolved with crypto transactions
column33: choosing easier
column34: gasless methods to interact with users. Airchains’ user base has soared by 150% in the past two quarters
column35: alluding to a widespread consensus about replacing traditional bureaucracy with a transparent and secure digital system of land ownership. The team plans to introduce 500
column36: 000 NFTs deployed on Polygon Supernets to expand the land mutation process across 27
column37: 000 acres
column38: as reported by Forbes. These examples illustrate why blockchain and crypto cannot be conflated — and why people shouldn’t be quick to point to market volatility as a reason to dismiss both. Once you distinguish a technology from its dominant applications
column39: its uses quickly multiply. Blockchain is a new frontier in the world of finance
column40: sure. But it is irresponsible and inaccurate to correlate an asset’s volatility to its legitimacy
column41: especially as bitcoin’s price now exceeds $40
column42: 000 and promises to continue being influenced by market dynamics
column43: investor sentiments and new regulation. The path to Web3 mass adoption will be long and tedious. But keeping crypto in the spotlight distracts from blockchain’s most disruptive use cases
column44: most of which haven’t even been dreamt up yet. It is the responsibility of advocates to explore how we can co-opt this technology to transform the long-standing institutional idea of “that’s just how things have been done” because we got too complacent to challenge it. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column50: stay for the fresh air. Permissionless III promises unforgettable panels

column1: 133::https://theconversation.com/how-can-criminals-manipulate-cryptocurrency-markets-97294::The Conversation::article::How can criminals manipulate cryptocurrency markets?::Cryptocurrencies like bitcoin are susceptible to fraud and price manipulation
column2: just like any other type of investment.::Cryptocurrencies like bitcoin are based on systems that are supposed to be inherently protected from fraud. Yet the U.S. Department of Justice has opened a criminal investigation into manipulation of bitcoin prices. How is that sort of activity even possible? From researching blockchain and cryptocurrencies for the past three years
column3: I know that blockchain systems have some immutable security features. For instance
column4: if I sent you some amount of bitcoin
column5: and that transaction were recorded in the blockchain ledger
column6: I couldn’t force the system to give that money back. The technology itself prevents the transaction from being reversed. But that is only true if transactions happen within the system. And there are other elements of cryptocurrency technologies that actually make fraud easier. Some of the problems the Justice Department is investigating appear to have arisen because bitcoin enthusiasts are not treating cryptocurrencies as a means of payment like dollars. Rather
column7: they’re behaving as if bitcoins and their ilk are speculative assets like stocks and bonds. So they’re placing orders to buy bitcoin in advance
column8: only later completing the deal. One type of fraud investigators are looking into is called “spoofing
column9: ” in which people place orders but cancel them before the deal is finalized – often without even having to pay a service fee. That makes it look like there’s more demand for bitcoin than there actually is
column10: driving up the value of each bitcoin. That sort of manipulation is possible with almost any type of asset. Bitcoin is more susceptible than stocks or bonds because so few people hold large amounts of bitcoin. The largest 1
column11: 000 bitcoin accounts hold 40 percent of all the bitcoins in existence – with almost 20 percent held in just 100 accounts. Many of the people who own large amounts of bitcoin have been in the cryptocurrency community for a number of years and know each other. They can take coordinated actions to increase or decrease prices – and because there’s no real regulation of cryptocurrency markets
column12: it might not even be illegal for them to do so. There are fewer protections for cryptocurrency trading
column13: in part because it’s so new. For instance
column14: a high volatility in stock prices would trigger “circuit breakers” in the U.S.
column15: halting trading and resetting prices to limit investors’ losses. Cryptocurrency markets have no such built-in mechanisms. Another type of fraud the Justice Department is investigating is called “wash trading
column16: ” in which one person sets up what looks like a legitimate purchase-and-sale deal
column17: but actually does the deal with himself or herself. That makes it look like there is more activity in the market than there actually is
column18: artificially increasing demand and value. Anyone can have as many cryptocurrency accounts as they wish to set up. And many blockchain-based systems keep users’ identities anonymous. The transactions themselves – if they actually happen – are recorded and publicly viewable
column19: but the accounts involved are only identified with bitcoin addresses
column20: which are long alphanumeric codes like “1ExAmpLe0FaBiTco1NADr3sSV5tsGaMF6hd.” That anonymity can make it very hard to prove that wash trading is happening and challenges law enforcement to identify and catch fraudsters. At a June 2017 congressional hearing a former federal prosecutor told of cryptocurrency investigations revealing an account set up by a person claiming to be “Mickey Mouse” living at “123 Main Street.” Some countries are starting to regulate cryptocurrency markets
column21: either under existing regulations or new ones. In 2015
column22: for instance
column23: a federal investigation found that the U.S. cryptocurrency company Ripple Labs had not properly followed anti-money laundering laws and rules about getting accurate customer identification information. In May 2018
column24: 40 jurisdictions including U.S. states
column25: Canadian provinces and national regulators in both countries launched a formal probe dubbed “Operation Cryptosweep
column26: ” to crack down on fraudulent cryptocurrency trading. They opened as many as 70 investigations and warned roughly 35 companies about potentially violating securities laws. The vast majority of cryptocurrency trading
column27: however
column28: happens in countries with few regulations and lax enforcement. For instance
column29: from early 2014 to early 2017
column30: about 90 percent of global bitcoin trading happened through Chinese cryptocurrency exchanges. At least some of those businesses allegedly falsely inflated trading volumes to attract new customers. China has since banned online cryptocurrency trading
column31: but people are finding loopholes. The problems will likely shift to other countries that lack strong rules
column32: which highlights the importance of international cooperation in investigations. Cryptocurrencies are a global phenomenon; the world’s nations – especially those with lots of trading activity – will have to work together to protect consumers.::2018-05-31T10:44:24Z::Cryptocurrency::Nir Kshetri::Home::https://images.theconversation.com/files/221027/original/file-20180530-120514-16z31os.jpg?ixlib=rb-4.1.0&rect=0%2C527%2C5501%2C2750&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop

column1: 134::https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2024/04/05/ethereum-foundation-researchers-proposal-to-slow-eth-issuance-draws-pushback/::CoinDesk::article::Ethereum Foundation Researchers' Proposal to Slow ETH Issuance Draws Pushback::The proposal
column2: introduced in February
column3: could harden Ethereum's native cryptocurrency
column4: ether (ETH)
column5: as a form of money – by reducing the inflation of new supply. But some members of the community say if it's not broke
column6: don't fix it. Reduction in ETH staking yield What is the role of the Ethereum Foundation?::Earlier this year
column7: a pair of Ethereum Foundation (EF) researchers put forth a proposal to reduce the pace of new issuance of ether (ETH) tokens. It was part of a concerted plan to reduce incentives for new stakers – the investors who lock cryptocurrency into the blockchain as a way of helping to secure the network. The freshly minted ETH is a crucial component of the rewards these investors hope to receive
column8: in the form of staking yields. As the researchers' thinking went
column9: there's already enough stakers to provide effective security for the blockchain
column10: and in fact any additional increases in the level of participation could enable the unwanted dominance of fast-growing third-party staking platforms like Lido. A side benefit of the proposed changes would be to harden ether as a form of money
column11: since the total supply of the cryptocurrency wouldn't grow as quickly – effectively tapering ether's inflation rate. Now
column12: though
column13: some members of the community are pushing back
column14: questioning whether there's really a need to change the tokenomics of ether and
column15: in the extreme
column16: whether the Ethereum Foundation plays an outsize role in influencing code upgrades on the decentralized network. The proposal was initially introduced in February by Ansgar Dietrichs and Caspar Schwarz-Schilling
column17: both researchers at the EF. It suggests setting the blockchain's parameters so that the annual issuance of new ETH would not exceed 0.4% – a step change lower than the current effective limit of 1.5%. The big idea is that top Ethereum researchers are satisfied with the number of stakers already working to secure the network
column18: so it might make sense to reduce the incentives for newcomers. The change would also avoid extra dilution for ETH investors. The current issuance rate "dilutes ETH holders beyond what is necessary for security
column19: the researchers wrote. They estimated that the proposal would reduce ETH staking yields by nearly a third. Some members of the Ethereum community argue that the proposal is being rushed ahead without enough time for outside feedback. Viktor Bunin, a protocol specialist at Coinbase Cloud, wrote on the social-media platform X, “If it's not broke don't fix it.” ETH staking is the main way the Ethereum network stays secure: Ethereum's proof-of-stake" consensus model lets users deposit ("stake") ETH with the network in exchange for yield
column20: and to help run the chain. The substance of Dietrichs and Schwarz-Schilling's concern is that too many ETH tokens are getting staked with the network via third-party liquid staking services like Lido – crypto protocols that stake on behalf of users
column21: and then issue derivative assets called "liquid staking tokens" (LSTs) representing their users' underlying deposits. The EF researchers say they're concerned that LSTs like Lido's stETH token – the most-traded asset on Ethereum other than the ETH token itself – could eventually replace the blockchain’s native currency as the network's de facto money
column22: making the entire system less secure. Ethereum's security model needs ETH to be valuable in order to work
column23: and a chief concern driving the new proposal is that if the cryptocurrency were to fall behind LSTs
column24: it could go down in price relative to other assets. Mike Neuder
column25: another researcher at the EF
column26: expanded on the initial proposal by explaining that
column27: as “real yield from staking goes to zero
column28: stakers will need to rely on exogenous rewards for profitability.” Reducing the ETH issuance rate could enhance Ethereum's economic model by making ETH scarcer
column29: potentially increasing its value. Some community members
column30: however
column31: are pushing back on the argument that changing the tokenomics of the blockchain will improve Ethereum’s economic model. Jon Charbonneau
column32: co-founder at crypto investment firm DBA
column33: wrote on X that “these tweaks try to solve an unsolvable problem of fundamental tradeoffs in PoS.” PoS stands for "proof-of-stake
column34: which is the core process or consensus mechanism" used to secure the blockchain. Paul Dylan-Ennis
column35: a lecturer and assistant professor at the University College Dublin School of Business
column36: wrote that “it seems to me it's not really issuance that is at stake
column37: so much as people have a sense that EF-associated devs and researchers appear to have an outsized power.” He added that “they are not engaging in the appropriate level of 'rough consensus' from the wider set of stakeholders.” The skepticism elicted responses from key figures within the Ethereum ecosystem
column38: and at the Ethereum Foundation specifically. Notably
column39: Vitalik Buterin
column40: the influential co-founder of the Ethereum blockchain
column41: is one of three members of the executive board of the Ethereum Foundation
column42: according to its website. The organization is described as a "non-profit that supports the Ethereum ecosystem
column43: and part of a larger community of organizations and individuals that fund protocol development
column44: grow the ecosystem and advocate for Ethereum." Tim Beiko
column45: protocol support lead at the foundation
column47: arguing that “it's pretty empirically untrue that 'core devs' or 'the EF' are uncontested re: governance. this current conversation is a clear example.” "Core devs" is shorthand for the broader
column48: group of developers – drawn from multiple companies and organizations
column49: as well as individuals – who participate in regular discussions over the network's rules
column50: code
column51: upgrades and strategy roadmap. Beiko added that: “I think core devs + researchers generally treat ethresearch+ethmag as a place to post WIP ideas/proposals
column52: whereas the broader community tends to perceive it as a place where the Official Roadmap gets shared after it's ~final.” Dietrichs
column53: the co-author of the initial proposal
column54: responded that the "intention was purely to propose this change for consideration to the community." “Of course any change to such a sensitive part of the protocol requires broad community buy-in
column55: Dietrichs wrote. We tried to be clear about that from the beginning
column56: but could certainly have done a better job.” Read more: Ethereum Finalizes 'Dencun' Upgrade

column114: scammers set up fake escrow services to conduct P2P transactions. column1: 136::https://blockworks.co/news/music-industry-blockchain-bandcamp::Blockworks::article::The music industry could learn a few lessons from blockchain::Opinion: Digital ownership is inevitable
column2: but let’s be realistic about the problems it solves.::Bandcamp’s drama and community response has reminded us that the investments we make into centralized internet products are neither owned by us nor permanent Midjourney modified by Blockworks I spent twenty years building digital music applications and businesses
column3: most recently Beats Music and Apple Music
column4: previously with Yahoo!
column5: Winamp
column6: Topspin and Beastie Boys. Today
column7: I work at Ledger and espouse the utility of crypto instead
column8: so I’m often asked the question
column9: “What about music on the blockchain?” “Meh
column10: ” is my standard response. I don’t see the innovation or consumer need in asking people to buy digital music NFTs like they bought CDs
column11: or trying to shoehorn digital ownership into streaming services meant to compete with Spotify. Listening to music on the internet is a solved problem
column12: and music listeners don’t need the help of a blockchain to hear what they want. Just say
column13: “Hey Siri
column14: play The Beatles
column15: ” to remind yourself just how far we’ve come since Napster. The business of music rights is an oligopoly controlled by three major labels and four digital music services
column16: none of whom have an interest in open standards. But the two-sided marketplace of Bandcamp is a great place to consider the value blockchains can and will add to the artist/fan relationship
column17: and how that change will come slowly over the next fifteen years. Below is a thought exercise using Bandcamp to demonstrate where digital ownership can meaningfully change the paradigm without asking consumers to change their habits all at once. For music fans — and in particular
column18: fans of niche genres such as heavy metal and contemporary jazz — Bandcamp is beloved. The site launched in 2008 and bloomed slowly
column19: building a passionate community of music lovers over fifteen years. The functionality of Bandcamp.com is simple: Stream for free
column20: buy digital for around $10
column21: and often buy vinyl (Bandcamp actually bought a pressing plant to help the creator side of their marketplace press vinyl)
column22: as well as t-shirts or other physical collectibles from the artist. Artists receive a net average of 82% of every sale
column23: and Bandcamp has paid out around $1 billion to artists and labels selling on the site since its launch. But in March 2022
column24: Bandcamp was sold to Epic Games. “Bandcamp will play an important role in Epic’s vision to build out a creator marketplace ecosystem
column25: ” Epic Games wrote in a statement. Bandcamp unionized in March 2023
column26: and when Epic Games announced it was laying off 16% of its total workforce in September
column27: a sale of Bandcamp to Songtradr was announced. Only 50% of the Bandcamp staff was retained and the community voiced its concern for the future of Bandcamp loudly culminating in this Pitchfork article: “Is Bandcamp as we know it over?”. Bandcamp’s drama and community response has reminded us — like MySpace
column28: Flickr and so many other platforms before — that the investments we make into centralized internet products are neither owned by us nor permanent. At the end of the day
column29: these are for-profit companies with investors looking for outcomes. Our investments into the platform are of value for them
column30: not for us. The digital albums purchased
column31: as well as the “relationship” between the artist and consumer
column32: are owned by Bandcamp. If they disappear
column33: so does the artist’s access to their fanbase and the listener’s backup of the music they’ve paid for. With decentralized ownership
column34: this could be fundamentally different. If I were at the helm
column35: here is how I would modify Bandcamp: The ambitions could be set higher than I suggest above — digital packaging and payouts to creative collaborators like Metalabel is building would be very useful in the Bandcamp context. Read more from our opinion section: You aren’t thinking hard enough about digital art You could also imagine artists earning ownership in Bandcamp based on performance and a revenue stream for artists where the profits of the platform are paid out based on this ownership (what Visa was for banks
column36: Bandcamp could be for artists). But I like the simple thought experience described in the bullet points above particularly because the changes are subtle and simple
column37: yet meaningful to both artists and fans
column38: without asking either to change their behavior overnight. But we should keep this in perspective — the entire recorded music industry made $26 billion in revenue in 2022
column39: whereas Bandcamp has paid out just $1 billion to artists since 2008. Also
column40: the examples above speak to how application developers in categories beyond music will integrate digital ownership slowly and optionally for their customers
column41: rather than a Web3 “big bang” overnight. Digital ownership is inevitable
column42: but let’s be realistic about the problems it solves and how quickly this new paradigm is arriving to mainstream consumers. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana
column43: in your inbox

column1: 138::https://cryptobriefing.com/crypto-talent-grants-nibiru/::Crypto Briefing::article::Nibiru COO highlights grants as a magnet for TradFi talent in crypto::Jonathan Chang shares his transition from the traditional market to crypto
column2: and what skills were valuable when pivoting.::Join the hunt for $12
column4: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article The presence of crypto among institutional investors is on the rise
column5: especially after the approval of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in the US. Companies such as JPMorgan
column6: UBS
column7: and Wells Fargo declared Bitcoin ETF holdings in their recent 13F filings. This rise in institutional interest can also be seen in the professional area. Executives with backgrounds in traditional finance (TradFi) are rotating to crypto as the market matures. Former Credit Suisse and JPMorgan Jonathan Chang
column8: is one of these executives
column9: now in the role of COO at layer-1 blockchain Nibiru. He shared insights with Crypto Briefing on valuable TradFi skills that can be used in crypto
column10: how grants are a powerful tool to attract more of the traditional market
column11: and how those professionals can help solve crypto issues. Crypto Briefing – What was your biggest challenge when pivoting from traditional finance to crypto? What set of skills learned from TradFi were most valuable when joining this new market? Jonathan Chang – Crypto is known for its unique complexities. Traditional Finance (TradFi) offers a more relatable framework for understanding decentralized finance due to its familiar concepts. However
column12: there is still a learning curve
column13: particularly with the specialized terminology used in crypto. For instance
column14: while the principles of lending
column15: including borrowers
column16: underwriting
column17: credit assessment
column18: and lenders are well-established in TradFi
column19: the application of these concepts in crypto—built on smart contract platforms and enhanced with tokenomics—introduces a new layer of complexity. In fintech
column20: the ledger is fundamental for recording bank transactions. This concept closely parallels the blockchain ledger used in crypto
column21: which also records transactions but does so in a decentralized way. I’ve noticed that fintech and crypto startups often share similar goals
column22: particularly in speeding up payments and financial services. The main difference lies in the technology stacks each uses to achieve these goals. Now that I’m more involved in crypto
column23: my background in traditional finance is proving beneficial. My experience in equity research enhanced my analytical and writing skills
column24: and deepened my understanding of how markets moved. In investment banking

column1: 139::https://theconversation.com/blockchains-focusing-on-bitcoin-misses-the-real-revolution-in-digital-trust-58125::The Conversation::article::Blockchains: Focusing on bitcoin misses the real revolution in digital trust::The transaction system underlying the bitcoin network has far broader uses than easing financial transfers – including identifying people and tracking property ownership.::In 2008
column2: short of sending a suitcase full of cash
column3: there was essentially just one way for an individual to send money between
column4: say
column5: the United States and Europe. You had to wire the money through a mainstream financial service
column6: like Western Union or a bank. That meant paying high fees and waiting up to several days for the money to arrive. A radically new option arose in 2009 with the introduction of bitcoin. Bitcoin makes it possible to transfer value between two individuals anywhere in the world quickly and at minimal cost. It is often called a “cryptocurrency
column7: ” as it is purely digital and uses cryptography to protect against counterfeiting. The software that executes this cryptography runs simultaneously on computers around the world. Even if one or more of these computers is misused in an attempt to corrupt the bitcoin network (such as to steal money)
column8: the collective action of the others ensures the integrity of the system as a whole. Its distributed nature also enables bitcoin to process transactions without the fees
column9: antiquated networks and (for better or worse) the rules governing intermediaries like banks and wire services. Bitcoin’s exciting history and social impact have fired imaginations. The aggregate market value of all issued bitcoins today is roughly US$10 billion. The computing devices that maintain its blockchain are geographically dispersed and owned by thousands of different individuals
column10: so the bitcoin network has no single owner or point of control. Even its creator remains a mystery (despite many efforts to unmask her
column11: him or them). Bitcoin’s lack of government regulation made it attractive to black markets and malware writers. Although the core system is well-secured
column12: people who own bitcoins have experienced a litany of heists and fraud. Even more than the currency itself
column13: though
column14: what has drawn the world’s attention are the unprecedented reliability and security of bitcoin’s underlying transaction system
column15: called a blockchain. Researchers
column16: entrepreneurs
column17: and developers believe that blockchains will solve a stunning array of problems
column18: such as stabilization of financial systems
column19: identification of stateless persons
column20: establishing title to real estate and media
column21: and efficiently managing supply chains. Despite its richly varied applications
column22: a blockchain such as bitcoin’s aims to realize a simple goal. Abstractly
column23: it can be viewed as creating a kind of public bulletin board
column24: often called a “distributed ledger.” This ledger is public. Anyone – plebeian or plutocrat
column25: baker or banker – can read it. And anyone can write valid data to it. Specifically
column26: in bitcoin
column27: any owner of money can add a transaction to the ledger that transfers some of her money to someone else. The bitcoin network makes sure that the ledger includes only authorized transactions
column28: meaning those digitally signed by the owners of the money being transferred. The key feature of blockchains is that new data may be written at any time
column29: but can never be changed or erased. At first glance
column30: this etched-in-stone rule seems a needless design restriction. But it gives rise to a permanent
column31: ever-growing transactional history that creates strong transparency and accountability. For example
column32: the bitcoin blockchain contains a record of every transaction in the system since its birth. This feature makes it possible to prevent account holders from reneging on transactions
column33: even if their identities remain anonymous. Once in the ledger
column34: a transaction is undeniable. The indelible nature of the ledger is much more powerful and general
column35: though
column36: allowing blockchains to support applications well beyond bitcoin. Consider
column37: for example
column38: the management of title to a piece of land or property. Property registries in many parts of the world today are fragmented
column39: incomplete
column40: poorly maintained
column41: and difficult to access. The legal uncertainty surrounding ownership of property is a major impediment to growth in developing economies. Were property titles authoritatively and publicly recorded on a blockchain
column42: anyone could learn instantly who has title to a piece of property. Even legitimate anonymous ownership – as through a private trust – could be recorded on a blockchain. Such transparency would help resolve legal ambiguity and shed light on malfeasance. Advocates envision similar benefits in blockchain recording of media rights – such as rights to use images or music – identity documents and shipping manifests. In addition
column43: the decentralized nature of the database provides resilience not just to technical failures
column44: but also to political ones – failed states
column45: corruption and graft. Blockchains can be enhanced to support not just transactions
column46: but also pieces of code known as smart contracts. A smart contract is a program that controls assets on the blockchain – anything from cryptocurrency to media rights – in ways that guarantee predictable behavior. A smart contract may be viewed as playing the role of a trusted third party: Whatever task it is programmed to do
column47: it will carry out faithfully. Suppose for example that a user wishes to auction off a piece of land for which her rights are represented on a blockchain. She could hire an auctioneer
column48: or use an online auction site. But that would require her and her potential customers to trust
column49: without proof
column50: that the auctioneer conducts the auction honestly. To achieve greater transparency
column51: the user could instead create a smart contract that executes the auction automatically. She would program the smart contract with the ability to deliver the item to be sold and with rules about minimum bids and bidding deadlines. She would also specify what the smart contract is to do at the end of the auction: send the winning bid amount from the winner to the seller’s account and transfer the land title to the winner. Because the blockchain is publicly visible
column52: anyone with suitable expertise could check that the code in the smart contract implements a fair and valid auction. Auction participants would only need to trust the correctness of the code. They wouldn’t need to rely on an auctioneer to run the auction honestly – and as an added benefit
column53: they also wouldn’t need to pay high auctioneer fees. Behind this compelling vision lurk many technical challenges. The transparency and accountability of a fully public ledger have many benefits
column54: but are at odds with confidentiality. Suppose the seller mentioned above wanted to conduct a sealed-bid auction or conceal the winning bid amount? How could she do this on a blockchain that everyone can read? Achieving both transparency and confidentiality on blockchains is in fact possible
column55: but requires new techniques under development by researchers. Another challenge is ensuring that smart contracts correctly reflect user intent. A lawyer
column56: arbiter or court can remedy defects or address unforeseen circumstances in written contracts. Smart contracts
column57: though
column58: are expressly designed as unalterable code. This inflexibility avoids ambiguity and cheating and ensures trustworthy execution
column59: but it can also cause brittleness. An excellent example was the recent theft of around $55 million in cryptocurrency from a smart contract. The thief exploited a software bug
column60: and the smart contract creators couldn’t fix it once the contract was running. Bitcoin is a proof of concept of the viability of blockchains. As researchers and developers overcome the technical challenges of smart contracts and other blockchain innovations
column61: marveling at money flying across the Atlantic will someday seem quaint.::2016-07-18T10:17:17Z::Bitcoin

Lightning wallets tested and goal Choosing the test location The testing process Payment costs Features and differences Second test in urban area with LTE connection Overall rankings for Lightning self-custody Conclusion::I'm conducting my second test of self-custodial Lightning wallets in Zimbabwe
column5: to see which might be best for any rural area. Given that none of the available self-custodial wallets are developed by Africans
column6: they are rarely used or tested here. On top of that
column7: Lightning is still new and complex
column8: building mobile apps that are running a node of the network on your phone is challenging. I am here to find out what works and what does not. As an educator
column9: I recommend tools for everyday users
column10: who want to send small payments. These tools have to be reliable
column11: otherwise people might conclude that Bitcoin isn't for them. Anita Posch is a world-renowned Bitcoin educator
column12: author of the book "(L)earn Bitcoin" and founder of the online academy Crack the Orange as well as non-profit initiative Bitcoin for Fairness. I opened my first Lightning channel on an app called BLW in January 2019. I’m used to testing new tools
column13: that’s why I have no problem if challenges and bugs arise. But regular users may not be as forgiving
column14: that’s why I aim to only recommend tools I’ve personally tested. In 2023
column15: the only two self-custody Lightning wallets available were Breez and Phoenix. This year I had more choices and tested: Blixt
column16: Mutiny
column17: Green
column18: Zeus and Phoenix. I also included the Wallet of Satoshi
column19: a custodial wallet
column20: just to see how it performs in comparison. I was familiar with Phoenix and used Zeus connected to my Voltage node earlier. Mutiny
column21: Blixt and the Lightning integration in Blockstream’s Green wallet just popped up in the last few months
column22: so using them was new for me too. All of the wallets have been undergoing huge changes and will continue to evolve. I had to download Mutiny manually and install a special .apk file used on Android phones. For the Green wallet
column23: I asked BlockStream to unlock its experimental Greenlight feature in order to test it. My goal was to find out which of the wallets are the best in sending and receiving bitcoin in a reliable
column24: fast
column25: easy to use manner and to compare the costs involved. See also: Coinbase CEO Confirms Exchange Will Support Lightning Before heading to the rural areas (I intended to test the wallets under suboptimal conditions)
column26: I set up the wallets and opened a Lightning payments channel in Harare as I anticipated low internet signal challenges. Based on my year-long experience in Zimbabwe
column27: I’ve learned that even with decent internet speed
column28: the upload and download of files as small as 2 MB can be problematic. I used the internet at a friend’s house to use the fastest internet provider in Harare called Liquid
column29: which is also the most expensive with a monthly cost of $300 for unlimited usage. My speed test results for download were 92.7 Mbps and upload 14.6 Mbps. Even with that fast internet it took me some time to install the apps
column30: secure the private keys and open a Lightning channel to be a part of the network. To ensure consistency
column31: I followed a test protocol for each wallet. On Dec. 26 and 27
column32: I installed the wallets and sent 100
column33: 000 sats (~$42 at current prices) to open a Lightning channel. A channel on the Lightning Network needs two transactions on the Bitcoin blockchain to be set up. That way the channel is constantly connected to the blockchain
column34: which is why the bitcoin on the Bitcoin blockchain and bitcoin on the Lightning network are the same. There is no difference in the value
column35: it’s the same unit
column36: not another token or asset. There are several ways to open a channel: sending on-chain bitcoin
column37: transferring Lightning directly from another wallet or through a swap from Liquid or some wallets are offering buying inbound liquidity. I tried them all to send the first bitcoin to the wallets
column38: affecting set-up speed and fees I had to pay. See also: Bitcoin Could See Growth in Layer-2 Ecosystem
column39: Drawing on Ethereum's Experience I used a Lightning payment to open a channel on all wallets
column40: except for Blixt
column41: as I only found the on-chain option there (except for liquidity providers). Seemingly

column43: because the channel opened immediately after the first transaction confirmation. Not with Blixt: I sent the first transaction and the confirmation took some hours
column44: it was evening already
column45: so I had to leave the friend's house. As soon as it was confirmed
column46: Blixt carried out the second on-chain transaction

column48: with internet speed only around 3 Mbps download
column49: 0.26 upload and a Ping over 300ms. Blixt wasn't able to open the channel in these circumstances. I needed to go back to my friend's house to finish the channel opening. It's hard to say how other wallets would have performed under these conditions. For the channel openings on Green and Zeus
column50: I used Liquid
column51: swapped via Boltz.exchange to Lightning
column52: due to high transaction fees at the time. Opening a channel from Liquid is far more economical in that situation. Liquid is a sidechain of Bitcoin
column53: its unit is called L-BTC. Learn the differences between Bitcoin
column54: Lightning
column55: Liquid
column56: and E-Cash in this non-technical explainer. One BTC is pegged to one L-BTC. This means if you peg-in 0.1 BTC to Liquid
column57: the resulting 0.1 L-BTC are of the same value as BTC. Compared to self-custodial Lightning there is more trust involved in using Liquid
column58: because you have to go through intermediaries for the peg-in and peg-out and trust a federation of 15 companies
column59: who are the signers for Liquid transactions
column60: whereas on Bitcoin and Lightning you don‘t have to trust any intermediaries. The upside of the Liquid blockchain is that the transaction speed
column61: privacy are higher and currently the fees are lower than on the Bitcoin blockchain. I compared all network fees
column62: transaction
column63: and service fees that applied with the different methods of opening a channel. The cost of the incoming transaction to open the channel was the highest with Blixt as I used bitcoin on-chain at a time when the average fee rate was 110 sat/vByte ($0.000054). Channel opening was the cheapest when using Lightning directly from another LN wallet. The route using Liquid and Boltz was a little bit more expensive than using Lightning. The available balance after opening the channel varied significantly. Zeus had the lowest balance of 52

column74: 2024. I strolled through the scorching heat
column75: making my way up to the kopje
column76: navigating through rocks
column77: grass

column83: regardless of whether I used NetOne or Econet. I was able to send WhatsApp messages

column88: and for this test

column90: surrounded by trees and bushes
column91: as I fend off large ants attempting to crawl up under my trousers I found 4.21 Mbps download and 0.36 Mbps upload. Glad that I set up the apps already a few days earlier. See also: Bitcoin and Stablecoins Will Bring Crypto Mass Adoption to Africa My speed test results showed a ping of 90 and a download speed of 4.6 Mbps and an upload speed 0.5 Mbps. When I started testing the wallets
column92: the Phoenix wallet opened immediately. The Green wallet took 13 seconds to open and the Mutiny wallet needed 18 seconds. However
column93: Zeus didn't open at all
column94: even after a 150-second wait. Similarly
column95: Blixt opened but failed to sync the channels and wallet
column96: so I couldn't use it. As expected

column98: 000 sats from the different wallets to my Phoenix wallet on my iPhone. So
column99: the Phoenix wallet on the iPhone was on the receiving end. Unfortunately
column100: I could not send from Blixt because
column101: as I said before
column102: it did not sync at all. Zeus was also unusable since it wouldn't even start up. When I attempted a payment with Zeus
column103: it failed after a five minute wait. The Green wallet's payment attempt was unsuccessful too
column104: displaying an error message after I waited for two and a half minutes. With the Mutiny wallet
column105: I almost wanted to stop but after 50 seconds
column106: I was able to send the payment successfully. The Phoenix wallet was the quickest
column107: completing the transfer in just three seconds. And interestingly

column109: taking nine seconds for the payment to go through. I didn't anticipate this result

column111: 000 sats from the Phoenix wallet on my iPhone
column112: which had previously served as the receiving wallet. The results were somewhat similar to the previous test. The time until the payment was sent from Phoenix was three seconds and it showed up in Mutiny
column113: Phoenix and the Wallet of Satoshi immediately. Blixt did not work. With Green
column114: the payment failed after I waited for 35 seconds. Similarly
column115: Zeus also failed to receive the payment after I waited for one and half minutes. For this test

column119: the Green wallet managed to send to a Lightning address this time
column120: completing the payment in 40 seconds. This was unexpected given its previous failures in other tests. Blixt and Zeus didn't work. Mutiny
column123: successfully completed the payments to a Lightning address. I wanted to test whether I could exchange 20
column124: 000 sats for Liquid in these conditions
column125: just to be confident in recommending it to my followers. For the Lightning to Liquid swap I was using the Boltz.exchange website

column127: Green and Zeus since their earlier payment attempts had failed. Surprisingly Mutiny failed in this swap; the payment did not go through even after I waited for two minutes. Both Phoenix and the Wallet of Satoshi successfully completed the swap from Lightning to Liquid Bitcoin. Also here the custodial Wallet of Satoshi was slower compared to the self-custodial Phoenix wallet. The differences in fees for the payments were marginal
column129: which is negligible. The costs for sending and receiving were roughly the same across different wallets. However
column130: the costs associated with opening a channel varied significantly. Notably
column131: the Green wallet was the cheapest option
column132: requiring only 3% of the transferred amount as fees. On the other hand
column133: Zeus was the most expensive in these terms. In terms of payment reliability
column134: Phoenix and the Wallet of Satoshi stood out as the most dependable. This isn't surprising for the Wallet of Satoshi
column135: given its custodial nature. Following closely was Mutiny
column136: which successfully completed three out of four payment attempts. Green
column138: managed only one successful payment out of four. Phoenix showed remarkable reliability
column139: successfully processing all four payments. I even managed to send 11 sats from my Phoenix wallet to my Alby Lightning address under very challenging conditions with a download rate of only 0.15 Mbps
column141: and a ping of 185. Phoenix stands out as the clear winner in terms of payment speed. It was even faster than the custodial Wallet of Satoshi. Green and Mutiny also show satisfactory performance
column142: provided they functioned correctly. I evaluated the wallets' features
column143: focusing on their user-friendliness and security aspects. How easy is it to do a backup? Is the wallet open source? How well are the wallet users guided to ensure highest security standards are applied without their actions compromising them? I focused on the backup process
column145: because this results in acceptable security and randomness for the private keys and it's easier to store 12 words than 24. Green and Phoenix use 12-word seeds
column147: Mutiny and Zeus opt for 24-word seeds. A key aspect of product design is encouraging users to adopt high-security measures seamlessly. Being forced to write down the backup while opening the wallet is one of these good design features. I call it “forced backup” and only Green offers it. All the other wallets show a call to action only. Conversely
column148: permitting the seed phrase to be copied to the device's clipboard for convenience may compromise the security of the funds. Uninformed users and newbies might copy it
column149: send their seed per email to themselves
column150: store it as a screenshot or in a Word document. I have seen it all. Convenience is the enemy of security. While it's true that users should only store small amounts in a Lightning wallet
column151: it's also a fact that users will apply the same unsafe behavior to an on-chain wallet
column152: because why not? Blixt allows copying the seed. Mutiny and Zeus too
column153: but they at least warn their users. Green and Zeus are doing it the right way and prevent copying the seed
column154: aligning with best security practices. I think cloud backups on the user side are not desirable. They can be a double-edged sword
column155: offering convenience but also presenting potential security risks and accessibility issues. Many people in African countries don't have a Google Drive or iCloud account to secure their channels. For added security
column156: I prefer to use a PIN
column158: or pattern lock to secure a Bitcoin wallet. Otherwise
column159: for example in case a security officer at an airport or a thief wants me to open my wallet
column160: I can be forced to use my fingerprint or my Face ID. Blixt
column162: Green and Zeus offer password or PIN-based security. Phoenix provided biometric options such as face ID or fingerprint recognition only
column163: but I hope they consider making changes to this feature. See also: Gridless Uses Bitcoin Mining to Power Rural Africa A significant feature I value is whether the wallets offer a separate on-chain Bitcoin wallet. This is a great feature as users only need to install one app for Bitcoin and Lightning. Blixt
column165: Green and Zeus provide a separate on-chain Bitcoin wallet. Phoenix does not. While it allows for swapping in and out
column166: the functionality is integrated and not separated as a distinct Bitcoin wallet. Coin control is going to be more and more important as transaction fees are rising. We need Bitcoin mobile wallets allowing us to do coin control and choose different UTXOs for a transaction. Sadly
column167: none of the tested wallets allows that. This limitation impacts users' ability to manage transaction costs effectively. While Green does offer coin control
column168: it's only available in their desktop version
column169: not on mobile. A Lightning address
column170: similar in format to an email address
column171: is a convenient feature that allows you to receive Lightning payments asynchronously without requiring the wallet to be actively open. Blixt offers a LN address in their experimental feature called "Lightning Box." Zeus is using hodl invoices
column172: a solution that has been criticized by a few developers because of the complexity and the fact that holding invoices could affect the performance of the Lightning Network overall. The other self-custody wallets do not offer Lightning addresses. Given this
column173: it might be a better option to use custodial services like getalby.com or the Wallet of Satoshi for a Lightning address and to send the sats to a Bitcoin
column174: Lightning or Liquid self-custody wallet from time to time. All the wallets allow payments to Lightning addresses. Only Phoenix offers auto channels at the moment. This means Phoenix is more convenient than other wallets
column175: because you only have to set up one channel. The channel then dynamically adjusts its size if you send more funds to it than its liquidity allows. To keep your channel size consistent
column176: you should not swap out to on-chain bitcoin as it reduces the size of the channel. In terms of fee settings
column177: all wallets except Mutiny allow you to define the maximum Lightning fee you're willing to pay. This gives users some control over their payment costs. Regarding channel management
column178: all wallets allow you to force close the channels. Additionally
column180: Zeus and Phoenix allow you to purchase inbound liquidity. After returning to town I tested the payments that failed a second time. I realized that Green’s experimental mode is really very experimental
column181: because I could not send a single Lightning payment with Green and other people reported the same in the Blockstream Telegram group. Blixt was still not able to sync to the top of the blockchain and after five minutes of waiting I stopped the process. Zeus was able to sync and started the node
column182: but then LND was taking a long time to get Zeus “ready to make payments” and after three minutes of waiting I closed the app. From my educator's perspective
column183: my top choices are the Phoenix and Mutiny wallet. Everything works with Phoenix
column184: you don’t need to worry about channel management and payments are even faster than with the custodial Wallet of Satoshi. The fees for payments in Phoenix might be off-putting
column185: from that perspective one might look into Mutiny as it is convincing due to its user-friendliness
column186: making it ideal for beginners. Mutiny’s channel opening was more expensive though and it doesn’t offer auto channels. Part of their business model is the optional Mutiny+ subscription for 16
column187: 000 sats per month. Green would be a strong recommendation

column1: 142::https://blockworks.co/news/algorand-fork-voi-blockchain::Blockworks::article::Algorand fork Voi tries a blockchain reboot::The self-declared “community-powered blockchain” testing a new network based on Algrorand tech.::Exclusive: The self-declared “community-powered blockchain” testing a new network based on Algrorand tech Maurice NORBERT/Shutterstock
column2: modified by Blockworks Veteran members of the Algorand proof-of-stake blockchain ecosystem have banded together to launch a new iteration of the open-source code
column3: called Voi
column4: which is currently in testnet. Leading the new project is Chris Swenor
column5: co-founder of both Reach
column6: a blockchain development platform and the Algorand decentralized exchange (DEX) HumbleSwap. Work on Voi began in 2022
column7: with a premise that the blockchain should better align incentives with its community of developers and users
column8: and motivated by Swenor’s frustration with perceived shortcomings within the crypto industry. “I looked around and I was so frustrated that I saw that [venture capitalists] and the early builders owned over 90% of all tokens
column9: and the people that are actually still there during the bear market really didn’t own the chain
column10: but they’re still there pouring their heart into it
column11: ” Swenor told Blockworks. Voi is only forking the Algorand code
column12: but not the chain’s state. So
column13: unlike the failed EthPoW fork of Ethereum
column14: for instance
column15: Voi will have its own crypto token
column16: but one with no connection to ownership of ALGO. In software development
column17: a repository fork is essentially a copy of a repository that allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project. That’s what’s happening here
column18: in contrast to an Algorand blockchain fork
column19: which is not possible. Algorand has struggled to attract users in recent years. Its seven-day dex volume
column20: for example
column21: is currently less than $10 million
column22: according to DeFi Llama
column23: placing it 38th by that metric. Read more: Closure of largest DeFi destination underscores Algorand’s struggles Swenor’s critique is not specifically of Algorand or its development stewards Algorand Technologies and the Algorand Foundation
column24: with which he said he maintains good relations. Blockworks reached out to both Algorand entities to learn more. As a long time developer within the Algorand tech stack
column25: Swenor said it was natural to remain focused on the Algorand consensus engine. “The thing that was very clear is that the Algorand tech is literally the best tech that we’ve ever worked with
column26: as far as speed and what it can deliver
column27: ” he said. One of the chief differences is that Voi’s developers have earmarked 75% of its entire market cap for “ecosystem growth.” That includes node runners
column28: and the testnet has attracted nearly 500 nodes according to its explorer
column29: though it’s not apparent how many of those are independently operated. “This means that a very small percentage of the overall network [token] is earmarked for operations and the core team
column30: ” Swenor said. Voi intends to concentrate on a smaller vertical of applications as part of its go-to-market strategy
column31: emphasizing “membership infrastructure
column32: ” in contrast to Algorand’s institutional focus. But Swenor also expects to contribute to Algorand development by bringing in developers
column33: and improving tooling such as wallet and node software. The new network counts original Algorand investor Arrington Capital among its seed investors along with Sonic Boom Ventures
column34: founded by former Algorand
column35: Inc. CEO Steven Kokinos
column36: who sees it as complementary to Algorand. “I think what is exciting about Voi in particular is that they’ve done a lot of work to be able to connect Voi back to the Algorand mainnet and be able to exchange assets using tech like state proofs that was built into Algorand for that express purpose
column37: ” Kokinos told Blockworks. The remaining Algorand team was initially skeptical of Voi
column38: Swenor said
column39: but that changed over time. They’re seeing now that this is actually beneficial for Algorand as a whole…because we’re kind of at different missions and we’re going after different things
column40: I don’t see them seeing it as a threat by any means
column41: ” he said. Updated Dec. 18
