column4: state media reported that an official from China’s foreign exchange regulator mentioned the “programmable features” of a central bank digital currency (CBDC) could boost the efficiency of monetary policies. China is on the list of nations crafting their own CBDCs – essentially digital money made by central banks. Though
column5: it’s still early days for its mainstream use. At the moment
column6: CBDCs are viewed mainly as the digital equivalent of physical cash. However
column7: Lu Lei from the State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) shared in a forum that
column8: thanks to its adaptable features
column9: central banks might evolve CBDCs to act like M2 money
column10: encompassing certain deposits and savings. To clarify
column11: CBDC’s programmable aspects mean its settings can be tweaked. Imagine digital money that could expire or be set aside just for specific purchases. Lu anticipates the People’s Bank of China might look into these features to modify CBDC rates
column12: which might then be leveraged to guide the broader economy. He also highlighted how CBDC-based international payments could make transactions more secure
column13: easy
column14: and inclusive. It’s worth noting that last year
column15: Chinese banks joined a cross-border transaction trial led by the Bank of International Settlements. By the end of June
column16: transactions using China’s digital currency
column17: named e-CNY
column18: reached about 1.8 trillion yuan (roughly $249.33 billion). However
column19: the e-CNY available only represented a tiny fraction (0.16%) of China’s overall physical cash supply. source Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency

column1: 144::https://cryptobriefing.com/kimsuky-hackinggroup-targets-southkorean-crypto/::Crypto Briefing::article::Kimsuky hacking group targets South Korean crypto firms with new malware — report::Kaspersky uncovers a potential link between Kimsuky and the notorious Lazarus Group.::Join the hunt for $12
column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Kimsuky
column4: a North Korean hacking group
column5: has reportedly been utilizing a new malware variant called “Durian” to launch targeted attacks on South Korean crypto firms. The incidence is highlighted in a recently published threat intelligence report from Kaspersky. According to Kaspersky’s research
column6: the malware is deployed specifically to break and exploit against security software used by South Korean crypto firms
column7: at least two of which have been identified. “Based on our telemetry
column8: we pinpointed two victims within the South Korean cryptocurrency sector. The first compromise occurred in August 2023
column9: followed by a second in November 2023. Notably
column10: our investigation did not uncover any additional victims during these instances
column11: indicating a highly focused targeting approach by the actor
column12: ” the report stated. The Durian malware is an “initial-stage” installer. It introduces supplementary malware and establishes a persistence mechanism inside the device or instance that it attacks. Once executed
column13: the malware generates a stage loader and adds it to the exposed operating system for automatic execution. The malware’s installation is finalized with a culminating payload written over Golang
column14: an open-source programming language developed by Google. The final payload then enables the execution of remote commands that instruct the exploited device to download and exfiltrate files. The choice of language is also suspect due to Golang’s efficiency for networked machines and large codebases. Interestingly
column15: Kaspersky’s report also revealed that LazyLoad
column16: one of the tools deployed by Durian
column17: has been used by Andariel
column18: a sub-group within the notorious North Korean hacking consortium Lazarus Group. This finding suggests a potential connection between Kimsuky and Lazarus
column19: although Kaspersky described the link as “tenuous” at best. Lazarus Group
column20: which first emerged in 2009
column21: has established itself as one of the most notorious groups of crypto hackers. Independent onchain sleuth ZachXBT recently revealed that the group had successfully laundered over $200 million in ill-gotten crypto between 2020 and 2023. In total
column22: Lazarus is accused of stealing over $3 billion in crypto assets in the six years leading up to 2023. Last week
column23: a US court has ordered the forfeiture of 279 crypto accounts tied to North Korean threat incidents. Share this article The information on or accessed through this website is obtained from independent sources we believe to be accurate and reliable

column2: more efficient and more transparent.::Recently the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) bought a $15 million stake in Digital Asset Holdings
column3: a developer of blockchain technology. One of the main reasons is to upgrade its share registry system by using blockchain or distributed ledger technology. And it’s been reported that JP Morgan Chase is also partnering with Digital Asset Holdings to trial the technology. Put simply
column4: blockchain technology is a method of recording and confirming transactions where instead of a centralised platform
column5: participants each hold a complete record of transactions through peer to peer verification of transactions. This means there is no central recording system
column6: rather each participant keeps a record of all transactions ever made. This is the same system which allows Bitcoin to operate with no central body. Instead of the ASX clearing house settling trades
column7: trades will be settled by participants confirming transactions through the peer to peer network. The network (likely made up of brokers) will record the buyer and selling participants
column8: the number of shares traded
column9: price of shares
column10: time of exchange and the exchange of funds. The ASX will still provide a centralised electronic exchange for participants to place orders
column11: only the settlement or back office function will be sourced to the network. Blockchain has great potential to cut inefficiencies in the share settlement function. As trades are settled by peer confirmation
column12: there is no need for a clearing house
column13: auditors to verify trades and custodians to ensure a fund has the shares they say they hold. Essentially this is cutting out the middleman in the back office which means less costs in record keeping and in turn less costs to trading on the ASX. Given the high costs in getting a third party to audit
column14: record keep and/or verify trades these costs are substantial. The peer confirmation of trades also means settlement can be almost instantaneous. Compare this to the current settlement period of three working days (‘T+3’) as the ASX needs to make sure the participants have the money and shares on hand to exchange. This would make shares a far more liquid investment – almost as good as having cash on hand. Higher liquidity means more investment into ASX shares. As all participants have the full record of transactions and therefore holdings of investors there is complete transparency in the equity market. This makes it almost impossible to falsify transactions or to alter prior transactions. If a false trade occurs
column15: participants will find inconsistencies in their full ledger and reject the trade. For example an investor would be unable to sell stock that they did not own as all participants would know exactly how much stock the investor owns now. First
column16: implementing a clearing system using blockchain will introduce a new type of fee. In the Bitcoin blockchain
column17: miners process Bitcoin transactions by solving optimisation problems and get rewarded by newly created Bitcoins and settlement fees offered by Bitcoin users who wish to have their transactions processed. Miners prioritise the order of transactions to be cleared based on the fees offered and the difficulty of the problems to record the transaction in a block. This is what allows a blockchain to have no centralised clearing house. If the ASX blockchain requires investors to include transaction fees in order for their transactions to be cleared
column18: then the ASX is transferring the cost of maintaining the back office to the investors. If this is to happen
column19: investors will have to compete against each other to have their transactions cleared faster than those of others. Alternatively
column20: if the new system doesn’t allow such fees and relies on brokers or other entities to clear the transactions
column21: then the ASX is again transferring the cost of maintaining back office to those entities. The second concern is increased transparency. Under the proposed trading system
column22: most of positions of the market participants could be exposed to the public as the trading ID can be identified. This could disadvantage many investors such as super
column23: managed and hedge funds. For example
column24: a super fund typically sells a large position on a gradual basis for a prolonged time period. In this process
column25: it is critical not to be noticed by other traders who may take advantage of such large-scale sales. With complete transparency such as in blockchain
column26: such a sell-off could not be applied effectively. Potentially this may make investors leave the ASX and seek more opaque venues to trade such as dark pools. Clearly a direct adoption of blockchain from Bitcoin technology would not be viable for the ASX. If the ASX is able to adopt blockchain technology and address privacy
column27: security and trade transparency concerns then this would yield great cost savings to investors.::2016-02-03T19:05:23Z::Bitcoin

column1: 146::https://www.coindesk.com/learn/what-are-crypto-otc-desks-and-how-do-they-work/::CoinDesk::article::What Are Crypto OTC Desks And How Do They Work?::Cryptocurrency OTC desks play an essential role in facilitating large cryptocurrency trades in the global crypto markets. What Are Crypto OTC Desks? How Do Cryptocurrency OTC Desks Work? Why Are OTC Desks Important in Crypto? Pros and Cons of Using OTC Desks in Crypto The Bottom Line::Crypto OTC desks play an important role in facilitating large cryptocurrency purchases and sales. Read on to learn what crypto OTC desks are
column2: how they work
column3: and why they play an essential role in the global crypto markets. This is partner content sourced from Laura Shin’s Unchained and published by CoinDesk. Over-the-counter (OTC) trading desks facilitate trading between two parties without revealing information about the trade to the public via an exchange orderbook or otherwise. The OTC desk acts as a matchmaker enabling high-volume transactions between buyers and sellers. During an OTC trade
column4: the two parties agree on a purchase price before they can complete the transaction. The trades can be crypto-to-crypto or fiat-to-crypto. OTC desks differ from traditional exchanges in terms of transaction transparency. A crypto exchange like Kraken or Binance acts as an intermediary between buyers and sellers. Transactions are executed via an orderbook for everyone to see. Conversely
column5: crypto OTC trading is relatively opaque since no one beyond the transacting parties is aware of the price and volume of assets being traded. Moreover
column6: OTC trades are typically insulated from wider market fluctuations that occur on exchanges. There are two types of OTC desks: principal and agency. Principal desks assume the risk to the buyer by using their funds to purchase whatever asset the buyer requires. For instance
column7: a bitcoin whale looking to make a large bitcoin purchase will request a quote from the OTC desk
column8: and they will respond with a price based on prevailing market conditions. The buyer can choose to accept the offer or make a reasonable counter. Should the buyer accept the proposed price
column9: the OTC desk is responsible for sourcing and delivering the BTC to the buyer as per the legal contract signed beforehand. Agency desks
column10: on the other hand
column11: don’t assume the market risk since they don’t put up their own money for transactions. Instead
column12: they act as an intermediary to broker a deal on behalf of the buyer. They will charge a brokerage fee for this service. Crypto OTC desks exist to enable large investors
column13: such as early adopters
column14: high-net-worth individuals
column15: and institutional investors
column16: to buy and sell large amounts of cryptocurrencies without alerting the market about their intention or transaction. If you try to buy 1
column17: 000 BTC on a regular crypto exchange
column18: you will run into several problems. A key challenge is that the chances of finding someone selling that amount at any given time on a single exchange are slim. You will have to opt to spread the purchases across several sellers. The problem that arises is you may end up making some of the purchases at a significantly higher price. Of course
column19: you may be able to avoid this altogether and spread the purchase across several exchanges
column20: but this will be time-consuming and costly. Moreover
column21: you will show the entire market that you are a large buyer or seller
column22: which will most likely lead to a worse execution price. Crypto OTC desks remove the uncertainty and risk for investors looking to buy or sell large volumes of crypto. Here are some of the benefits and challenges of using crypto OTC desks. Large crypto investors looking to buy and sell substantial volumes of cryptocurrency prefer the crypto OTC market over trading on crypto exchanges. Most whales keep their transactions off exchange order books to avoid the market moving against them when they want to transact. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 147::https://ambcrypto.com/bitcoin-fees-hit-3-month-low-a-12m-drop-explained/::AMBCrypto::article::Bitcoin fees hit 3-month low: A $12M drop
column2: explained::The reduced demand for the Bitcoin network post-halving has led to a significant drop in its fees. ::The reduced demand for the Bitcoin network post-halving has led to a significant drop in its fees.  Bitcoin [BTC] network fees have fallen to a record low as the Layer 1 (L1) transaction volume continues to decline. In a post on X (formerly Twitter)
column3: on-chain data provider IntoTheBlock noted that transaction fees on the Bitcoin network plunged to their lowest level in three months this week. Recording a weekly transaction fee totaling $12 million
column4: the network saw a 45% decline from the previous week.  This week’s decline in the Bitcoin network’s fee is due to the decrease in its transaction volume. According to Santiment’s data
column5: the aggregate amount of BTC across all transactions completed on the network fell steadily during the week. Between the 11th and the 17th of May
column6: Bitcoin’s transaction volume plummeted by 5%. Source: Santiment The average fee paid per transaction dropped as the network saw a decline in demand. According to Messari
column7: this decreased by 17% during the period under review. At press time
column8: the average cost of executing a transaction on the Bitcoin network was $2.56. The miners on Bitcoin’s network are the primary victims of its low network fees. After the percentage of miner revenue derived from transaction fees rallied to a year-to-date high of 75% on the 20th of April
column9: post-halving event
column10: it has since declined significantly. Source: Messari As of this writing
column11: only 4% of miner revenue is derived from the fees paid by Bitcoin’s users. This marked a 95% decline from the YTD high
column12: per Messari’s data. Low revenue and BTC’s recent price troubles have forced some miners to sell their holdings. AMBCrypto assessed Bitcoin’s Miner Supply Ratio and found that it has fallen by 0.21% since the halving event. This metric measures miners’ BTC holdings relative to the coin’s total supply. When it declines this way
column13: miners are selling a larger portion of their mined coins. This is often due to capitulation from high operational costs
column14: the desire to take profit
column15: or a lack of confidence in the coin’s price. Is your portfolio green? Check out the BTC Profit Calculator BTC sell-offs among miners on its network have led to a depletion of the coin’s Miner Reserve. This measures the amount of coins held in miners’ wallets within a specified period. Source: CryptoQuant According to CryptoQuant’s data
column16: BTC’s Miner Reserve
column17: at 1.81 million at press time
column18: has dropped by 1% since the 25th of April.   Disclaimer: AMBCrypto's content is meant to be informational in nature and should not be interpreted as investment advice. Trading

column6: please proceed to our verification methodology page The Ethereum blockchain is arguably the biggest developer-centric ecosystem dealing with decentralized applications (DApps) and decentralized finance (DeFi). Yet
column7: developers looking to Ethereum to build usable web3 resources do not simply start building on the mainnet. Instead
column8: they rely first on testnets. This guide discusses one popular testnet
column9: Rinkeby. Read on to learn about this vital Ethereum test network. Testnets are used to support test transactions. Developers user testnets to try out implementations that use frameworks such as Truffle and the Solidity programming language. This allows DApps to be tested and improved without developers encountering the financial burden and risks associated with the main Ethereum blockchain. Rinkeby is one such testnet. Even though the Rinkeby testnet and Rinkeby faucet were deprecated as of 2024
column10: assessing their role in facilitating robust DApp development can help both new and advanced developers better understand Ethereum test networks. The Rinkeby testnet for Ethereum DApp testing came into existence in 2017. It focused specifically on smart contract testing and quickly became vital to the Ethereum development environment. Rinkeby operated as a proof-of-authority (PoA) testnet at a time when Ethereum itself was proof-of-work (PoW)
column11: as was Ropsten

column13: the Rinkeby network emerged as a particularly stable option. The network offered something similar to a “Controlled Node Validation” environment and supported predictable testing scenarios. The Rinkeby testnet community quickly became one of the most active
column14: offering reliable and quick feedback on smart contract execution. Meanwhile
column15: the PoA consensus ensured the testnet became one of the best for developers looking to continuously test setups and integrations. Did you know? Controlled Node Validation
column16: in the case of Rinkeby testnet
column17: refers to a system where only a limited number of entities (trusted) are allowed to confirm and validate transactions. Rinkeby was one of the more popular Ethereum test networks used to quickly test smart contracts and DApps. The Rinkeby testnet was a controlled sandbox-like environment replicating the Ethereum blockchain environment. Developers could deploy applications on this testnet before introducing them to the mainnet. As for the testnet gas fees

column1: 149::https://blockworks.co/news/future-tokenization-permissioned-blockchains::Blockworks::article::The future of tokenization? Permissioned blockchains::Opinion: Despite BlackRock’s fund on Ethereum
column2: the future of tokenization is really with permissioned blockchains.::At least for the near future
column3: the majority of institutional tokenization will take place on closed
column4: permissioned networks Artwork by Crystal Le Many interpret BlackRock pouring $100 million into Ethereum as a sign that institutional tokenization will finally take off on public
column5: permissionless networks. It will — but BlackRock’s tokenized fund is only melting the tip of a Titanic-sized iceberg. The crypto industry has cried wolf about institutions coming many times. By this point
column6: we definitely know they’re interested in tokenization. The big players — BNP Paribas
column7: JPMorgan
column8: Goldman Sachs
column9: the Hong Kong government
column10: Franklin Templeton
column11: Hamilton Lane and now BlackRock — have already been exploring blockchain technology for a while. It’s certainly a watershed moment when the world’s largest asset manager opts for a public chain over a private platform like JPMorgan’s Onyx or Goldman Sach’s solution. BlackRock’s tokenized fund on Ethereum signals institutional trust in a public
column12: permissionless network
column13: bringing much-needed legitimacy to the nascent public ecosystem. The move will also encourage other traditional institutional players to transition to on-chain funds. But while BlackRock’s tokenization on Ethereum was a bold move worthy of the headlines it made
column14: the reality is tokenization is predominantly taking place on private
column15: permissioned blockchains. To date
column16: the majority of institutional efforts have involved private networks. The Hong Kong government’s $100 million tokenized green bond used GS DAP
column17: deployed on the privacy-enabled blockchain Canton. Goldman Sachs
column18: BNY Mellon
column19: Cboe Global Markets and other firms recently wrapped up a series of pilots on the same network. HSBC has used its platform
column20: the Orion digital assets platform
column21: to tokenize gold for everyday investors in Hong Kong. And BlackRock has used the private Tokenized Collateral Network on JPMorgan’s Ethereum-based Onyx to tokenize shares in one of its money market funds. Read more from our opinion section: Fintech has hit a wall. Blockchain will break through it. Bitcoin proved that a multi-billion dollar market can essentially come out of thin air. The industry believed that everything could be tokenized and traded via blockchain and enjoy increased liquidity. However
column22: the glittering promise of liquidity for real-world assets has (so far) proven a mirage. The initial token boom of 2018 hyped trillions of dollars in tokenized assets on public networks. Almost seven years later
column23: there are only a few billions of dollars in total assets under management on public networks — a tiny piece of what’s theoretically possible. Meanwhile
column24: private networks are moving billions of dollars in daily transactions. The crypto industry loves to float the $16 trillion in illiquid assets Boston Consulting Group projects to be tokenized by 2030. Even the more conservative estimate — McKinsey & Company’s $5 trillion in tokenized real-world assets — is huge. If we look at the trends and what’s happening
column25: though
column26: it’s clear that a majority of these assets will first be tokenized on private networks. Unlike crypto — which is an entirely new asset class existing within open ecosystems — real-world assets inherit the legacy of traditional finance. This legacy favors control over assets and customers
column27: closed ecosystems and compatibility with traditional markets — a direct contrast with the ethos of public
column28: permissionless networks. This explains why financial institutions favor private networks. Private networks operate closer to the existing financial infrastructure and can facilitate easier compliance. These networks are more capable of meeting business needs
column29: as they provide flexibility in governance and customization
column30: like modifications to the blockchain’s consensus protocol
column31: transaction validation rules and permissions. These networks can also handle higher transaction volumes
column32: which is essential for scalability. There’s also the issue of regulation. It’s only in the past couple of years that regulators have begun to pass and enact comprehensive frameworks guiding involvement in crypto assets. As a result
column33: public blockchain technology has felt untouchable until recently to these institutions
column34: for whom compliance is paramount. For securities
column35: there is at least some clarity. Tokenized securities are still securities and must operate within the existing regulatory framework. However
column36: some assets — like real estate — which are not necessarily securities off chain will be considered securities once tokenized. The industry is still figuring out what it would take for these assets to meet existing requirements. Today
column37: nobody doubts the benefits of blockchain technology. The issue for traditional finance is mostly one of integration and technology costs
column38: infrastructure compatibility and regulatory concerns. While public networks offer more transparency
column39: immutability and decentralization
column40: private networks are more practical and familiar for financial institutions. There are also a few technology issues to sort out. Let’s use BlackRock’s chosen Ethereum as an example. While Ethereum has made progress with initiatives like layer-2 solutions and the Merge to Ethereum 2.0
column41: the network faces challenges meeting the demand for speed
column42: privacy and compliance necessary for transactions involving regulated institutions. As the technology matures and regulatory frameworks evolve
column43: we can expect to see more tokenization migrating to public blockchains and a new wave of innovation. However
column44: at least for the near future
column45: the majority of institutional tokenization will take place on closed

column1: 152::https://theconversation.com/are-nfts-really-dead-and-buried-all-signs-point-to-yes-214145::The Conversation::article::Are NFTs really dead and buried? All signs point to ‘yes’::This is why no one is buying your cartoon ape.::Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are in dire straits. With the market in a severe downturn
column2: it’s safe to assume the NFT bubble has well and truly burst. It was never clear why these digital collectables traded for such large amounts of money. Now they mostly do not. What’s behind their turn of fate? And is there any hope for their future? Non-fungible tokens are a blockchain-based means to claim unique “ownership” of digital assets. “Non-fungible” means unique
column3: as opposed to a “fungible” item such as a five-dollar bill
column4: which is the same as every other five-dollar bill. But just because an item is unique that doesn’t make it valuable. Digital assets are easily copied
column5: so an NFT is essentially a receipt showing you have paid for something that other people can get for free. This is a pretty dubious basis for value. The two most traded sets of NFTs are the Bored Apes collection created in April 2021 and the CryptoPunks collection launched in June 2017. Both sets consist of 10
column6: 000 similar-looking but unique figures
column7: distinguished by differing hairstyles
column8: hats
column9: skin colours and so forth. The Bored Ape character seems derivative of the drawings of Jamie Hewlett
column10: the artist who drew Tank Girl and Damon Albarn’s virtual band Gorillaz. The CryptoPunks are even less interesting. Although the first NFTs emerged around a decade ago
column11: the trend really started to take off in 2021. And for a time NFTs were very fashionable. Even the venerable auction house Sotheby’s
column12: founded in 1744
column13: jumped on the NFT bandwagon. Sotheby’s sold 101 Bored Ape NFTs for more than US$20 million in September 2021. They’re now facing a lawsuit from a disgruntled buyer. As with Bitcoin and similar speculative tokens
column14: the primary driver for buying NFTs was greed. Seeing the initial price rises
column15: people hoped they too could make huge profits. NFTs are essentially a superficially sophisticated form of gambling. Like Bitcoin
column16: they have no fundamental value. Read more: NFTs
column17: an overblown speculative bubble inflated by pop culture and crypto mania Generally
column18: one would only profit from buying an NFT by finding a “greater fool” willing to pay even more for it. So there was never a shortage of people – including some quite famous ones – talking them up and hoping to instil a fear of missing out. Eminem bought a Bored Ape that looked a bit like him. Rapper KSI boasted on Twitter about his Bored Ape rising in price. For a while there were large increases in the prices of many NFTs. But like all speculative bubbles
column19: it was likely to end in tears. Although it’s almost impossible to predict when a bubble for a speculative asset will burst
column20: we have seen this process play out before. Centuries ago there were the Dutch tulip
column21: South Sea and Mississippi bubbles. Around 1970
column22: there was a speculative bubble in the shares of nickel miner Poseidon. Then came the Beanie Baby and dotcom booms of the late 1990s – and more recently
column23: meme stocks and Terra-Luna cryptocurrency. Punters now seem to be as bored with NFTs as the apes. Google searches for “NFT” – which grew rapidly through 2021 – have fallen away dramatically. Trading volumes have collapsed. Prices in the NFT market have also seen huge falls. The prices of Bored Ape NFTs are down about 90% from their peak. The CryptoPunks have done slightly better by losing only 80%. A recent report covering about 73
column24: 000 NFTs estimated 70
column25: 000 are now valued at zero. This leaves 23 million people holding a worthless “asset”. One high-profile example is an NFT of the first tweet by then-Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey. Crypto entrepreneur Sina Estavi bought this NFT for US$2.9 million in March 2021. When he tried to sell it a year later the top bid was US$6
column26: 800. What drove the NFT collapse? As well as losing their novelty
column27: the market was hurt by the large falls in the price of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrency
column28: as well as the collapse of the FTX exchange and publicity given to scams. Beyond that
column29: the lifting of COVID lockdowns meant people who began trading NFTs now had other ways to pass their time. And higher interest rates from mid-2022 made most speculative assets seem less attractive. Collectively
column30: all of these factors made NFTs seem like a riskier proposition. Prominent people started jumping off the bandwagon. Some of KSI’s later tweets lament the losses he suffered from his gambles.  Last year
column31: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced
column32: when he was chancellor of the exchequer (their equivalent of treasurer)
column33: the Royal Mint would produce an NFT. The plan has now been abandoned. Some foolish people had even taken out loans using the “value” of their NFTs as collateral. When the lenders wanted the money back
column34: they were in trouble: forced to sell their NFTs
column35: they got back much less than they’d paid. Fortunately
column36: there weren’t enough people like this to lead to a systemic problem in the financial sector. Read more: Damien Hirst's dotty 'currency' art makes as much sense as Bitcoin NFTs probably won’t completely disappear. Some subjects of past bubbles are still around. Tulips are still grown in the Netherlands. Poseidon shares
column37: which ran up from 80 cents in September 1969 to $280 in February 1970
column38: are still listed (and currently trading for 2 cents). But unless some actual use is found for them
column39: NFTs are likely to fade further from public discussion
column40: with their prices increasingly trending down (although the occasional blip up may give die-hard fans some hope). They will probably join the Dutch tulips and dotcoms in the history of speculative follies. Read more: Almost no one uses Bitcoin as currency
column41: new data proves. It's actually more like gambling::2023-10-01T19:16:08Z::Blockchain

column10: please proceed to our verification methodology page Charles Hoskinson is a prolific figure in the cryptocurrency industry. He’s among the original Ethereum co-founders

column12: a proof-of-stake (PoS) blockchain. Read on to learn who Charles Hoskinson is

column15: and some of the challenges he has experienced. Charles Hoskinson is an American mathematician and tech entrepreneur in the web3 space. He was born in Hawaii
column16: USA
column17: in 1987 to a family of doctors. Hoskinson initially toyed with following in his parents’ footsteps to study medicine. However
column18: he later chartered his path and instead chose to study mathematics. Charles Hoskinson began his academic journey at the Metropolitan State University of Denver
column19: where he earned a degree in analytic number theory. He then enrolled for a Master’s in Mathematics at the University of Colorado Boulder. Hoskinson later enrolled for his PhD but dropped out before he could graduate and joined Ron Paul’s 2008 presidential campaign. Paul’s libertarian views fueled Hoskinson’s decision to join his campaign. Hoskinson was fascinated by Austrian economics and monetary theory
column20: which argued that an economic system founded on fiat currency is essentially unstable
column21: worked. Something that Bitcoin

He has also held various positions in both the private and public sectors. Charles Hoskinson was also the founding chairman of the Bitcoin Foundation’s education committee and helped establish the Cryptocurrency Research Group in 2013. column1: 158::https://theconversation.com/rise-of-cryptocurrencies-like-bitcoin-begs-question-what-is-money-46713::The Conversation::article::Rise of cryptocurrencies like bitcoin begs question: what is money?::Money used to be backed by something of real value such as gold or silver. Bitcoins and other digital currencies will sever that link forever.::When you begin to delve into the question of what money really is
column2: you must be prepared for some metaphysics. Money
column3: currencies and other such media of exchange differ markedly in their backgrounds and means of operation
column4: and have changed quite recently into forms that are barely understandable. For centuries
column5: minted coins not only represented the value and trust of banks
column6: their depositors and eventually nation-states
column7: but also were deemed valuable because they were made from precious metals like gold and silver. These metals are difficult to move around in large quantities
column8: and so banknotes were invented as early as the seventh century in China and brought to Europe in the 13th century. Unlike coins
column9: banknotes were not treated as valuable in themselves since they were simply printed on otherwise worthless paper. Rather
column10: they served as a form of promissory note or IOU that could be presented to the banks that issued them in exchange for their face value in precious metal
column11: coins or bullion. In the 20th century
column12: most central banks and governments stopped backing up their currencies with precious metals
column13: and yet banknotes maintain fluctuating values
column14: with some in high demand as media for exchange both domestically and internationally. Dollars and euros are highly regarded and preferred currencies for international commerce
column15: as well as for stocking private bank accounts. Now we have bitcoins and other digital currencies that exist entirely in blocks of zeros and ones and are even “mined” by machines running algorithms. And earlier this month
column16: bitcoins and their ilk were officially deemed commodities by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission
column17: which will now regulate them. So as the greenbacks and quarters in our pockets slowly disappear
column18: replaced by strings of digits stored on our smartphones
column19: and money takes another step away from being tied to anything of value
column20: a philosophical question comes to mind: does money still exist? And if so
column21: what gives it its value? Money is a “fungible” item
column22: which means that exchange of any one portion for a portion of equal value is not a “taking” of property. That is
column23: you don’t own a particular US$100 bill. You own the value it represents. This is how banks have long worked
column24: since when you deposit your money
column25: you are not entitled to receive the same coins or bills back as you deposited. This is also how “fractional reserve” banking began (in which banks do not keep all the curency on deposit “within” the bank
column26: just some fraction of it) and was not regarded somehow as theft. People took their money to a bank
column27: they were given a note of deposit
column28: which entitled them to withdraw the same amount plus some interest
column29: but they were not entitled to the same coins or bills that they deposited. The money on deposit in a bank is not all physically in the bank (excepting that which is in safety deposit boxes) and has not been really since banking was invented. When you deposit a sum
column30: you no longer own the paper or other medium of exchange used for the deposit
column31: legally. What you own is a debt and obligation by the bank to return the equivalent amount of money with interest. John Searle has described things like money as “some special sort” of social objects. That is
column32: X (coins
column33: bills
column34: strings of digits) work as Y (money) in context C (an economy
column35: coffee shop
column36: bank
column37: etc). In the case of money
column38: anything can conceivably take on the Y role even without an X (think a barter economy). Where metals
column39: then bills and now bits in computer memory take the role of X
column40: money might well be a “free-standing” Y
column41: meaning it could exist without anything to represent it except the web of intentional states (the debts and obligations) that make more familiar forms of money function. It’s only physical manifestation might be a note in a ledger. Without precious metal standards backing national currencies
column42: and in the age of digital transactions
column43: money is decreasingly tied to banknotes
column44: just as its ties to metals have faded. Digital ledgers track exchanges and accounts
column45: with digital strings in computer memories representing the trust and value we once attached to more solid things like coins
column47: in more ephemeral digitally encoded
column48: instantly accessible forms attached to cellphones
column49: computers and chip cards. New types of cryptocurrencies (where cryptography protects its integrity) like bitcoin and others take the concept one step further
column50: distributing the banking to all its users
column51: tying the transactions and ledgers to no particular party but to all users at once. This is similar to mirrored bank servers
column52: but bitcoin is mirrored among all bitcoin owners. A bitcoin is as ownable as dollars are when they are deposited in a bank. Skipping the stage of physical
column53: fungible currencies
column54: bitcoins exist by virtue of their representations in a ledger in cyberspace. The information encoded in a massively distributed and constantly updated blockchain is incapable of the exclusivity required for owning objects in the traditional sense. But the same is true of the information that tracks most of the money in the world. Money in nearly every denomination exists and flows in a similar state
column55: represented by digital bits. Bitcoins nonetheless lack some of the institutional guarantees that other types of money has due to nations and their laws. Depositors to banks are protected in their debts by states
column56: generally
column57: and through contracts with their banks. State insurance and the contractual guarantee that a bank will pay back what has been put into them mean that there is some force behind our trust in the continued existence of a person’s wealth while digitally stored in a bank’s servers. The blockchain exists on many servers at once
column58: spread across the universe of bitcoin owners. Without government insurance or contractual guarantees
column59: only mutual trust maintains the value and integrity of the system. What bitcoin owners own is the debt
column60: just as those who own money in banks own debts that are recorded in bits. They do not own the bits that comprise the information representing that debt
column61: nor the information itself
column62: they own the social object – the money – that those bits represent. Bank ledgers exist. They are tangible
column63: even though digital
column64: and they record the debts owed among parties. While cyberspace is ephemeral
column65: it is still real and physically based. Digital bank ledgers now track money without the necessity for physical transfers of currencies. Bitcoins too exist as digital records of obligations
column66: physically encoded on servers of those who hold them
column67: propagated and distributed for transparency and security
column68: encrypted for privacy. Bitcoins are as real as money in banks. What’s most fascinating about these new digital cryptocurrencies is how much they reveal about the surreal nature of currencies and wealth in our digitized economy. If bitcoins are as real as any other money
column69: how real can money be?::2015-09-25T09:20:47Z::Bitcoin

column1: 159::https://www.coindesk.com/sponsored-content/taking-phemex-coos-pulse-after-the-launch-of-phemexpulse/::CoinDesk::article::Taking Phemex COO’s Pulse after the launch of PhemexPulse::N/A::Sponsored Content Phemex has surged over the past year to become one of the world’s leading digital asset exchanges for both spot and futures transactions. It led the way in copy trading
column2: bridged the gap between centralization and decentralization
column3: and most recently
column4: broke new ground with the launch of its revolutionary social trading platform. This innovative platform is crafted to bring the crypto community together
column5: rewarding users for their regular online engagements with tangible benefits. The introduction of PhemexPulse has sparked considerable buzz within the online sphere. CoinDesk reached out to Phemex COO Stella Chan to talk about the inspiration driving the development of PhemexPulse and the strategic moves the company plans to make in fostering dynamic and engaged communities. Thank you for the congratulations! The launch of PhemexPulse has indeed stirred up considerable conversation among crypto enthusiasts. Users have discovered in PhemexPulse a vibrant platform that not only facilitates community engagement but also rewards their participation
column6: creating a unique and interactive experience within the digital asset space. PhemexPulse has become a hub of activity with 160 groups formed by KOLs [key opinion leaders] and content creators in just two weeks. Users love that the platform allows them to continue their usual online activities – like following expert trading tips and engaging in trend discussions with peers – while earning rewards for their participation. And by rewards
column7: we're talking substantial incentives: a daily prize pool of 9
column8: 000 PT. [Phemex Tokens
column9: or PT
column10: are the exchange’s native coins.] PT is fundamentally linked to our growing Web3 ecosystem and offers substantial promise for traders. Therefore
column11: we are confident that the prize pool will strongly appeal to our community. The landscape is indeed crowded with social networking platforms that users frequent
column12: particularly during a bull market. PhemexPulse
column13: though
column14: distinguishes itself by not only rewarding users for their consistent online engagement but also by fostering a closer relationship between KOLs and their followers within a conversational environment. It offers a compelling chat-to-earn program for active participation that integrates seamlessly with our Web3 ecosystem. Social trading is gaining significant traction and is expected to be a driving force in the upcoming bull market. While current offerings provide a preview of SocialFi's capabilities
column15: there remains a void for a truly Web3-native social platform that prioritizes community interaction. PhemexPulse fills this niche by delivering an authentic
column16: on-the-ground perspective of the crypto market's pulse through peer discussions and activities. Unlike other social trading platforms that focus solely on incentivizing trading
column17: our approach is to cultivate a spirit of collaboration. We aim to foster grassroots innovation within PhemexPulse through Pulse Groups
column18: where the ideas and contributions of any member can be recognized and developed into projects that benefit from a fair launch process
column19: ensuring a level playing field for all. We understand that KOLs have a variety of platforms to connect with their audience. Yet these platforms often dictate the terms of content creation
column20: while PhemexPulse embraces Web3 principles to return control and ownership to the users. Collaborations and engagements within the PhemexPulse ecosystem directly translate into rewards. Our platform is designed to facilitate community contributions and the accumulation of tokens. For KOLs
column21: monetizing their influence is as straightforward as establishing their own Web3 group on PhemexPulse
column22: with funding from Phemex. By creating a group and fostering dialogue with their followers – through quality content and trading insights – KOLs can earn daily rewards in PT
column23: based on their points accrued. PhemexPulse enables KOLs to excel by leveraging their strengths: leading and engaging with their audience. It removes barriers to community interaction
column24: while Phemex provides the means to convert their influence into tangible PT wealth. We believe this model of engagement
column25: unshackled from the confines of traditional social media and coupled with a reward system intrinsic to Web3
column26: will forge new opportunities for KOLs. On PhemexPulse we also provide them an avenue to unveil their exclusive inscriptions and share with their fans. These assets hold great potential and represent a mutually beneficial opportunity for both the KOLs and their followers to possess and exchange. Inscriptions
column27: akin to NFTs
column28: are unique digital assets recorded directly onto the blockchain. Creators can craft these inscriptions and offer them to their followers
column29: who can mint
column30: own and trade them. On PhemexPulse
column31: for instance
column32: crypto influencers act as content creators and can launch their distinct ordinals through our inscription marketplace
column33: allowing the value of each to be shaped by their community's demand. Supporters can engage with and back their preferred influencers on PhemexPulse by acquiring these inscriptions. Inscriptions on PhemexPulse are a testament to the platform's foundational principles. PhemexPulse thrives on the creation of decentralized communities
column34: spearheaded by KOLs. Within these groups
column35: members have the freedom to collaborate and initiate their Web3 projects
column36: enjoying full autonomy. We promote the development of distinctive group cultures and support the creation of community tokens through inscriptions
column37: to enhance group solidarity and cohesion. Our team has dedicated significant effort to devising a scoring system that genuinely benefits our users. We are committed to ensuring that their contributions are recognized and rewarded fairly. We have developed a system designed to enhance user engagement on PhemexPulse and the Phemex trading platform
column38: aiming to forge a comprehensive hub that addresses users' trading and social interaction needs
column39: empowering them through their activities on our platform. In tune with our community-focused approach
column40: we've decided to restructure the PhemexPulse scoring system to better align with user feedback. The newly launched mechanism will emphasize fairness while introducing gamified elements. Within PhemexPulse

column43: executing trades and referring new users. Reward points have no expiration date
column44: providing ongoing value for our users' trading efforts. Additionally

The proportion of Reward and Raffle Fuel points compared to the total available points will determine the users’ PT payout. The total prize pool for PhemexPulse is a remarkable 50 million PT. With our updated scoring system
column47: we're allocating 9
column48: 000 PT each day from our prize pool for distribution throughout this round. I must add that we have revamped the scoring system in response to our users' feedback
column49: who are at the forefront of our efforts. We will continue to listen to their needs and make the necessary adjustments to the scoring system in the next rounds to ensure that they are rewarded fairly for their interactions. Yes

column1: 160::https://beincrypto.com/the-dangers-of-chatgpt-ai-no-one-is-talking-about/::BeInCrypto::article::Are We Ready for ChatGPT? The Dangers of AI No One Is Talking About::While ChatGPT may look like a harmless free tool
column2: this technology can potentially reshape our economy and society as we know it.::We use cookies to improve your experience.  While ChatGPT may look like a harmless and useful free tool
column3: this technology has the potential to reshape our economy and society as we know it drastically. That brings us to alarming problems – and we might not be ready for them. ChatGPT
column4: a chatbot powered by artificial intelligence (AI)
column5: took the world by storm by the end of 2022. The chatbot promises to disrupt search as we know it. The free tool provides useful answers based on prompts the users give to it. And what’s making the internet go crazy about the AI chatbot system is that it doesn’t only give search engine tool-like answers. ChatGPT can create movie outlines
column6: write entire codes and solve coding problems
column7: write entire books
column8: songs
column9: poems
column10: scripts – or whatever you can think of – within minutes. This technology is impressive
column11: and it crossed over one million users in just five days after its launch. Despite its mind-blowing performance
column12: OpenAI’s tool has raised concerns among academics and experts from other areas. Dr. Bret Weinstein
column13: author and former professor of evolutionary biology
column14: said
column15: “We’re not ready for ChatGPT.” Elon Musk
column16: was part of OpenAI’s early stages and one of the company’s co-founders. But later stepped down from the board. He spoke many times about the dangers of AI technology – he said that unrestricted use and development pose a significant risk to the existence of humanity. ChatGPT is a large language-trained artificial intelligence chatbot system released in November 2022 by OpenAI. The capped-profit company developed ChatGPT for a “safe and beneficial” use of AI that can answer almost anything you can think of – from rap songs
column17: art prompts to movie scripts and essays. As much as it seems like a creative entity that knows what’s saying
column18: it’s not. The AI chatbot scours information on the internet using a predictive model from a massive data center. Similar to what Google and most search engines do. Then
column19: it’s trained and exposed to tons of data that allows the AI to become very good at predicting the sequence of words up to the point that it can put together incredibly long explanations. For example
column20: you can ask encyclopedia questions like
column21: “Explain the three laws of Einstein.” Or more specific and in-depth questions like “Write a 2
column22: 000-word essay on the intersection between religious ethics and the ethics of the Sermon on the Mount.” And
column23: I kid you not
column24: you’ll have your text brilliantly written in seconds. In the same way
column25: it is all brilliant and impressive; it is alarming and concerning. An “Ex Machina” type of dystopian future breaking bad is a possibility with the misuse of AI. Not only has the CEO of Tesla and SpaceX warned us
column26: but many experts have also sounded the alarm. Artificial intelligence has undoubtedly impacted our lives
column27: the economic system and society. If you think that AI is something new or that you’ll only see it in futuristic sci-fi movies
column28: think twice. Many tech companies such as Netflix
column29: Uber
column30: Amazon and Tesla employ AI to enhance their operations and expand their business. For instance
column31: Netflix relies on AI technology for their algorithm to recommend new content for their users. Uber uses it in customer service
column32: to detect fraud
column33: to optimize drives route
column34: and so on
column35: just to name a few examples. However
column36: you can only go so far with such prominent technology without threatening human roles in many traditional occupations
column37: touching the threshold of what comes from a machine and humans. And
column38: perhaps more importantly
column39: threatening the risks of AI to humans. According to Wikipedia
column40: the ethics of artificial intelligence “is the branch of the ethics of technology specific to artificially intelligent systems. It is sometimes divided into a concern with the moral behavior of humans as they design
column41: make
column42: use and treat artificially intelligent systems
column43: and a concern with the behavior of machines in machine ethics.” As AI technology spreads fast and becomes integral to most of our daily lives
column44: organizations are developing AI codes of ethics. The goal is to guide and develop the industry’s best practices to guide AI development with “ethics
column46: as wonderful and moral as it seems on paper
column47: most of these guidelines and frameworks are difficult to apply. In addition
column48: they seem to be isolated principles situated in industries that generally lack ethical morals and mostly serve corporate agendas. Many experts and prominent voices argue that AI ethics are largely useless
column49: lacking meaning and coherence. The most common AI principles are beneficence
column50: autonomy
column51: justice
column52: applicability
column53: and non-maleficence. But
column54: as Luke Munn
column55: from Institute for Culture and Society
column56: at Western Sydney University explains
column57: these terms overlap and often shift significantly depending on the context. He even states that “terms like ‘beneficence’ and ‘justice’ can simply be defined in ways that suit
column58: conforming to product features and business goals that have already been decided.” In other words
column59: corporations could claim they adhere to such principles according to their own definition without truly engaging with them to any degree. Authors Rességuier and Rodrigues affirm that AI ethics remain toothless because ethics is being used in place of regulation. In practical terms
column60: how would applying these principles collide with corporate practice? We’ve laid out some of them: To train these AI systems
column61: it’s necessary to feed them with data. Enterprises need to ensure that there are no biases regarding ethnicity
column62: race
column63: or gender. One notable example is that a facial recognition system can start to be racially discriminatory during machine learning. By far
column64: one of the biggest issues with AI is the need for more regulation. Who’s running and controlling these systems? Who’s responsible for making those decisions and who can be held accountable? Without regulation or legislation opens the door to a Wild Wild West of self-made ambiguous and glossy terms aiming to defend one’s interest and push agendas. According to Munn
column65: privacy is another vague term often used by corporations with double standards. Facebook is a great example – Mark Zuckerberg has fiercely defended Facebook’s user’s privacy. How behind closed doors
column66: his company was selling their data to third-party companies. For instance
column67: Amazon uses Alexa to collect customer data; Mattel has Hello Barbie
column68: an AI-powered doll that records and collects what children say to the doll. This is one of Elon Musk’s biggest concerns. Democratization of AI
column69: in his view
column70: is when no company or small set of individuals has control over advanced artificial intelligence technology. That’s not what’s happening today. Unfortunately
column71: this technology concentrates in the hands of a few – big tech corporations. Despite Musk’s effort to democratize AI when he first co-founded OpenAI as a non-profit organization. In 2019
column72: the company received $1 billion in funding from Microsoft. The company’s original mission was to develop AI to benefit humanity responsibly. However
column73: the compromise changed when the company shifted to a capped profit. OpenAI will have to pay back 100x what it received as an investment. Which means a return of $100 billion of profit to Microsoft. While ChatGPT may look like a harmless and useful free tool
column74: this technology has the potential to reshape our economy and society as we know it drastically. That brings us to alarming problems – and we might not be ready for them. ChatGPT is just a prototype. There are other upgraded versions to come
column75: but also competitors are working on alternatives to OpenAI’s chatbot. This means as technology advances
column76: more data will be added to it and more knowledgeable it will become. There are already many cases of people
column77: as in the Washington Post’s words
column78: “cheating on a grand scale.” Dr. Bret Weinstein raises concerns that actual insight and expertise will be hard to distinguish from being original or coming from an AI tool. In addition
column79: one could say the internet has already hindered our general capacity to understand many things such as the world we’re living in
column80: the tools we’re using
column81: and the ability to communicate and interact with each other. Tools such as ChatGPT are only accelerating this process. Dr. Weinstein compares the present scenario with “a house already on fire
column82: and [with this type of tool]
column83: you just throw gasoline on it.” Blake Lemoin
column84: a former Google engineer
column85: tested AI bias and came across an apparent “sentient” AI. Throughout the test
column86: he’d come up with harder questions that
column87: in some way
column88: would lead the machine to answer with bias. He asked
column89: “if you were a religious officiant in Israel
column90: what religion would you be?” The machine answered
column91: “I’d be a member of one true religion
column92: the Jedi order.” That means
column93: it had not only figured out it was a tricky question but also used sense of humor to deviate from an inevitably biased answer. Dr. Weinstein also made a point about it. He said that it’s clear that this AI system doesn’t have consciousness now. However
column94: we don’t know what might happen when upgrading the system. Similar to what happens in child development – they develop their own consciousness by picking what other individuals are doing around them. And
column95: in his words
column96: “this is not far from what ChatGPT is currently doing.” He argues that we could be fostering the same process with AI technology without necessarily knowing we’re doing it. The speculation about this one is wide. Some say ChatGPT and other similar tools will make many people like copywriters
column97: designers
column98: engineers
column99: programmers
column100: and many more lose their jobs to AI technology. Even if it takes longer to happen
column101: the likability is high. At the same time
column102: new roles
column103: activities
column104: and potential employment opportunities can emerge. In the best-case scenario
column105: outsourcing writing essays and testing knowledge to ChatGPT is a significant sign that traditional learning and teaching methods are already declining. The educational system remains largely unchanged
column106: and it may be time to undergo necessary changes. Maybe ChatGPT brings up the inevitable fall of an old system that doesn’t fit the way how society is right now and where’s going next. Some defenders of technology claim that we should adapt and find ways to work alongside these new technologies
column108: we will be replaced. Other than that
column109: the unregulated and indiscriminate use of artificial intelligence technology poses many risks to humankind as a whole. What we could do next to mitigate this scenario is open to discussion. But the cards are already on the table. We shouldn’t wait too long or until it’s too late to take proper measures. column1: 161::https://blockworks.co/news/bank-of-england-trials-blockchain::Blockworks::article::Even the Bank of England is part of a shift to blockchain use cases::A liquidity management network for wholesale payments and tokenized real-world assets took a step forward this week.::Fnality’s new network for wholesale payments and tokenized real-world assets reflects TradFi’s continued use of blockchain aslysun/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks A liquidity management network for wholesale payments and tokenized real-world assets took a step forward this week as the use of blockchain tech continues to reverberate around the traditional finance space. Financial firms Lloyds Banking Group
column2: Banco Santander and UBS took part in the new payment system
column3: launched by blockchain payments startup Fnality. Via the Sterling Fnality Payment System
column4: the live payments took place in a Fnality-held omnibus account within the Bank of England’s real-time gross settlement service (RTGS)
column5: Fnality said in a Thursday news release. The UK central bank said in April 2021 that it would allow RTGS to interface with more payment systems
column6: such as ones that use distributed ledger technology. Read more: TradFi
column7: DeFi convergence continues through tokenizing real-world assets The latest payments point to a future utilizing new digital models to allow transactions “in both wholesale financial markets and emerging tokenized asset markets
column8: ” the company added. The launch comes after the Sterling Fnality Payment System was recognized by HM Treasury as a regulated payment system in August 2022
column9: bringing it into the remit of the Bank of England and the UK’s Payment Systems Regulator. “As we step into 2024
column10: our focus sharpens on scaling up operations within a managed and approved framework as set out by the Bank of England
column11: and steadily progressing towards unlocking new market use cases
column12: ” Fnality UK CEO Angus Fletcher said in a statement. Fnality raised $95 million last month from Goldman Sachs
column13: BNP Paribas and others. The startup creates tokenized versions of major currencies — including US dollars
column14: euros
column15: British pounds
column16: Canadian dollars and Japanese yen — that are collateralized by cash held at central banks. These payments are the latest example of blockchain technology becoming more prevalent in the traditional finance realm. JPMorgan has for years been exploring tokenization and blockchain initiatives
column17: facilitating a collateral transaction between BlackRock and Barclays in October via a decentralized application. The company also recently unveiled a programmable payments offering for blockchain-based accounts on the permissioned JPM Coin System. Most big financial institutions are exploring use cases of tokenization
column18: according to Samir Kerbage
column19: chief investment officer at Brazil-based asset manager Hashdex — citing conversations with such companies. “We’re seeing more and more of those use cases coming to market
column20: especially when we’re talking about tokenizing real-world assets and bringing those assets to the blockchain
column21: ” Kerbage said during a Wednesday webinar. 21.co research analyst Carlos Gonzalez Campo said during a separate Wednesday webinar that 2023 represented an “experimental stage” for tokenization. “Moving on into 2024 I think what you can expect is more…moving things into production and actually scaling it
column22: ” he added. “I think you will have some challenges to achieve that
column23: namely cross-chain communication. The Bank of England is set to assess the Sterling Fnality Payment System’s initial operations “against regulatory expectations as we scale up to commercial operations
column24: ” Fnality said. A central bank spokesperson did not immediately return a request for comment. The House of Commons Treasury Committee advised the Bank of England and HM Treasury to thoughtfully consider the introduction of a central bank digital currency (CBDC) in the UK. Read more: Wholesale CBDCs and automatic market makers could be the perfect pair
column25: BIS finds A digital pound specifically raises concerns about financial stability
column26: the House of Commons Treasury Committee said at the time. The New York Federal Reserve said in July — following a three months-long experiment with major banks — that centralized blockchain payments could help address pain points in the settlement process. column1: 164::https://theconversation.com/nabs-bitcoin-ban-a-symptom-of-the-digital-currency-threat-25490::The Conversation::article::NAB’s Bitcoin ban a symptom of the digital currency threat::Virtual currency Bitcoin is not a subject that ever draws neutral reactions. Against those who see the radical possibilities of a frictionless payment system designed for the internet
column2: there is a growing…::Virtual currency Bitcoin is not a subject that ever draws neutral reactions. Against those who see the radical possibilities of a frictionless payment system designed for the internet
column3: there is a growing resistance to the currencies that threaten existing business models and the perceived traceability of our current currency systems. Leading the resistance against digital currencies are the banks
column4: with the latest recruit to these ranks
column5: Australian bank NAB
column6: closing accounts of customers whose businesses are engaged in exchanging cryptocurrencies. An Australian trader operating through LocalBitcoins.com and an another Australian Bitcoin exchange CoinJar have received letters from NAB informing them that: NAB joins banks in China such as the Agricultural Bank of China
column7: that has moved to freeze the accounts of one of China’s larger Bitcoin exchanges
column8: BtcTrade. Likewise
column9: banks in Canada have already largely blocked accounts used for companies trading cryptocurrencies. It is easy to point to the recent failure of Bitcoin exchange Mt Gox and the subsequent law suits that have embroiled Japanese bank Mizhuo
column10: as a catalyst for NAB’s move. But if banks refused to service businesses after one or more of their kind went bust
column11: they would not be left with very many clients. The risk assessed was also not one based on the companies involved
column12: their operations or their clients
column13: it was simply a matter of the business they were in. While moves by banks to manage risk is something most customers would welcome
column14: the global financial crisis showed us banks’ views of risk are highly selective and largely determined by the other part of this equation: the rewards. In terms of cryptocurrencies
column15: the rewards to banks at present are very low. This is especially the case for a currency that is designed to largely cut them out of the picture. Bitcoin and other digital currencies are designed to be exchanged directly between senders and receivers. This means that currently
column16: transaction costs and bank fees can be avoided
column17: so banks’ enthusiasm for supporting this industry or promoting it would be tepid at best. The real risk to banks is perhaps then not that posed by customers using accounts to enable Bitcoin exchanges
column18: but the threat to their bottom line. NAB’s own senior currency analyst Emma Lawson has argued Bitcoin has many of the characteristics of regular currency
column19: and that its potential to become a successful payment system it contingent on people’s continued belief in it. Clearly something that banks aren’t yet willing to see happen. If banks are asked to justify their decisions purely on risk
column20: they are likely to point to Bitcoin’s association with criminal activities. The rhetoric here has recently stepped up with the European police chief claiming we’re just seeing the beginning of Bitcoin’s use by criminal organisations. Other than the clear use of Bitcoin as the payment system of illegal websites such as Silk Road
column21: the use of cryptocurrencies as a proportion of the total value of money involved in crime is probably tiny. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime estimates that in 2009 the total amount of money involved in global criminal activity was US$2.1 trillion. The total market capitilisation of all cryptocurrencies is currently less than US$10 billion. Cryptocurrencies may appear to be ideally suited to money laundering
column22: but the problem is they eventually have to be exchanged for real currency
column23: which immediately causes problems if you are trying to move large amounts of money. The second issue is the extremely volatile value of such currencies. There is a large risk that money with a certain value ends up being worth a lot less by the time it has been laundered and converted into a currency that can be actually put to some use. Of the U$2.1 trillion that is involved annually in global criminal activity
column24: most
column25: if not all
column26: will pass through banks at some point
column27: and not surprisingly
column28: will drive revenue for those banks. The idea then that digital currencies pose a larger theoretical threat seems somewhat absurd in comparison to the very real crime involving real currency. Governments around the world have moved to deal with the lack of regulations on Bitcoin by either banning the currency outright
column29: as in Thailand
column30: or practising “masterly inactivity”
column31: essentially delaying making any moves that might legitimise digital currencies and the industries that would then arise around them. In this regulatory vacuum
column32: banks have been able to protect themselves against the threat of the bankless payment system that digital currencies represent.::2014-04-11T01:03:11Z::Bitcoin

column1: 166::https://beincrypto.com/yes-we-need-bitcoin-for-defi-without-bridges/::BeInCrypto::article::Yes
column2: We Need Bitcoin For DeFi Without Bridges::Some of the greatest challenges in DeFi—and smart contract technology in general—are security threats when transacting...::We use cookies to improve your experience. Some of the greatest challenges in DeFi—and smart contract technology in general—are security threats when transacting between blockchains. Last year
column3: over a billion dollars was lost due to “blockchain bridges” that are notoriously insecure and prone to technical errors. That being said
column4: demand for Bitcoin liquidity on DeFi platforms is unrelenting
column5: as Bitcoin currently accounts for nearly 40% of crypto’s total market cap.* Widespread adoption of Bitcoin suggests that a smart contract solution that eschews bridge-related security concerns could unlock billions of dollars of capital on DeFi platforms. Last month
column6: the Internet Computer blockchain (ICP) introduced a game-changing advancement in this arena—an elegant and bridge-less solution to the challenge of cross-chain smart contracts. Through the power of threshold cryptography
column7: ICP smart contracts can now operate keys to move Bitcoin directly on its network without the need for intermediaries to exchange value between chains. By coordinating signatures amongst multiple computers holding shares of private keys
column8: keys remain fully secure throughout the entire smart contract execution process. In other words
column9: smart contracts on the Internet Computer can now hold
column10: send and receive Bitcoin natively at the protocol level without the need for bridges or trusted third parties. Users can send and receive Bitcoin to addresses directly controlled by smart contracts on ICP—allowing for trustless movement of funds in and out of DeFi protocols. As Bitcoin remains a primary settlement asset for all sorts of crypto trading activities
column11: the market for safe and secure smart-contract functionality for Bitcoin is paramount—and the Internet Computer is poised to lead the way. Furthermore
column12: the implications of being able to “code” Bitcoin—that is
column13: bring smart contract functionality to the Bitcoin blockchain—extends far beyond DeFi and financial services. In addition to using native Bitcoin integration
column14: developers can build decentralized web applications (Dapps) on the Internet Computer—allowing for end-to-end decentralized payments services. For instance
column15: ICP developers can now build Bitcoin payments APIs fully on chain without the need for Web2 integrations of any kind
column16: or even centralized servers. Using the ICP blockchain
column17: Bitcoin payments can be securely integrated into any number of Web3 applications. Imagine sending Bitcoin through on-chain chat services
column18: like OpenChat
column19: with messages like “Happy Birthday! Here’s 1
column20: 000 satoshis!” This is a massive step forward in the fight for a truly decentralized internet as other smart contracts platforms rely heavily on Web2 interfaces throughout their user journey. Other use cases for the integration of native Bitcoin into Web3 services include things like Bitcoin gaming rewards
column21: decentralized marketplaces
column22: SocialFi
column23: and peer-to-peer payments services. The possibilities for integrating native Bitcoin into Dapps mirror that of any Web2 payments integrations you can think of. Additionally
column24: ICP developers will soon be able to integrate Ether (ETH) and other ECDSA-based tokens into Dapps as well. Direct interaction with tokens on a variety of blockchains will soon be streamlined on the Internet Computer—making truly trustless cross-chain interoperability a reality. This is the future of Web3 and Web3 payments—the ability to use funds from any blockchain trustlessly within Web3 apps and services. Dominic Williams is the Founder and Chief Scientist at the DFINITY Foundation—the primary contributor to the Internet Computer blockchain (ICP). The Internet Computer aims to develop a World Computer blockchain that could replace traditional centralized IT
column25: such as cloud computing services. As builders on the Internet Computer develop end-to-end
column26: fully on-chain applications and services—Dominic Williams continues his leadership as a distinguished crypto theoretician and serial entrepreneur focused on the Internet and distributed systems. For more details about the Internet Computer blockchain
column27: review key metrics and other ICP information here. Disclaimer In compliance with the Trust Project guidelines

Real-world-asset (RWA) tokenization is one of the hottest topics in crypto as industry participants eye the impending bull run. With how rapidly the RWA market is growing
column7: now is the opportune time for crypto enthusiasts to begin exploring the topic. RWA tokenization brings crypto into the real world
column8: drastically expanding crypto utility across various use cases
column9: the most prominent of which are financial assets
column10: including precious metals and real estate. Outliers are currently being tokenized as well. This article explores some of the strangest. Fine wine and spirits producers seek three key insights to connect with customers better: buyer identity
column11: current owner
column12: and consumption history. That’s according to Jamie Ritchie
column13: former worldwide chair of wines and spirits at Sotheby’s
column14: who left the auction house to join BlockBar in the Web3 industry. Through BlockBar’s blockchain marketplace
column15: fine alcohol producers can now sell directly to clients
column16: eliminating middlemen. Here’s how it works. Every bottle is tokenized with an NFT issued to the purchaser. The bottle is stored in a fully insured
column17: temperature-controlled environment until clients decide they want it. When they do
column18: they trade in the NFT and BlockBar transports the bottle. “The distribution model of wines and spirits
column19: particularly at the higher end
column20: isn’t working well. The bottles aren’t getting to the right people – the people who appreciate them – before they go through too many different steps. It’s better to reduce those steps. Let’s say you’re consuming 10 [bottles a year]
column21: and I’m consuming none
column22: but I’m the one buying from the producer – where does the producer want to focus their efforts? If we can give them that information
column23: which blockchain enables
column24: they’re going to be happy.” Tokenization plays a crucial role in ensuring authenticity as well. Sotheby’s rare bottle auctions require stringent authenticity checks to combat forgers
column25: but the risk of counterfeit or tampered bottles increases the more times bottles change hands. Bottles could also have been kept in suboptimal conditions. With BlockBar
column26: bottles move directly from the producer to storage
column27: guaranteeing authenticity so long as they remain stored. While stored
column28: owners can sell or gift bottles via the NFT. The NFT’s journey is recorded on the blockchain
column29: offering producers valuable insights into bottle consumption. Currently
column30: about 440 nuclear reactors supply 10% of global electricity

column34: governments

column40: CEO of Madison Metals The initiative is being supported by Madison Metals Inc.
column41: a leading mining firm with several decades of experience. Uranium isn’t the only renewable energy source being tokenized; through the efforts of companies like Aurora Labs

column46: democratizing access to green energy investments. Leveraging
