column1: 169::https://cryptobriefing.com/crypto-market-unlocks-analysis/::Crypto Briefing::article::20% of top 300 cryptos have majority of their supply locked: CoinGecko::New cryptos face market impact from upcoming token unlocks.::Join the hunt for $12
column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article One out of five cryptos in the Top 300 by market cap has the majority of their supply locked
column4: according to a report by CoinGecko. The report calls these assets “low float”
column5: as they show a market cap to fully diluted valuation (FDV) ratio below 0.5. The four cryptos with the lowest floats among these large caps are Worldcoin (WLD)
column6: with a market cap to FDV ratio of 0.02
column7: Cheelee (CHEEL) at 0.06
column8: Starknet (STRK) at 0.07
column9: and Saga (SAGA) at 0.09. Notably
column10: all four were launched within the last two years. The majority of low float large-cap cryptos are recent market entrants
column11: with 54 out of 64 having been launched since 2021. The impending token unlocks are expected to exert additional pressure on the crypto market as these projects release more tokens into circulation. Conversely
column12: only 74 of the top 300 cryptos have reached a market cap to FDV ratio of 1
column13: meaning they are fully diluted with no further tokens to be unlocked. Less than half of these fully diluted cryptos were launched in the past four years
column14: with the majority having been introduced between 2014 and 2020. Interestingly
column15: meme coins such as Pepe (PEPE) and dogwifhat (WIF)
column16: comprise 14 of the 74 fully diluted cryptos and represent a significant portion of those launched in 2023 and 2024. This trend underscores the growing narrative of meme coins in the crypto market. High float cryptos
column17: which have already unlocked more than half of their token supply
column18: account for 162 of the top 300
column19: or 54%. Among these
column20: 28.7% are nearly fully diluted

column1: 170::https://theconversation.com/japan-the-yen-plunges-to-34-year-low-despite-interest-rate-hike-221478::The Conversation::article::Japan: the yen plunges to 34-year low despite interest rate hike::Raising interest rates can’t stop Japan’s currency from sinking to a record low.::The Bank of Japan (BoJ) raised interest rates for the first time in 17 years on March 19
column2: bringing an era of negative interest rates to an end. The key rate was hiked from –0.1% to a band from zero to 0.1% – a token effort to offer some tightening after decades of loose but unsuccessful monetary policy. Despite the adjustment
column3: Japan remains the major economy with the lowest interest rates in the world. In my opinion
column4: the move is not designed to end Japan’s monetary policy dilemma; instead
column5: it confirms the central bank’s role in supporting the US dollar. Negative rates were ostensibly adopted to stimulate the economy
column6: based on the idea that lower interest rates lead to higher growth. But the negative rates were never a stimulus to the economy. They served as a tax on the reserves held by commercial banks at the central bank. Under negative rates
column7: banks had to pay the central bank
column8: squeezing their profit margins as soon as the rates were imposed (in 2016 in Japan). Since banks in Japan never extended negative rates to deposits made by bank customers
column9: they passed this penalty onto borrowers. This was relatively easy to do as small Japanese firms have been desperate for more bank loans for 30 years. As a result
column10: lowering rates into negative territory actually raised borrowing rates for loan customers. Due to the squeeze on bank profits
column11: the years of zero and negative rates (the BoJ had already reduced interest rates to 0.001% in the 1990s) have also forced thousands of small banks in Japan (likewise in Europe) to merge with bigger banks. Central planners love the idea of a concentrated banking system with a few big banks. But it is small firms and the middle class that get crushed. Research has found that bigger banks lend less to small firms
column12: thus economies are most vibrant when they boast many small banks. Bank lending provides the fuel for economic growth. So the BoJ’s low and negative interest rate policies have harmed the Japanese economy by suppressing bank credit growth for decades. Is the small rise in interest rates a step in the right direction? Barely. Zero rates are still bad for the economy. Rates should have been raised much more and much earlier. But the BoJ is not interested in supporting the domestic economy and national interests
column13: nor even explicit government policy. Consider the exchange rate. It is often thought that the low rates have contributed to a weak yen
column14: since investors could earn higher interest by investing in other currencies. But the yen has fallen in value since the rate rise was announced. Before interest rates were raised
column15: the yen stood at ¥149 to the US dollar. One week later
column16: it had slipped to ¥151 to the dollar. And on April 15
column17: the yen fell past ¥154 per dollar – its weakest in 34 years. Forecasters have predicted that the yen would bounce back given the prowess of Japanese manufacturing. They are also aware of the hawkish rhetoric of the Japanese Ministry of Finance
column18: which is legally in charge of official currency intervention and deploys this to stop yen weakness. However
column19: the BoJ is independent and has a long history of sabotaging the plans of the Ministry of Finance. The BoJ usually sterilises any intervention ordered by the Finance Ministry to pursue the opposite goal. It has
column20: for instance
column21: aimed to prolong the recession in order to force through structural change. The sterilisation is why the yen has weakened further since the recent policy announcement
column22: and so far there is no change in sight. The BoJ has been expanding credit creation faster than the US Federal Reserve. Faster money printing in Japan will weaken the value of the yen against the US dollar. These factors are more important than interest rates
column23: which tend to simply follow the economy. The US dollar had been threatened by the Fed’s extraordinary monetary policy of March 2020
column24: when it implemented the Blackrock plan. This was the plan proposed by American asset management firm Blackrock in 2019 to create inflation via a version of quantitative easing. This plan was actually based on a proposal of “quantitative easing” that I had developed in Japan 30 years ago to help the country stage a swift recovery from its incipient banking crisis. It was a policy designed for deflationary economies with shrinking bank credit
column25: namely for the central bank to purchase assets from the non-bank sector. However
column26: bank credit growth in 2020 was already more than 5% in the US when the Fed added fuel to the fire and doubled bank credit growth to 11%. That’s why I had been forecasting in 2020 that we would see significant inflation 18 months later
column27: which is what happened in those countries that followed the Fed’s money printing. Read more: Why central banks are too powerful and have created our inflation crisis – by the banking expert who pioneered quantitative easing Since then
column28: the BoJ has been given the job of propping up the US dollar. In an era when the Brics countries (Brazil
column29: Russia
column30: India
column31: China and South Africa) are challenging the dominance of the dollar and even Saudi Arabia is selling oil against the Chinese currency
column32: the US has enlisted its allies to support the dollar. The BoJ continues to expand credit creation faster than the Fed
column33: and while that happens
column34: the yen will stay weak no matter what the Ministry of Finance says or does. As Henry Kissinger said in 1972 with reference to South Vietnam: “It is bad to be America’s enemy. It’s fatal to be its ally.”::2024-04-16T15:43:16Z::Bank loans

column1: 172::https://beincrypto.com/decentralizing-social-media-can-web3-empower-users/::BeInCrypto::article::Decentralizing Social Media: Can Web3 Empower Users?::Decentralizing social media has the potential to revolutionize the industry by empowering users and promoting free speech
column2: but it also comes with its own set of challenges. The rise of social media has completely transformed how we communicate and interact online
column3: with over five billion daily active users worldwide. However
column4: centralized social media platforms have … Continued::We use cookies to improve your experience. Decentralizing social media has the potential to revolutionize the industry by empowering users and promoting free speech
column5: but it also comes with its own set of challenges. The rise of social media has completely transformed how we communicate and interact online
column6: with over five billion daily active users worldwide. However
column7: centralized social media platforms have been criticized for handling user data despite their success
column8: as evidenced by the Cambridge Analytica scandal. In recent years
column9: decentralizing social media has gained significant momentum as a potential solution to the centralization
column10: censorship
column11: and data handling issues plaguing social media platforms. Decentralization has the potential to empower users by giving them greater control over their data and privacy. By allowing users to own their data
column12: decentralization can offer a viable solution to the growing demand for privacy and data protection. Additionally
column13: decentralization can prevent power concentration in a few entities’ hands
column14: promoting free speech and reducing censorship. Decentralized social media platforms are a critical component of the future vision of Web3. Currently
column15: social media users spend an average of 2.5 hours per day scrolling through content without receiving any compensation. However
column16: by tokenizing content and marking ownership
column17: Web3 can create an economy that benefits all ecosystem participants and distributes wealth across industry participants. However
column18: decentralization also has its drawbacks. The biggest concern is the potential for misinformation to spread more easily without a centralized entity to regulate content. Additionally
column19: decentralization can lead to further fragmentation and isolation of communities
column20: with limited exposure to diverse perspectives. Ultimately
column21: the debate around whether Web3 can truly empower users or whether stricter regulations are necessary to prevent the spread of harmful content is ongoing. Recently
column22: Elon Musk highlighted that Twitter could be run with just a handful of team members while easing censorship and eliminating most manual content approvals. Still
column23: even with centralization
column24: social media’s role in the spread of fake news has been significant
column25: and measures to address this issue will continue to evolve. In conclusion
column26: the application of blockchain technology and decentralization is a crucial conversation about the future of social media. While it can potentially transform how we interact online
column27: decentralization comes with its own challenges. Regardless
column28: Web3 will revolutionize the industry
column29: and social media will be one of the most significant beneficiaries. (L-R) Vugar Adigozalov – Chief Marketing Officer

column1: 173::https://blockworks.co/news/obligate-blockchain-bonds-base::Blockworks::article::Protocol Obligate ramps up push to boost institutional blockchain use::On-chain debt capital markets platform deploys on Coinbase-incubated layer-2 after structured investment products push.::On-chain debt capital markets platform deploys on Coinbase-incubated layer-2 after structured investment products push Obligate and Adobe modified by Blockworks On-chain debt capital markets platform Obligate has launched on Coinbase’s layer-2 network. This new deployment aligns with the protocol’s strategy to increase institutional engagement with blockchain-native assets. It comes just after the Switzerland-based firm made its initial entry into on-chain investment products; a decision that aligns with a larger trend across the industry. Obligate lets companies issue on-chain bonds and other debt securities to receive funding from investors. These bonds
column2: initially issued via smart contracts on Polygon
column3: have now expanded to another venue. The deployment on Base — a Coinbase-incubated layer-2 built on the Optimism stack and launched in July — “represents a paradigm shift in the integration of blockchain technology into institutional finance
column4: ” according to Matthias Wyss
column5: Obligate’s head of strategic partnerships. Read more: The ‘crypto degen crowd’ has settled in on Coinbase layer-2
column6: Base “Our capabilities are especially relevant in the current macro environment as they allow small- and medium-sized enterprises cheap and efficient access to debt capital
column7: which is crucial in the rising interest rate environment
column8: ” Wyss told Blockworks. Obligate issued its first bond on the Polygon blockchain in March. Investors in the protocol include Blockchange Ventures
column9: Circle Ventures
column10: Earlybird and SIX Fintech Ventures. Investors fund their orders into escrow before capital and bonds are exchanged
column11: according to the company’s site. From issuance to maturity
column12: investors hold ERC20 bond tokens in their wallets and — unless transfer limitations are set by the issuers — can move or sell them to other wallets. Users receive payment redemption tokens at maturity
column13: at which time the investors can burn their tokens for the final payments. Issuers can also secure their bonds with collateral
column14: leading to the liquidation of that collateral in the case of default. The deployment to Base comes a couple weeks after STS Digital issued a structured investment product — a barrier reverse convertible linked to bitcoin — on Polygon as an Obligate eNote. Obligate said in a Nov. 15 blog post that it intends to build “an extensive product suite alongside a broad spectrum of digital asset services” — including products with “bespoke payoff profiles.” Moving real-world assets onto the blockchain via tokenization has gained steam in recent months as financial players and investors seek to boost efficiency and lower costs. Read more: BlackRock CEO touts tokenization
column15: warns US ‘lagging’ in innovation Various projects have sought to offer on-chain access to US Treasury securities
column16: for example — the largest and most liquid government bond market globally. Traditional finance giants
column17: such as JPMorgan
column18: continue exploring ways to use blockchain technology. The company most recently carried out tests designed to let fund managers tokenize their portfolios on chosen blockchains. Wyss said all institutional blockchain applications reaffirm the path to a future where all capital market transactions are issued and settled on-chain. “We already see an expansion of blockchain native assets along the risk curve from payment to debt to equity and
column19: as pioneered by Obligate recently
column20: to structured investment products
column21: ” he added. “This will continue to grow with the…institutional adoption of Tier1 [traditional finance] players.” Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column3: developed by the Hong Kong […]::China has taken a step forward in its journey
column4: towards the yuan by connecting its Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) platform with Hong Kongs Fast Payment System (FPS). This integration aims to improve the speed of border digital yuan transactions and enhance its compatibility with global payment systems. The FPS
column5: developed by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) serves as a communication channel between banks. It provides users with a way to make person to person transfers engage in online shopping and top up their e wallets making transactions easier and faster. According to reports from the Peoples Daily this achievement was made possible through collaboration between HKMA and Chinas banks Digital Currency Research division
column6: known as the People’s Bank of China (PBoC). With this arrangement travelers from Hong Kong can effortlessly add funds to their yuan wallets using ICBC (Asia) Bank of China (Hong Kong) Hang Seng Bank and HSBC HK dollar and yuan accounts. Enough this system was launched in time
column7: for the Asian Games benefiting Hong Kong athletes who have already started taking advantage of it.The athletes were impressed
column8: with how user friendly and efficient the digital yuan wallets were. They found it easy to recharge using the FPS
column9: which made their time in the athletes village convenient for spending. Moreover the media praised the e CNY FPS platform for its advantages its ability to shorten transaction chains and lower costs. column1: 175::https://cryptobriefing.com/blockchain-referendum-app-disputes-putin-inauguration/::Crypto Briefing::article::Russian opposition activist launches zero-knowledge voting app to challenge Putin's inauguration::Former Pussy Riot lawyer uses blockchain referendum app to enable anonymous dissent against Putin inauguration.::Join the hunt for $12
column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Russian opposition activist and former Pussy Riot lawyer Mark Feygin has launched a referendum on the zero-knowledge voting app Russia2024
column4: challenging the legitimacy of the recent Russian elections and Vladimir Putin’s inauguration as president. The vote
column5: which went live on May 10th
column6: three days after Putin’s inauguration
column7: is the first protest vote on the app following months of audits and stress tests. Russia2024 was built using Rarimo’s Freedom Tool
column8: an open-source
column9: surveillance-free voting solution that leverages blockchain and zero-knowledge cryptography to ensure citizens can poll
column10: vote
column11: and protest without being tracked. The app was first announced in a broadcast on March 9
column12: 2024. Following the announcement
column13: the Kremlin attempted to obstruct the app by filing against it
column14: temporarily removing it from the Apple store
column15: and sponsoring negative reviews
column16: a strategy exposed by a whistleblower who expressed support for the app. “Dissent in Russia is growing more risky and public opinion harder to track. It is critical that we provide reliable
column17: surveillance-proof avenues for protest and polling. Russia2024 and its underlying technology has enabled that
column18: ” Feygin said in a press release shared with Crypto Briefing. The app was developed by Kyiv-based Rarilabs
column19: with key contributions from activist developers working anonymously inside regimes around the world. Rarilabs is a privacy-first social protocol backed by Pantera Capital. In 2022
column20: the company raised $10 million at a $100 million valuation for its Series A funding round. According to the project’s whitepaper
column21: the app uses Russia’s machine-readable passport information submitted by a user. The data is then decrypted and verified locally (on a device). Digital identity
column22: once authenticated
column23: is resolved using a generated keypair
column24: which is then used to interact with the app’s smart contract. The image below illustrates how the app works. Zero-knowledge cryptography severs the link between the pass and passport data
column25: and votes are published directly on Arbitrum
column26: an Ethereum L2
column27: where the data then becomes tamper-proof. “Freedom Tool was built to help give a voice to people living in regimes. Its implementation in Russia is an early example of how blockchain and zero-knowledge cryptography can meet the urgent need around the world for privacy technology
column28: ” said Lasha Antadze
column29: co-founder of Rarilabs. Antadze previously worked on the Ukrainian government’s e-identity and digitalization reform
column30: as well as the EU’s Stork 2.0 digital signature standardization. Share this article The information on or accessed through this website is obtained from independent sources we believe to be accurate and reliable

column1: 176::https://theconversation.com/ftx-and-binance-how-latest-crypto-scandals-could-influence-public-opinion-on-digital-currency-regulation-218939::The Conversation::article::FTX and Binance: how latest crypto scandals could influence public opinion on digital currency regulation::The general public may want tighter crypto regulations but is the UK government listening?::True believers in cryptocurrency have had a rough few weeks. The US government just fined Binance – the world’s largest crypto exchange – US$4.3 billion (£3.4 billion) for its involvement in money laundering. It forced the firm to accept intrusive monitoring and demanded that its secretive boss
column2: Changpeng Zhao
column3: step down and pay a personal fine of $50 million. Zhao
column4: known as CZ
column5: has been called the most powerful man in crypto. The industry is still reeling from the conviction of Zhao’s bitter rival
column6: Sam Bankman-Fried
column7: earlier in November on seven counts of fraud and conspiracy. His company FTX – previously the second-largest crypto exchange in the world – collapsed in November 2022. SBF
column8: as he is commonly known
column9: could theoretically face more than 100 years in jail when he is sentenced in March 2024. Several other former leading crypto executives are also under investigation or being prosecuted. Crypto has just squared off against the US state
column10: and at halftime the result is state power 2 – crypto 0. After this display of muscular regulation on one side of the Atlantic
column11: what is the future of crypto regulation in the UK? The UK government has repeatedly vaunted its ambition to make the UK a global crypto hub. The new minister for the City of London
column12: Bim Afolami
column13: doubled down on this message shortly after taking up his post
column14: warning regulators against going overboard. Speaking at a Financial Times event on global banking
column15: he said: “If you’re regulating a market
column16: in any area
column17: there’s no point in having the safest graveyard”. And then added: “It’s really important that we don’t tar every crypto business as being like FTX or Binance.” This attitude could put Afolami and the government on a collision course with UK regulator the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). Former FCA chair Charles Randell recently criticised the government’s plans for treating crypto like any other financial investment
column18: saying they risked normalising crypto even though fraud “is a feature
column19: not a bug” of much of the sector. Read more: What Binance's US lawsuit says about the future for cryptocurrency regulation The government would say that its view is the democratically legitimate one – no one has elected the FCA. But research shows British people may respond to revelations of wrongdoing in the sector by wanting to regulate crypto more severely. Through the Banklash research project
column20: my colleagues and I have studied what happens to public opinion about financial regulation when people are exposed to news about financial scandals
column21: such as the payment protection insurance scandal in the UK. We found that in multiple countries
column22: the public has clear views about financial regulation
column23: and that when they read about scandals
column24: their demand for regulatory stringency increases. Such changes in public opinion are not simply abstract experimental effects. In a separate article
column25: Harvard professor Taeku Lee and I have shown how a US Congress investigation of Goldman Sachs’ role in the global financial crisis drew public attention to malfeasance by big banks and the position of political parties on it. In the wake of this explosion of publicity
column26: Republicans dropped their filibuster of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
column27: which was the biggest reform of US financial regulation since the 1930s. Two years after the financial crisis
column28: defending the unpopular big banks was not a hill the Republicans wanted to die on. Read more: Crypto: what could more regulation mean for the future of digital currencies? We have followed up this research with a study this year of British attitudes towards cryptocurrency. Our new work
column29: which has not yet been published in an academic journal
column30: suggests that the FCA is more in tune with British public opinion than the government. Among the four countries we surveyed in March 2023 – with responses from more than 36
column31: 000 people – British respondents expressed the highest level of support for crypto regulation. Americans want the least
column32: while France and Germany fall in the middle. As part of the same study
column33: we also investigated how consuming media coverage of the FTX scandal affected those attitudes. Reading about the scandal caused a significant increase in the appetite to regulate crypto among Brits
column34: starting from an already high base. This is the same effect we found in other areas of financial regulation in our earlier research. It seems reasonable to expect that the recent demonstrations of malfeasance by CZ and SBF will lead to a toughening of public attitudes about the regulation of crypto. Despite the fact that cryptocurrency is perceived as an esoteric topic
column35: people have views about it. UK politicians would be well-advised to take these views into account when trying to balance demands for regulatory stringency and the economic defence of London’s status as an international financial hub. The US government has flexed its regulatory muscles without concern for damaging the appeal of its crypto market
column36: although of course that market is much larger. Political leaders in the UK should not deceive themselves that the general public doesn’t understand these issues. There will be an election next year. And as Bankman-Fried and Zhao have discovered
column37: you can fool some of the people some of the time
column38: but you can’t fool all the people all the time. Even on a subject as apparently baffling as crypto.::2023-12-01T12:14:48Z::Big banks

column1: 177::https://www.coindesk.com/opinion/2024/05/16/crypto-custody-for-advisors/::CoinDesk::article::Crypto Custody for Advisors::Financial advisors seeking to navigate the crypto custody landscape must understand the full spectrum of crypto custody options
column2: balancing innovation with risk management to optimize client portfolios. Crypto Custody for Financial Advisors Ask an Expert Keep Reading::Crypto custody can be a challenging topic
column3: as there are many options investors and advisors face when considering the storage
column4: security and accessibility of digital assets. In today's main article
column5: Todd Bendell
column6: from Amphibian Capital
column7: discusses the different custody options financial advisors need to know. Meredith Yarbrough from LaHoja Capital Partners answers questions about bitcoin custody and collateral in today’s Ask an Expert. –S.M. You’re reading Crypto for Advisors
column8: CoinDesk’s weekly newsletter that unpacks digital assets for financial advisors. Subscribe here to get it every Thursday. In the dynamic world of cryptocurrency
column9: strategic foresight is a necessity. Financial advisors seeking to navigate this volatile landscape must understand the full spectrum of crypto custody options
column10: balancing innovation with risk management to optimize client portfolios. Self-Custody: The Ultimate Control Opting for self-custody equates to holding the reins of responsibility. This approach involves securing private keys through cold storage – hardware wallets isolated from online threats. It’s a fortress of solitude for crypto
column11: offering maximum security but requiring technical acumen. For the savvy investor or the privacy-centric individual
column12: self-custody is best suited for those prioritizing absolute control over their digital assets. On-Exchange Custody: Convenience with a Catch The convenience of on-exchange custody cannot be overstated. Cryptocurrencies remain readily accessible
column13: facilitating swift transactions. However
column14: this method is not without its pitfalls—security is only as robust as the platform’s weakest link. Here lies a paradox: the more convenient the access
column15: the greater the vulnerability. The collapse of FTX highlighted the potential vulnerabilities and the importance of selecting platforms with strong
column16: transparent security practices and regulatory compliance. Advisors must thus choose platforms with military-grade security protocols
column17: yet even the most fortified castles have fallen. Off-Exchange Solutions: Institutional Assurance For those managing substantial assets
column18: off-exchange custody solutions represent a strategic chess move. This type of arrangement can include additional verification layers by involving a third party in the authorization of transactions
column19: aligning with the stringent demands of institutional investors. It represents a strategic blend of old-world banking safety and new-tech efficiency. Investing in Crypto Quant Funds Venturing into crypto quant funds offers a compelling narrative. These funds utilize algorithms for high-frequency trading and other market-neutral strategies
column20: potentially reducing risks through diversification and sophisticated strategies. This method can allow for diversified
column21: long-term exposure to flagship cryptocurrencies while minimizing the typical complexities and risks associated with direct crypto asset management and custody. Navigating the Regulatory Landscape Advisors must also master the complexities of regulatory frameworks governing digital assets. The landscape is as politically nuanced as it is technologically advanced
column22: requiring a judicious balance of compliance and strategic innovation. Concluding Thoughts In summary
column23: integrating cryptocurrencies into investment portfolios requires a confluence of knowledge
column24: strategic acumen and a keen understanding of risk. The paths of self-custody
column25: on-exchange custody
column26: and innovative off-exchange solutions offer diverse strategies that cater to different needs. Whether directly holding assets or investing in algorithmically driven funds
column27: the key lies in leveraging these tools to achieve superior outcomes

column31: Amphibian Capital Q. What do credit fund managers look for when choosing a custodian for bitcoin collateral assets? Credit fund managers prioritize minimizing business risk when selecting a custodian for bitcoin collateral. Since bitcoin collateral is typically held for the duration of the loan
column32: custodians are evaluated for their long-term viability
column33: including their audit practices and business continuity plans. Safety is also a key concern; managers assess both general safety policies and specific procedures tailored to bitcoin
column34: along with any additional services the custodian might offer. The biggest challenge in choosing a custodian is lack of standardization as many institutions retrofits traditional frameworks to include bitcoin programs. Q. How does custody of bitcoin collateral differ from traditional asset custody? While there are shared concerns like cybersecurity risks across both traditional and digital assets
column35: bitcoin custody carries unique challenges. For example
column36: the cyber risks associated with digital assets can potentially translate into physical risks through the unauthorized access to keys. Competent bitcoin custodians mitigate this risk by implementing robust key ceremony procedures
column37: where the keys controlling the assets are distributed across multiple geographic locations with strict protocols governing their access and use. Q. Is it possible to insure bitcoin assets? Obtaining insurance for bitcoin assets is possible
column38: though not commonly practiced among credit managers handling bitcoin collateral
column39: similar to the lack of standard insurance policies for traditional financial assets. Instead
column40: managers rely heavily on stringent security protocols and existing regulatory frameworks to protect these assets. - Meredith Yarbrough

column1: 178::https://beincrypto.com/saving-planet-profit-carbon-credits-bitcoin/::BeInCrypto::article::Saving the Planet And Making a Profit: Carbon Credits Are the New Bitcoin::Web3 us revolutionizing sustainable energy markets through blockchain-powered energy trading platforms and carbon-offsetting markets.::We use cookies to improve your experience. Web3’s underlying technologies are revolutionizing the future of sustainable energy markets through blockchain-powered peer-to-peer energy trading platforms and carbon-offsetting markets. In pursuing sustainability
column2: web3 technologies have paved the way for inventive solutions to bolster climate-focused ventures
column3: renewable energy programs
column4: and initiatives to capture and store carbon. The recent decline of over 70% in the value of web3-related assets is indeed disconcerting. However
column5: the focus should not be on their volatility. The fundamental technological advancements that have enabled web3 should be the highlight. These innovations are set to impact many sectors of the global economy and serve as a locomotive for reaching sustainability goals. BE[IN]CRYPTO Global Crypto and Web3 Sustainability Report Sustainable Growth & Reducing Climate Impact “Blockchain innovation and tokenized carbon credit have the potential to transform the way carbon is traded” The blockchain industry is taking urgent steps toward addressing climate change by promoting sustainability and reducing carbon emissions in multiple sectors. Blockchain can revolutionize the management of carbon credits
column6: offsetting and measuring carbon footprints. Carbon trading is commonly used to meet international emissions reduction targets
column7: including those outlined in the Kyoto Protocol and the Paris Agreement. Carbon credits also serve as certificates representing the right to emit one tonne of carbon dioxide or its equivalent. Under a carbon trading scheme
column8: companies that emit less than their allocated carbon credits can sell their surplus credits to companies that exceed their emissions limit. This situation then creates a financial incentive for reducing emissions by putting a price on carbon. By offering a transparent
column9: secure
column10: and decentralized platform
column11: blockchain facilitates the seamless integration and management of renewable energy sources. Allowing companies to account for carbon emissions precisely. As renewable energy sources become increasingly integrated into existing power grids
column12: blockchain technology is critical in streamlining the process of bookkeeping emissions and green energy used by the single grid. A significant instance of this integration is the partnership between Energy Web Foundation (EWF) and Vodafone. In 2020
column13: they launched a blockchain-focused energy management system to improve the integration of renewable and distributed energy assets within power grids. Utilizing secure IoT connectivity backed by blockchain technology
column14: this system optimizes the energy market while fostering a more sustainable future. Blockchain-based decentralized carbon registries offer a transparent and impenetrable record of carbon credits
column15: enhancing the efficiency and openness of the carbon market. For example
column16: Powerledger has created the world’s first blockchain-based renewable energy trading platform. Allowing consumers and producers to monitor
column17: trace
column18: and trade every kilowatt generated off-grid. Simultaneously
column19: it provides a trustworthy and secure platform for conducting carbon trading transactions. As we move into the next decade
column20: web3 will play a crucial part in establishing trust in the carbon market and crafting a more dependable system for monitoring the ownership and exchange of carbon credits. Blockchain technology sets the stage for a more transparent
column21: trustworthy
column22: and eco-friendly carbon market. Blockchain technology is taking peer-to-peer energy trading to the next level. It’s changing how solar energy is traded among neighbors
column23: businesses
column24: and entities. By allowing direct energy trading
column25: these platforms enable individuals and organizations to monetize excess solar power. They can also foster a more sustainable and decentralized energy market. Despite the existence of environmental credits
column26: the current market structure creates friction. Veridium
column27: an ecological tech startup
column28: offers a solution to the issue through tokenization and smart contracts. The startup recently joined forces with IBM to use its technology to issue and manage carbon credit-backed blockchain tokens. Blockchain technology also allows households to combine solar energy production and battery storage. They then effectively operate as a cohesive virtual power plant. This approach empowers consumers to participate more actively in the energy market and promotes a greener and decentralized energy landscape. BE[IN]CRYPTO Global Crypto and Web3 Sustainability Report Sustainable Growth & Reducing Climate Impact The potential of web3 tools and blockchain technologies extends well beyond the realm of cryptocurrency’s volatile and often speculative market. To successfully navigate this shifting tide
column29: it is essential to develop a comprehensive understanding of the transformative potential of the technology and its implications for the broader business landscape. Advocates of the carbon market will likely push for uniform global standards that provide increased assurance to market participants
column30: fostering expansion in the process. The web3 industry has developed innovative methods for supporting climate-related initiatives
column31: renewable energy projects
column32: and carbon sequestration efforts. One potential solution to address the uncertainty created by changing policies and questions about the validity of certain credits is to digitalize the carbon credit market and remove intermediaries. Improving market transparency can also ensure investments are directed towards genuine sustainability initiatives. This could help boost the slowing growth of voluntary carbon markets. column1: 179::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchain-audit-security-standards::Blockworks::article::Blockchain needs standards::Opinion: Without security audit standards
column2: apps built on blockchain will continue to fall prey to hacks and exploits.::Without security audit standards
column3: apps built on blockchain will continue to fall prey to hacks and exploits Frame Fusion Art/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks The 2023 crypto winter has been challenging for many
column4: not least the thieves who target crypto wallets
column5: platforms and token protocols. So far this year
column6: they’ve only managed to steal $1 billion in crypto assets — a steep fall from 2022’s record $3.8 billion. Unfortunately
column7: the decline appears to have more to do with a reduction in available capital than with stronger defenses. And while the scale of attacks has fallen
column8: their frequency has in fact risen sharply: from 60 hacks in 2022 to 75 as of the end of October. And the year isn’t over. If decentralized finance is ever to be widely accepted by retail and institutional investors
column9: then it needs to achieve its goal of democratizing global finance. We must collectively do better at closing the loopholes that malicious actors are forever looking to slip through. The key to locking the door against bad actors? We need to vastly improve security auditing
column10: which
column11: at present
column12: is inconsistent at best and a rubber-stamp exercise at worst. Specifically
column13: our industry as a whole needs to adopt a consistent auditing methodology for decentralized technology that is rigorous
column14: standardized and repeatable — as robust as what protects traditional finance. Such an auditing standard
column15: coupled with a public commitment by auditing firms to the principle of responsible disclosure — the willingness to call out projects that refuse to listen to or act on recommendations — will encourage projects themselves to raise their security standards. Atomic Wallet’s refusal to heed a February 2022 public disclosure of serious security vulnerabilities by auditor Least Authority resulted in the loss of more than $100 million to hackers in June 2023. At its best
column16: a third-party security audit is a thorough investigation by a skilled team that analyzes every aspect of a system’s design and implementation
column17: seeking out weaknesses and flaws that could affect operations or users — or offer bad actors access to sensitive data or assets. A good audit also carefully assesses whether developers and designers have adhered to best practices in a system’s creation and roll-out. Vulnerabilities come in many forms; incorrect or insufficiently secure cryptography
column18: sensitive information leaks
column19: unprotected system parts
column20: inconsistencies between system design documentation and the code used in implementation. Weaknesses like these can result in anything from the exposure of sensitive and secret user data to the loss of user and system assets. That audits are as detailed — and consistent — as possible is therefore essential to both a project and its users’ safety. There are dozens of firms out there offering audit services
column21: but with no industry standard
column22: quality can and does indeed vary drastically. Even within reputable firms
column23: there is neither consensus on what should be audited nor a consistent set of yardsticks. There is
column24: of course
column25: no guarantee that even the most experienced auditors will either sniff out every weakness in a system or protect every user from loss. But if they are thoroughly and regularly carried out
column26: security audits have been proven to sharply reduce the risk of a serious vulnerability going undetected. Read more from our opinion section: It’s time for blockchain security firms to join forces However
column27: audits can’t stop social engineering attacks — those that involve the manipulation of human beings — such as when North Korean group Lazarus convinced engineers at an unidentified crypto exchange earlier this year to download malware disguised as an arbitrage bot. Preventing that type of attack only comes from vigilance and team training. It is true that every audit will be different
column28: just as every project is different. But my long experience in the security auditing space has taught me there are specific steps an auditor must take to maximize the effectiveness of the security audit for the benefit of clients
column29: users and the ecosystem. What are these requirements? An auditing standard that aims to make decentralized systems more resilient and protect their users from potential losses must include an exhaustive assessment of the following: To ensure that any improvement in standards benefits blockchain as a whole
column30: we also advocate knowledge-sharing and the creation of public goods such as research
column31: tooling and training. By working together to improve the standards of the security auditing industry as a whole — and thus the decentralized technology sphere — we can go a long way toward stopping the blockchain black hat hackers from breaking 2022’s record for crypto assets stolen. And that’s one record we don’t want to see broken again. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column1: 477::https://theconversation.com/quest-to-find-bitcoins-founder-highlights-currencys-biggest-threat-the-taxman-52411::The Conversation::article::Quest to find bitcoin’s founder highlights currency’s biggest threat: the taxman::How tax authorities decide to treat virtual currencies like bitcoin may determine whether they thrive or die.::Bitcoin enthusiasts have recently been roiled by claims that an Australian named Craig Wright and his deceased partner are the mysterious founders behind the cryptocurrency. Of course
column2: we’ve been down this path before. The New York Times
column3: Fast Company
column4: The New Yorker and Newsweek have all made similar claims about different people
column5: only to be proved wrong. And last month
column6: Wired – the magazine behind the most recent claim – said there are reasons to believe Wright is actually a hoaxer and not “Satoshi Nakamoto
column7: ” as the currency’s creator is known. Regardless of whether the new claims are correct
column8: it has resurrected a worry that has long plagued bitcoin users. Around one million bitcoins were mined early in the currency’s history and have never been transferred. Were they to be sold en masse
column9: bitcoin’s value could drop precipitously
column10: wiping out a lot of wealth and threatening its status as a reliable alternate currency
column11: independent of banks and governments. However
column12: the reporting about Wright and the bitcoin businesses and trusts he has established – presumably for tax and secrecy purposes – reveals an even bigger threat to bitcoin users and other supporters of virtual currency: how will such currencies be treated for tax purposes? This is a question I have been exploring for the last decade
column13: both with regard to virtual currencies designed to be used solely online
column14: such as for World of Warcraft
column15: and those designed for use in the real world
column16: such as bitcoin. Bitcoins are created by a computer algorithm and are initially allocated through a process colloquially referred to as “mining.” Miners collect bitcoins by solving complex mathematical equations used to authenticate transfers and in so doing both bring more of the currency into the world and maintain the system. Bitcoin users have a public key and a private key associated with the bitcoins they own. To effect a transfer
column17: one must use the private key. However
column18: transfers are recorded on a public “block chain
column19: ” which uses the associated public key. This secure public record-keeping obviates the need for third-party intermediaries
column20: like banks. While the world can see the public key and how many bitcoins are associated with it
column21: the owner of the bitcoin can remain anonymous if he keeps his association with that key secret. Approximately 15 million bitcoins have been issued to date
column22: and they are currently valued at about US$430 each
column23: for a total of approximately $6.5 billion. The algorithm is designed to generate 21 million bitcoins
column24: and experts anticipate that the last bitcoin will be issued sometime between 2110 and 2140. Bitcoin is designed to be used as a currency
column25: though some hold it as an investment. The difficulty is that governments have taken a variety of positions on the nature of bitcoin for tax purposes. For instance
column26: some countries
column27: including those in Europe
column28: have classified bitcoin as a currency for consumption tax purposes
column29: meaning that the various value-added taxes do not apply to bitcoin exchanges
column30: while others
column31: such as Australia
column32: have not. Similarly
column33: the U.K. treats bitcoin as foreign currency for income tax purposes
column34: while the U.S. regards it as property. Those who “mine” bitcoins will likely be subject to income tax on the value they receive under the theory that they are being compensated for validating bitcoin transactions and maintaining the block chain that records all transfers. But this is true regardless of whether bitcoin is recognized as a currency. In other words
column35: they are not really mining and not subject to the complex rules governing mining operations. Instead
column36: they are being compensated for services. The difficulty arises when people try to spend their bitcoins
column37: however acquired. Those who spend local currency
column38: such as dollars (U.S. or Australian) or euros
column39: do not report a gain or loss when they do so. For instance
column40: if I buy a hamburger
column41: I don’t have a gain or loss on the currency used
column42: regardless of whether it has changed value relative to other currencies. As the baseline currency
column43: a dollar is worth a dollar
column44: even though it may fluctuate against other currencies or be affected by inflation. Foreign currency is different. If I buy a euro for $1 and spend it later
column46: theoretically I have a $0.10 gain that I should be taxed on. Different countries have different rules
column47: but in the U.S.
column48: taxpayers need not pay taxes on such gains if they are under $200 in a given year. By refusing to classify bitcoin as a currency for income tax purposes (local or otherwise)
column49: tax authorities effectively treat bitcoins as any other property
column50: meaning that those who buy items with bitcoins must report any gain on the transaction associated with a change in its value. That is
column51: it is treated like an investment
column52: regardless of how the owner actually uses it. It is as if they sold their bitcoins for cash and then used that cash to make a purchase. Worse yet
column53: if the bitcoin has gone down in value
column54: taxpayers might not be able to deduct the losses
column55: because they could be considered personal. Thus
column56: anyone using bitcoin as a currency has to keep track of each bitcoin’s cost so that he can accurately calculate gain or loss. This administrative task
column57: combined with the potential need to pay income taxes
column58: could make bitcoin too difficult to use as an alternate currency. Wright’s tale of woe with the Australia Tax Authority (ATA) (revealed in a transcript made public as part of the effort to prove that he is Satoshi Nakamoto) shows how the decision not to classify bitcoin as a currency creates problems with a tax on goods and services (GST). Among other things
column59: Wright sought to create an exchange to buy and sell bitcoin. If bitcoin were considered a currency
column60: such exchanges would be exempt from the GST
column61: and the exchange could operate economically. However
column62: if the GST applied to such transactions
column63: as the ATA claimed
column64: the exchange would be forced to purchase $1 of bitcoin for $1.10 (assuming a 10% rate). In other words
column65: if you use normal currency
column66: it would cost you $1
column67: but if you use bitcoin
column68: it would cost $1.10. Bitcoin becomes a lot less attractive under those conditions. To avoid this result
column69: Wright and his lawyers established a number of offshore trusts and argued that
column70: for many of the transactions the ATA was investigating
column71: no bitcoin was actually transferred. Instead
column72: the beneficial interests in the trusts
column73: which were not subject to the GST
column74: were transferred. The bitcoin itself was purportedly held offshore
column75: and any transfer of the bitcoin or rights to it were outside the reach of the ATA. It’s not clear whether such arguments would actually succeed
column76: but they illustrate a real problem that intangible assets raise for both consumption and income taxes
column77: especially for countries that use a territorial tax system (that is
column78: one that doesn’t tax foreign income). If assets are considered to be outside a given country
column79: they will not be subject to that country’s GST or equivalent tax. Moreover
column80: if the asset can be “wrapped” in a trust or other entity whose ownership interests are exempt from the GST
column81: it can potentially escape tax even if it is held locally. Similarly
column82: if such assets generate income
column83: for instance when they are bought or sold
column84: under a territorial system
column85: that income will be taxed in the country where the sale occurred. It is not surprising that Wright established at least some of his trusts in known tax havens
column86: such as the Seychelles. Even if his efforts to shield bitcoin from tax through these efforts succeed
column87: they are far too complicated for the average user and will likely further impede bitcoin’s adoption as an alternate currency. Much of the recent focus has been on whether Wright really created bitcoin and whether he is sitting on a hoard worth close to a half billion dollars
column88: which could potentially destabilize the market. However
column89: the real threat to bitcoin and other similar products may come from a far more mundane source: the world’s tax authorities. Absent favorable rulings
column90: every bitcoin transaction could generate both income and consumption tax liability
column91: rendering bitcoin impractical as an alternate currency. Sophisticated tax planning to avoid such outcomes might succeed but would make bitcoin harder to use. Thus
column92: while bitcoin was developed as a means to free individuals from the need to interact with third parties
column93: including the government

column1: 479::https://ambcrypto.com/willy-woos-bitcoin-price-prediction-btc-has-room-to-run-and-that-means/::AMBCrypto::article::Willy Woo’s Bitcoin price prediction: BTC has ‘room to run’ and that means…::Bitcoin's price can head in so many different directions as the year goes on. It all depends on...::Bitcoin’s price can head in so many different directions as the year goes on. It all depends on…  Bitcoin recorded a notable hike recently
column2: with gains of 4.9% seen over the past week. This uptick has contributed to a broader bullish trend across the cryptocurrency market. Analysts are now closely monitoring various indicators to predict what might lie ahead for the world’s leading cryptocurrency. One such analyst
column3: Willy Woo
column4: shared his insights on the Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) Oscillator for Bitcoin
column5: discussing its potential implications for future market movements. Woo’s analysis on the social media platform X delved into the VWAP
column6: a technical indicator that averages the price of an asset while considering the volume of transactions at each price level. This approach gives more importance to price levels with higher trading volumes
column7: providing a more balanced view of price movements.  For Bitcoin
column8: Woo specifically examined the VWAP using on-chain volume
column9: which benefits from the transparency of the blockchain to provide clear data to all observers. The focus of Woo’s study is the VWAP Oscillator
column10: which measures the ratio between Bitcoin’s spot price and its VWAP
column11: displaying this relationship in a form that oscillates around zero. Source: Willy Woo on X Recent trends revealed that the VWAP Oscillator has been in negative territory for the past few months
column12: but is now on an upward trajectory. Should this continue
column13: it could soon reach the neutral zone
column14: signaling a potential shift in market dynamics. Historical data also seemed to indicate that when the VWAP Oscillator exits the negative zone and starts to climb
column15: it often precedes a period of bullish momentum for Bitcoin. The price typically continues to surge until the oscillator peaks in positive territory and begins to decline. According to Woo
column16: this pattern means that “there is still a lot of room to run before a reversal or consolidation occurs
column17: ” making it a challenging time for bearish investors in the market. Further supplementing these bullish observations
column18: a CryptoQuant analyst also highlighted an increasing number of purchases from retail investors. According to the analyst
column19: they have now bought roughly $135.7 million worth of Bitcoin over the past month alone. Source: CryptoQuant This buying spree aligns with a spike in Bitcoin’s daily active addresses
column20: as shown by Santiment’s data. The number of daily active addresses surged from approximately 49
column21: 000 to over 66
column22: 000 in a single day
column23: illustrating a significant hike in market activity. Source: Santiment From a technical analysis perspective too
column24: Bitcoin’s chart on the 4-hour timeframe showed some promising signs. The appearance of a bullish abandoned baby pattern followed by a bullish engulfing candlestick that closes above its predecessor is a particularly positive bullish signal. Source: BTC/USDT
column25: TradingView These technical patterns align with Woo’s prediction
column26: indicating that Bitcoin might be gearing up for more gains. Notably
column27: one of the catalysts behind BTC’s current bullishness is the release of the latest CPI data which was slightly lower than the expected 0.4%
column28: as previously reported by AMBCrypto.   Disclaimer: AMBCrypto's content is meant to be informational in nature and should not be interpreted as investment advice. Trading

column7: tokens and coins are two distinct categories of cryptocurrency. It is important to know the difference as there may be different trust assumptions associated with using one or the other. This guide covers the differences between tokens vs. coins and highlights recommended platforms for purchasing each. column27: click the following link. In cryptocurrency
column28: coins are digital assets native to a blockchain. Put another way
column29: they are assets built into the blockchain itself rather than on top of the blockchain. We can think of this in terms of nations. The native currency for the United States is the United States Dollar (USD)
column30: the British Pound Sterling (GBP) for the United Kingdom
column31: and the Euro (EURO) for the Eurozone. Similarly
column32: the native cryptocurrency for the Bitcoin blockchain is Bitcoin (BTC)
column33: Ether (ETH) for Ethereum
column34: and Solana (SOL) for the Solana blockchain. Let’s take this further. The U.S. Department of the Treasury issues seven denominations of paper currency ($1
column40: and $100) and five denominations of coins (1¢
column44: 50¢). In the same way
column45: cryptocurrency coins have several denominations as well. There are two popular methods for creating a blockchain’s native coins — UTXO (unspent transaction output) and the account model. While cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Litecoin use the UTXO model
column46: other cryptocurrencies like Ethereum and the BNB chain use the account model. A UTXO is created when a transaction occurs. When miners mine a block
column47: they make a Coinbase or a transaction to pay themselves for updating the blockchain. A coinbase transaction is the first transaction in a block a miner creates. When a transaction output is created
column48: it becomes a UTXO until it is spent. Each UTXO contains information about its value (e.g.
column49: how many coins it represents). Once created
column50: the outputs can only be used once as input in a new transaction. Two types of record-keeping models are popular in today’s blockchain networks. The first method is the UTXO (Unspent Transaction Output) Model and the second one is the Account/Balance Model. The UTXO model is employed by Bitcoin
column51: and Ethereum uses the Account/Balance Model. pic.twitter.com/HEEzlMViVF This is similar to a transaction made in coins or bills. A UTXO is like a coin or bill itself
column52: while the bill’s value can vary
column53: similar to how the value of a UTXO can vary. Once spent
column54: you can not retrieve the bill you used to pay once
column55: just like UTXOs can only be used once. The buyer receives any change left over from the transaction. Another UTXO is created and sent to the recipient when a UTXO is spent. If the original UTXO exceeds the amount sent
column56: a second UTXO is made
column57: and the sender receives the remainder via a change address. Each UTXO must reference a previous UTXO as its input
column58: except for special cases like coinbase transactions where new coins are minted. This creates a chain of custody from one UTXO to another based on the history of transactions. You can trace a UTXO back to the transaction where it was created as an output. While the UTXO model records transactions in a way that is similar to transacting with bills and coins
column59: the account model is similar to traditional banking. In this model
column60: accounts hold balances that increase or decrease with each transaction. When you send a transaction
column61: the blockchain directly adjusts the accounts’ balances. It also debits the amount from the sender’s account and credits the same amount to the recipient. As a result
column62: the coins technically are not “sent.” Rather
column63: there is a ledger that updates with each transaction. Another important detail to keep in mind is the account nonce. The account nonce is simply an index of the number of successful transactions of a single account. It ensures that transactions from a single account are processed in the order they are sent. This is important for maintaining the state consistency of the account
column64: such as the balance of Ether. The term nonce (number used once) is used quite frequently in crypto and tech-related fields. “Account nonces” have a separate purpose from nonces in blockchain mining
column65: message authentication codes (MAC)
column66: and other systems. Blockchains are distributed databases requiring a network of nodes to maintain all the data it stores. The nodes are computers or servers maintained by individuals or organizations. However
column67: keeping these databases comes at a cost. Unlike Amazon Web Service or Microsoft Azure
column68: the database (or blockchain) nodes are anonymous and distributed globally. Therefore
column69: paying these node operators for their work in a fiat currency is impossible. When a block is created
column70: the node that mines or proposes the block receives a coinbase or a stipend for maintaining this distributed database. Another reason that coins exist is to pay gas and transaction fees. When you create a transaction on a blockchain
column71: a node must pick up your transaction and expend resources to execute it. A transaction fee is paid to the miner or proposer (validator) that executes the transaction. Alternatively
column72: gas fees are the cost to execute the transaction
column73: and transaction fees are the cost to pay the miner or validator to execute the transaction. Users pay both transaction and gas fees in coins. 1. Bitcoin (BTC): Created by the pseudonymous Satoshi Nakamoto
column74: Bitcoin is the original cryptocurrency. While Bitcoin was designed as a medium of exchange
column75: it has since found a stronger use as a store of value. 2. Ether (ETH): Ether is the native cryptocurrency to the Ethereum blockchain. It is used as gas for the Ethereum virtual machine
column76: which allows developers to create applications with some level of complexity. 3. Solana (SOL): As the native coin of the Solana network
column77: SOL is used as payment for gas and transaction fees — which are extremely low on Solana. The smallest unit of SOL is a Lamport
column78: named after Leslie Lamport. 4. Avalanche (AVAX): Avalanche is a layer-0 protocol that uses the AVAX coin as its native crypto. On Avalanche
column79: users can launch subnets using their own nodes. 5. Cosmos (ATOM): Cosmos is a hub allowing founders to create blockchains using the IBC. This enables blockchains to communicate
column80: share information
column81: and transfer assets like ATOM securely and standardized. Unlike coins
column82: developers do not build cryptocurrency tokens directly into the blockchain. Instead
column83: they create tokens as cryptocurrencies using smart contracts on a blockchain. The logic for what “qualifies” as a token and governs its behavior depends entirely on the developer that creates it. With most blockchains today
column84: the network does not recognize the tokens built on it. A few blockchains like Sui and Aptos offer rare exceptions to this rule. As such
column85: some communities have developed token standards specific to their blockchain ecosystem. Token standards govern how accounts are updated. Some of the logic that they manage includes: Perhaps the most popular token standard is the ERC-20 standard for the Ethereum ecosystem and EVM-compatible chains. There is also the BEP-20 standard for the BNB chain
column86: SPL (Solana Program Library) for Solana
column87: and
column88: more recently
column89: the BRC-20 standard for Bitcoin. The concept of tokens is not specific to cryptocurrency. Many examples of tokens exist in the real world. In this case
column90: a token is just a physical representation of some right or privilege. For example
column91: you could consider the deed to a house or the title to a car as a token or proof of ownership of those assets. Tokenization is the digital representation of rights and privileges. In the case of tokens created by smart contracts
column92: the token represents the right to transact value. Aside from the standard logic
column93: tokens work in many different ways. Founders typically create tokens with a purpose in mind and will tailor their behavior to the decentralized application (DApp) or ecosystem in which it will operate. Many have attempted to create frameworks for classifying token logic. This is quite the herculean feat
column94: considering that they are as diverse as the developer is imaginative. In the case of ERC-20 tokens
column95: the logic for the token exists completely within the smart contract. So technically
column96: addresses on Ethereum do not actually “hold” tokens. Rather
column97: the smart contract is like a ledger for an accountant. It keeps a record of the balances of each address that owns tokens. When someone “sends” tokens to another address
column98: the smart contract updates the balance of both addresses. That is why it is important to create tokens using well-tested standards and best practices. Unless developers are careful
column99: a hacker could game poorly formed token logic. As stated previously
column100: many have attempted to create standards for classifying tokens. This is difficult
column101: considering tokens gain new use cases every year. The most popular uses for tokens are: 1. Chainlink (LINK): Chainlink is most notably known for its blockchain-agnostic oracle services. The team behind Chainlink also creates infrastructure for cross-chain communication
column102: bridging
column103: verifiable randomness
column104: and more. 2. The Graph (GRT): Often described as the Google of web3
column105: The Graph is a protocol for indexing information stored on the blockchain. It allows users to query
column107: and use public data to build applications. GRT: The Graph: The Graph is a decentralized protocol that allows developers to index
column109: and access blockchain data in a scalable and efficient manner. $PIXIZ | $BAMA | #Bitbama | #R2E. 3. Render (RNDR): Render is a project that allows users to transact in a GPU marketplace. Sellers can rent out their GPU power while buyers utilize it for graphic rendering tasks. 4. Uniswap (UNI): Uniswap is Ethereum’s most popular decentralized exchange (DEX). The UNI token gives its holders governance rights over the protocol. 5. Gala (GALA): Gala Games is a blockchain-based gaming platform that lets players own
column111: and trade in-game assets with cryptocurrency. Here’s a comparison chart that outlines the key differences between crypto coins and tokens. This chart helps to delineate the differences between crypto coins and tokens
column114: and their characteristics in the cryptocurrency ecosystem. You can compare coins and tokens to currency in traditional finance (TradFi) in many ways. From an accounting perspective
column115: the ledger that records and issues the currency is centralized in trades
column117: and depends on tokens. In traditional finance
column118: there are different forms of money because of the system’s complexity. For example
column119: USD can come in bank deposits
column126: and central bank notes. “When most people think of money
column127: they picture rectangular pieces of government-printed paper
column129: decorated with historical figures. Although it is the most well-known form of money
column130: it is only a small part of what constitutes money in the modern financial system.” This complexity complicates the ledger; however
column131: at the end of the day
column132: the system is mostly centralized under the U.S. government. On the other hand
column133: coins built on blockchains are part of a decentralized ledger that is maintained by a global community. In the case of USD
column134: the U.S. government can sanction any country to prevent it from using dollars. With a blockchain
column135: anyone has the right to update the ledger (mint more coins)
column136: but no one can exclude anyone else from doing so or transacting. However
column137: tokens do not necessarily have this ability. It all depends on the smart contract itself. Despite the name
column138: stablecoins are primarily tokens. Developers create stablecoins on vetted and seasoned blockchains. This makes them tokens. The reason is that mature blockchains already have the infrastructure for users to utilize stablecoins. If stablecoin providers had to build their blockchains to issue coins
column139: they would also have to find a way to attract developers to build apps on their blockchain or the applications themselves. Both of these options are extremely costly. There could also be significant ramifications if these providers built their own blockchains and bridged the stablecoins to other ecosystems. This comparison between crypto coins and tokens highlights substantial differences between asset types. You must thoroughly research and understand these distinctions for safe trading practices. Staying well-informed will empower you to navigate the cryptocurrency sector safely and effectively. Coins are cryptocurrencies that have their blockchain. Tokens are built on blockchains but do not have their own. They are simply smart contracts that exist outside of the source code of a blockchain. Ethereum is a blockchain. The native coin of Ethereum is Ether. Though many cryptocurrencies exist on Ethereum
column140: their logic is not built into the source code of Ethereum. Tokens are useful for utilizing services on decentralized applications (DApps). For example
column141: traders can not use native Ether in many applications on Ethereum. They must use Wrapped Ether (WETH)
column142: a tokenized (smart contract) version of Ether. There are many different classifications for tokens. Utility
column146: and transactional are the most common. Tokens are often difficult to classify because their uses and purposes grow with time. Tokens are not a phenomenon specific to cryptocurrency. They also exist in the traditional world. For example
column147: a deed to a house or car title could be considered a token. Examples of tokens include Chainlink (LINK)
column149: and Shiba Inu (SHIB). Nearly all stablecoins and most meme coins are also tokens
column152: and AVAX are not tokens because their logic is built into the blockchain. However
column156: and WAVAX) are considered tokens. Disclaimer In line with the Trust Project guidelines

column1: 481::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchains-still-arent-great-at-communication::Blockworks::article::Blockchains still aren’t great at communication::Opinion: The current state of blockchain interoperability poses an existential threat to the mainstream adoption of blockchain as a whole.::The current state of blockchain interoperability poses an existential threat to the mainstream adoption of blockchain technology as a whole Midjourney modified by Blockworks One of the prerequisites for the mass adoption of blockchain technology is interoperability — the ability to pass data between distinct blockchain and blockchain-like systems. Numerous interoperability projects have established themselves today
column2: and many are growing at an incredible rate. Indeed
column3: it’s only a matter of time before the number of cross-chain messages is measured in trillions. Blockchain interoperability has never been more ubiquitous. In January 2024
column4: more than $23 billion worth of assets were locked in cross-chain bridges on Ethereum alone. Clearly
column5: our industry’s early adopters — affectionately called Web3 enthusiasts — are keen to explore new ecosystems as they routinely bridge assets from one blockchain to another. This process
column6: though clunky
column7: has become so commonplace that many believe that blockchain interoperability is a solved issue. The truth is far more bleak. The state of blockchain interoperability today is one of fractured incompatibility. Competing interoperability projects build ad hoc solutions that gerrymander the blockchain landscape
column8: making it impractical for enterprises and regulators to vet the security of each. As it stands
column9: the current state of blockchain interoperability poses an existential threat to the mainstream adoption of blockchain technology as a whole. Modern interoperability projects are far too focused on building and growing their own proprietary products. The fight to become the one-and-only has introduced growing system complexity and
column10: therefore
column11: unbounded risk. As different projects make different tradeoffs to solve different problems
column12: blockchain interoperability protocols continue to increase in complexity. Not only does this complexity make protocols progressively more incompatible with one another
column13: each new system component or trust assumption introduces new attack vectors. As an industry
column14: we must curb this troubling trend. A shared framework for interoperability is desperately needed. As a trustless system
column15: decentralized blockchains are incapable of communicating with other blockchain networks out-of-the-box. Trust assumptions dictate the risk profile of a particular cross-chain design by shaping its vulnerabilities and delineating how a system can be exploited. Generally speaking
column16: the greater the complexity of a system
column17: the higher its susceptibility to attack. It is therefore preferable to simplify the design of cross-chain solutions in order to limit the number of exploitable components. So
column18: while it is true that trust assumptions are inherent to blockchain interoperability solutions
column19: there is security in simplicity. Read more from our opinion section: There’s no reason to fear open platforms A shared framework for interoperability between blockchain and blockchain-like systems — one that includes architectural guidelines and vetted interface definitions — makes it possible to reduce system complexity. This has the knock-on effect of preventing fragmentation across different project implementations. Even something as simple as common interfaces and functions to decode and verify the validity of messages would go a long way towards enhancing interoperability
column20: while reducing the need for custom implementations. A shared framework for interoperability also has the potential to foster collaboration between different interoperability projects. Broadly speaking
column21: interoperability projects simply don’t trust each others’ work. This isn’t entirely surprising considering that
column22: between 2021 and 2023
column23: more than $2.9 billion was stolen from exploited cross-chain bridges. Nevertheless
column24: this distrust has directly contributed to the fractured state of blockchain interoperability today. A shared framework
column25: built openly and vetted by all
column26: will result in a more secure system. Blockchain interoperability must be core infrastructure first
column27: product second. If we as an industry are to have any hope of achieving the mainstream adoption of blockchain technology (without sacrificing the industry’s core ethos of decentralization)
column28: we must establish a shared framework for interoperability. Time is running out. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana
