column1: 511::https://blockworks.co/news/bitcoin-halving-impact-on-layer-2s::Blockworks::article::How will the Bitcoin halving impact Bitcoin L2s?::Bitcoin will likely grow to rely on its layer-2 infrastructure a lot more for most post-halving transactions this year
column2: experts say.::Bitcoin will likely grow to rely on its layer-2 infrastructure for most post-halving transactions this year
column3: experts say Artwork by Crystal Le The Bitcoin halving is anticipated to occur in the second half of April this year. Like real-world gold
column4: bitcoin is considered by many to be “digital gold
column5: ” with a maximum supply of 21 million coins. As the Bitcoin halving draws near
column6: many are concerned that miners will endure an inevitable revenue cut following the major event. Mining bitcoin has previously been a profitable way for people to earn rewards while simultaneously securing the network. Fisher Yu is the co-founder of Babylon
column7: a project aiming to create a Bitcoin-secured proof-of-stake economy. He noted the motivation behind early participation in Bitcoin’s proof-of-work security
column8: attributing it to the high amount of bitcoin rewards available when the blockchain was first created. “Nakamoto’s hope is that
column9: over time
column10: Bitcoin becomes very well adopted so that the increase in transaction fee will outrun the reduction in mining rewards
column11: so that miners’ operational costs are well covered
column12: ” Yu said. Read more: Why most bitcoin mining stocks are down amid a persistent crypto rally Although such a trend is observed
column13: Yu notes that existing transaction fees are not quite sufficient
column14: and there are growing concerns that miners may leave the network
column15: reducing the blockchain’s overall security. This belief is shared by Max Chamberlin
column16: the founder of next-gen EVM and layer-2 for Bitcoin
column17: Bitfinity
column18: who noted that many bitcoin mining businesses could become unsustainable following the halving. “While bitcoin’s mining difficulty is dynamic
column19: automatically adjusting to the current hash rate capabilities
column20: it would still be better for the network’s decentralization to have as many miners as possible
column21: ” Chamberlin said. Read more: 20% of bitcoin network hash rate could go offline after halving: Galaxy He notes that the emergence of Bitcoin Ordinals has boosted on-chain activity significantly and provided miners with a considerable new stream of income through transaction fees
column22: which have so far amounted to almost $240 million. “In a broader sense
column23: the introduction of ordinals and Runes has sparked considerable excitement within the cryptocurrency community in general
column24: introducing a novel category of tokens — assets that exist directly on the Bitcoin blockchain
column25: ” Chamberlin said. Despite this
column26: Chamberlin is aware that the Bitcoin ecosystem still needs to work on developing broad-spectrum
column27: general-purpose applications
column28: a challenge that stems primarily from the constraints of Bitcoin’s programming language
column29: Script. “This predicament echoes a longstanding conundrum in finance — the emergence of new assets begs the question of what to do with them
column30: ” he said. Read more: The history of Bitcoin halvings — and why this time might look different He remarks that a potential solution to this concern is to integrate assets into DeFi services through Bitcoin layer-2 solutions
column31: which often enable a more complex ecosystem of decentralized applications. “Bitfinity
column32: a next-gen EVM serving as a layer-2 for Bitcoin and other assets
column33: emerges as a strong contender in this regard. It provides developers with the familiar EVM programming environment but with access to Runes and other Bitcoin-native assets
column34: ” Chamberlin said. Yu agrees and explains that Babylon’s Bitcoin staking protocol could alleviate some of the growing concerns around cut rewards. He notes that miners could use their bitcoin to secure its proof-of-stake economy and be rewarded for their security. Read more: Let’s talk Bitcoin staking: Babylon’s litepaper Rena Shah shares this sentiment. Shah is the vice president of products and operations at Trust Machines
column35: a company that is building a decentralized economy on Bitcoin. She told Blockworks that Bitcoin will likely grow to rely on its layer-2 infrastructure a lot more for most post-halving transactions this year. “While the base layer will still focus on high-value settlements
column36: Bitcoin DeFi and other activities will no longer have to use the base layer
column37: as more [layer-2s] start unlocking frictionless usability
column38: ” she said. She added that “solving transaction times
column39: identity solutions and even wallet functionality between the [layer-1] and [layer-2s] are areas our team at Trust Machines has identified as most appealing to users. As well as DeFi opportunities
column40: which are of particular interest to users of other smart contract-based chains.” Updated April 3

And learn how to avoid falling prey to scams.::“Invest in crypto
column2: ” – more and more people advice that nowadays. But is it easy to choose the best crypto to invest in? When many options are available
column3: how do you choose between them? Several factors must be considered when deciding which cryptocurrency to invest in. It can be challenging to navigate
column4: given the vast variety of available currencies. To help you find answers to this question
column5: we have put together this guide. Monitoring current market capitalization is one technique to decide which crypto to invest in next. This will not only show which cryptos are ranked the highest right now but also the curve of their value.Keep track of global events that have an impact on cryptocurrency pricing. For instance
column6: Elon Musk’s purchase of the social media site Twitter affected the price of other cryptocurrencies. Certain events make some cryptocurrencies more volatile than others do. Consider this when you decide – it can be both a pro and con. The cryptocurrency’s utility
column7: or practical value
column8: is an essential element that can significantly affect its value. In simple terms
column9: if a cryptocurrency has more useful functions
column10: it is likely to be more valuable. Conversely
column11: if its use cases decrease
column12: its value is likely to follow suit. Identifying the most promising use cases and those with the most market traction are crucial for making informed investment decisions. A cryptocurrency with a wide range of potential use cases
column13: or those that have gained significant traction in the market
column14: can be a positive sign for the investment portfolio. However
column15: it is worth noting that the regulatory landscape of cryptocurrencies is constantly evolving. New regulations and restrictions can limit the use of cryptocurrencies. Therefore
column16: staying informed about the regulatory environment is crucial for informed investment decisions in the dynamic cryptocurrency market. In summary
column17: understanding the utility of a cryptocurrency is essential when deciding which crypto to invest in. Investing in a crypto with high-quality use cases or the potential for new ones can be a positive sign for your investment portfolio. However
column18: staying up to date with the regulatory environment is equally important in making informed investment decisions in the crypto market. Always check whether the cryptocurrency you are thinking about investing in has a white paper. The coin
column19: its uses
column20: and its goals are covered in detail in the white paper
column21: along with the technology that supports it. This will not only provide you with crucial details about the currency
column22: but also reassure you of its genuineness. Generally
column23: it is critical to pay close attention to the legitimacy of currencies and brokers in the current crypto market. The most important
column24: the white paper on cryptocurrency is a vital document that investors need to examine before investing. It provides transparency
column25: outlines the project’s goals and technical specifications
column26: and explains the cryptocurrency use case. Without white papers
column27: investors do not have the information they need to make informed investment decisions. It is crucial to assess whether a specific cryptocurrency has limited supply. Understanding the current number of coins in circulation and the extent to which they can be created through mining are equally important. These factors can impact the price of cryptocurrencies in the long term. An excellent illustration of this concept is that of Bitcoin. Bitcoin has a finite number of available coins
column28: making it a valuable commodity as more people invest in it. An increase in demand for Bitcoin increases its value. However
column29: if the demand remains the same
column30: the value will change once there are no more bitcoins to mine. Therefore
column31: it is essential to keep an eye on the supply and demand factors of cryptocurrencies to make informed investment decisions. To elaborate further
column32: the limited supply of Bitcoin makes it a valuable asset. The Bitcoin mining process involves solving complex mathematical equations
column33: which results in the creation of new coins. However
column34: a finite number of coins can be created with a maximum of 21 million bitcoins in circulation. Once all 21 million Bitcoins are in circulation
column35: no more can be created
column36: and the only way to obtain Bitcoin is to buy it on exchange. This limited supply of Bitcoin makes it valuable
column37: as the demand for Bitcoin increases with a growing number of investors. Consequently
column38: the price of Bitcoin has increased dramatically over the years
column39: making it a popular investment asset. Understanding supply and demand factors is vital when you want to invest in crypto. Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency

column1: 514::https://theconversation.com/blockchain-is-useful-for-a-lot-more-than-just-bitcoin-58921::The Conversation::article::Blockchain is useful for a lot more than just Bitcoin::While Bitcoin gets all the attention
column2: the blockchain technology it’s based on could have applications across business and government.::Blockchain technology is not just useful for creating digital currencies such as Bitcoin or developing new financial technologies. Blockchains can be used for a wide variety of applications
column3: such as tracking ownership or the provenance of documents
column4: digital assets
column5: physical assets or voting rights. Blockchain technology was popularised by the Bitcoin digital currency system. But
column6: essentially
column7: a blockchain is just a special kind of database. The Bitcoin blockchain stores cryptographically signed records of financial transfers
column8: but blockchain systems can store any kind of data. Blockchains can also store and run computer code called “smart contracts”. What makes a blockchain system special is that it doesn’t run on just one computer like a regular database. Rather
column9: many distributed processing nodes collaborate to run it. There can be a full copy of the database on every node
column10: and the system encourages all those nodes to establish a consensus about its contents. This boosts our confidence in the database and its contents. It’s difficult
column11: if not impossible
column12: to meddle with the database without others finding out and correcting it. The global consensus among the nodes about the integrity and contents of the distributed database is why it’s often called a “distributed ledger”. In our society
column13: we normally rely on trusted third parties
column14: such as lawyers
column15: courts
column16: banks and governments to process and keep authoritative records about commercial transactions. These transactions aren’t just about financial transfers
column17: but also include the creation or transfer of physical assets
column18: shareholdings
column19: certifications
column20: digital rights
column21: intellectual property or even votes. These third parties are trusted because we rely on them. If they fail or lie
column22: we suffer. We tend to trust the third parties for reasons that are external to the database; lawyers are accredited; votes are counted by independent monitors; and courts run to established laws for matters such as oversight and the possibility of appeal. Blockchains are interesting because the integrity of the contents of the distributed ledger does not rely on any specific individual or organisation. So
column23: rather than relying on trusted third-party organisations to facilitate these commercial transactions
column24: we might instead rely on a trusted blockchain system. This means blockchains give us new opportunities to rethink how parts of our society work. Innovation here might reduce friction in the economy
column25: or create new kinds of services and ways of doing business with each other. Whether or not blockchain systems are trustworthy is an interesting question. The reasons for believing that blockchain systems won’t fail or lie would be based on our understanding of the underlying software technologies. It also depends on our understanding of market incentives that influence behaviour of the many distributed processing nodes that run blockchains. However
column26: blockchain technologies are still new in the scheme of things
column27: and the community is still discovering their risks
column28: limitations and potential economic and social impact. Because blockchain technology is so new
column29: it’s difficult to predict exactly how they will end up being used. This is why we at Data61 in CSIRO are exploring new ways blockchains can be used across industries. To understand the economic and societal opportunities presented by blockchain technology
column30: we also need to understand its technological risks and limitations. At Data61
column31: we plan to identify
column32: develop and evaluate some “proof of concept” systems using blockchains to investigate them. A recent UK government report on blockchain technologies provides a good overview and examples of the use of blockchain. One of these is Everledger
column33: a company founded by Australian woman Leanne Kemp. Everledger uses a blockchain to record information about the provenance and ownership of individual diamonds and other valuables. Here
column34: rather than the blockchain recording transfers of digital currency
column35: it records transfers of ownership of identified physical assets. This globally accessible provenance trail could reduce fraud and theft
column36: and enable new or improved kinds of insurance and finance services. The same general idea could be used for any supply chain
column37: such as in retail
column38: agriculture or pharmaceuticals. The drivers for improving assurance of supply chain quality vary in different industries. It could be brand reputation in retail
column39: or safety in pharmaceuticals
column40: or a combination in agriculture. It is worth observing that blockchains don’t totally do away with the need for trusted third parties. A blockchain is only a digital record
column41: but we need others to determine if those records actually match the corresponding physical assets in the real world. Everledger relies on major diamond certification companies to measure identifying information about individual diamonds. These measurements can be independently cross-checked. But in some sense
column42: companies such as these become trusted third parties for this blockchain-based system. One can imagine the adoption of blockchain technologies creating opportunities for new kinds of trusted third-party organisations. Underlying all of these applications is the need for data integrity
column43: which is the key security property for commercial systems
column44: and the primary property for blockchain technologies. For financial transactions
column45: data integrity means you can’t spend money you don’t have
column46: and you can’t spend money twice. For physical supply chains
column47: this means you can’t fraudulently acquire record of ownership for an asset. However
column48: other security properties
column49: such as privacy and confidentiality
column50: are also important in many application areas. To achieve confidentiality
column51: other mechanisms such as cryptography must be used in conjunction with the blockchain. Part of our software architecture research at Data61 is to seek to understand how design choices for software-based systems affect tradeoffs for qualities including security (integrity
column52: confidentiality
column53: privacy)
column54: performance (latency
column55: throughput and scalability)
column56: and others. Good design choices can control risks to achieving these qualities
column57: and this is part of what is evaluated in our research using proof-of-concept systems. Computer programs are a special kind of data and so can be stored in a database. That means we can store programs in the distributed ledger of a blockchain system
column58: and execute those programs while later transactions are being processed. In the Ethereum blockchain
column59: these programs can be highly complex. These programs are normally called “smart contracts”. Smart contracts can carry value
column60: and can conditionally transfer that value according to complex business conditions based on the latest state of the distributed ledger. This means blockchain systems can do more than store information about commercial transactions; they can also process commercial transactions too. This greatly expands the opportunities for using blockchain systems. Although smart contracts are often thought of as standing for self-executing legal contracts
column61: they are written in a general purpose programming language and can be used to implement a wide range of business logic. Can smart contracts actually stand as legal contracts? This is an interesting question. For legal contracts to be enforceable
column62: they need to be understandable by reasonable persons. Can the bytecode of a program stored on a blockchain really be understood by any human? Perhaps only obsessive hobbyists might be able to develop that skill! Another thread of research in Data61 is investigating new ways of representing and analysing smart contracts
column63: using recent results from legal informatics. Blockchain technology is still in its infancy. There are a wide range of plausible future scenarios for their future impact
column64: ranging from efficiency improvements for commercial transactions through to a complete reinvention of the economy. As with any disruptive technology
column65: understanding the plausible
column66: possible and probable impacts – the opportunities and risks – will be vital for wise policy
column67: strategy
column68: and design choices by Australian governments and companies.::2016-05-09T20:04:28Z::Bitcoin

column6: 000 mark for the first time since April and posted its biggest single-day gain since March. Such a move

column19: which suggests there is less Bitcoin supply coming into the market to sell via these entities.” The firm defines short-term traders as addresses that hold bitcoin for less than 155 days and are likely to capitalize on short-term price movements. A breakout in bitcoin comes after weeks of low volatility. Since March
column20: the market has been range-bound between $60
column23: with the halving event in April not providing the expected boost due to a general lack of market catalysts
column24: traders have previously said. Higher risk appetite for token bets showed signs of beginning earlier this week after an X post by retail trader Keith Gill sent some meme stocks and meme coins surging. Gill's online persona and investment strategies contributed to a short squeeze on video game retailer GameStop’s stock in 2021

column1: 517::https://blockworks.co/news/bitcoin-halving-inflation-and-issuance-schedule::Blockworks::article::Why is 2140 the end of bitcoin inflation?::The final Bitcoin halving
column2: where the mining reward becomes smaller than one satoshi
column3: is expected to occur in 2140.::The final Bitcoin halving
column4: where the mining reward becomes smaller than one satoshi
column5: is expected to occur in 2140 Artwork by Crystal Le It’s well known that the Bitcoin network experiences a halving of supply approximately every four years. Less appreciated is that these are set to continue for over a century into the future. Bitcoin’s pseudonymous creator Satoshi Nakamoto programmed the year 2140 — 30 halvings from now — as the year that the block rewards (the subsidy paid to miners for processing transactions into blocks) would drop to less than one satoshi
column6: the smallest unit of bitcoin. The use of the term “satoshi” — equivalent to 100 millionth of a bitcoin (or 0.00000001 BTC) — emerged organically among early Bitcoin users and developers
column7: appearing in various forums and discussions starting in 2010 or 2011
column8: and became widely accepted in 2013. Read more: The Bitcoin halving is about a month away — here’s what you can expect The halving is modeled after the physical mining of scarce resources
column9: according to Jameson Lopp
column10: co-founder and chief security officer at Casa. “There’s nothing special about the year 2140
column11: ” Lopp told Blockworks. “It’s just how the nature of halvings along with the level of precision of satoshis ended up working out.” Lopp notes that Nakamoto explained the supply schedule to Mike Hearn
column12: a former Google engineer who became an early Bitcoin contributor
column13: in 2009: “My choice for the number of coins and distribution schedule was an educated guess
column14: ” Satoshi wrote. “I wanted to pick something that would make prices similar to existing currencies
column15: but without knowing the future
column16: that’s very hard.” Read more: Satoshi warned against labeling bitcoin as an ‘investment’ He picked 21 million
column17: but Satoshi added that the divisibility of a bitcoin in practice could be represented differently depending on how valuable one bitcoin gets. “For example
column18: if 0.001 is worth one euro
column19: then it might be easier to change where the decimal point is displayed
column20: so if you had one bitcoin it’s now displayed as 1000
column21: and 0.001 is displayed as one.” For what it’s worth
column22: 0.001 BTC is worth about 65 euros (approximately $70) today. Why the rate of issuance would decline for 132 years
column23: however
column24: was never explained. “I expect it was more of a ‘better safe than sorry’ decision to give the system decades to bootstrap
column25: ” Lopp said. Unless the price of bitcoin (BTC) doubles every four years
column26: each halving brings less income from block rewards to miners. So to maintain the network’s hashrate
column27: which is important for Bitcoin’s security
column28: transaction fees will become more important over time. Whether that will happen in practice remains to be seen
column29: but Lopp is optimistic. “I expect that as we see the multi-layered Bitcoin ecosystem continue to expand
column30: the base chain will start to look more and more like a high-value cryptographic accumulator and it will make economic sense for on-chain transactions to pay relatively high fees
column31: ” he said. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana
column32: in your inbox
column33: every day. Subscribe to daily Solana news from Jack Kubinec and Jeff Albus. Newsletter Blockworks Daily  Upcoming Events Permissionless III WED - FRI

column1: 518::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-articles/crypto-lending-crypto-loans-7118/::Coinatory::article::Crypto lending - All you need to know about crypto loans::Looking to learn about crypto lending and how to profit from it? Discover what crypto lending is
column2: how it works
column3: and how you can earn money from it!::Crypto lending is the act of depositing cryptocurrency to be lent to borrowers in exchange for recurrent interest payment. Payments are made in the form of cryptocurrency
column4: which is commonly deposited and compounded every day
column5: every week
column6: or every month. Decentralized and centralized crypto lenders are the two primary categories of crypto lending platforms. Both provide access to high interest rates
column7: often as high as 20% annual percentage yield (APY)
column8: and both typically need depositing collateral in order to get a crypto loan. The opportunity to lend out cryptocurrency and earn interest in the form of cryptocurrency incentives is made available through cryptocurrency lending platforms for investors. In 2020
column9: lending platforms gained popularity
column10: and since then
column11: the total value of loans locked on different platforms has increased to billions. There are two parts to cryptocurrency lending: interest-bearing deposits and loans. Similar to a bank account
column12: deposit accounts have similar functions. The lending platform accepts cryptocurrency deposits from users and pays interest of up to 8% APY (depending on the platform and the cryptocurrency). Deposited money might be used by the platform to make loans to borrowers or for other kinds of investments. In order to borrow money or cryptocurrency
column13: borrowers normally have to deposit at least 100% (and sometimes up to 150%
column14: depending on the lender) in cryptocurrency as collateral. The interest rates differ by platform and require for monthly payments
column15: much like with traditional loans. In contrast to conventional loans
column16: cryptocurrency loans have durations as short as seven days and as long as 180 days
column17: with an hourly interest rate
column18: like Binance. Some lenders
column19: like Nexo
column20: which offers 0% APR
column21: provide an endless line of credit in their place. There are several types of cryptocurrency loans available: Some services provide a cryptocurrency line of credit rather than a standard loan with a defined term length. Users can borrow up to a specific amount of the deposited collateral using this kind of collateralized loan
column22: but there are no specified terms for repayment
column23: and they just pay interest on the money they withdraw. Collateralized loans are the most popular and require deposited cryptocurrency that is used as collateral for the loan. The majority of platforms demand overcollateralization
column24: which limits how much of the deposited collateral borrowers can access (usually below a 90% loan-to-value). The interest rate and the likelihood of having your margin called are both lower the lower the loan-to-value (LTV) ratio. Flash loans are typically available on crypto exchanges and are instant loans that are borrowed and repaid in the same transaction. These are very high-risk loans that are typically used to take advantage of market arbitrage opportunities
column25: such as buying cryptocurrency for a lower price in one market and instantly selling for a higher price in another
column26: all within the same transaction Uncollateralized loans are not as popular
column27: but they function similarly to personal loans. Borrowers must fill out a loan application
column28: pass identity verification
column29: and complete a creditworthiness review to be approved. These loans have a higher risk of loss for lenders because there is no collateral to liquidate in the event of a loan default. Due to the loans’ and deposited funds’ dependence on the constantly erratic cryptocurrency market
column30: lending in the cryptocurrency space is inherently dangerous for both borrowers and lenders. Crypto aficionados are less than thrilled as a result of the recent Celsius fiasco
column31: which resulted in the overnight freezing of billions of dollars in deposits. Here are a few of the risks of crypto lending: Though some crypto loans offer low rates
column32: most crypto loans charge over 5% APR
column33: with some charging up to 13% APR (or more). Crypto assets often become unaccessible and illiquid when they are deposited onto crypto loan services. While some cryptocurrency lending services permit lenders to access deposited funds reasonably quickly
column34: others may necessitate a protracted waiting period. A decrease in the value of the deposited collateral might result in a margin call when customers pledge collateral and borrow against it. When the LTV of a cryptocurrency loan falls below the agreed-upon rate
column35: this occurs. When this occurs
column36: borrowers have two options: they can either add more collateral to bring the LTV back down or they can risk liquidation. Platforms for crypto lending are unregulated and do not provide the same level of protection that banks do. For instance
column37: user money up to that amount are safeguarded in the event that a bank goes bankrupt since U.S. bank deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) for up to $250
column38: 000 per depositor. There are no user protections for cryptocurrency lending platforms that have solvency problems
column39: and money may be lost. Users must register for a centralized lending platform (like BlockFi) or link a digital wallet to a decentralized lending platform in order to submit an application for a cryptocurrency loan (such as Aave). Users will next choose the type of loan and the desired loan amount before choosing the collateral to deposit. The amount that is available will change depending on the collateral and deposit. The borrowed cash will quickly move to the user’s account or digital wallet after the user deposits the collateral into the platform’s digital wallet. The majority of loans give quick approval
column40: and smart contracts are used to lock in loan conditions. Users must register for a lending platform
column41: choose a supported cryptocurrency to deposit
column42: then pay money to the platform in order to become a crypto lender. Interest can be paid in kind or with the native platform token on a centralized crypto lending platform. Interest is paid out in kind on a decentralized exchange
column43: but there may also be bonus payments. Lending cryptocurrency is a double-edged sword. On the one hand
column44: the majority of loans are secured by collateral
column45: so even in the case of a default
column46: lenders can recover their losses through liquidation. In comparison to conventional bank accounts
column47: they also offer deposits at substantially greater interest rates. On the other hand
column48: there are no legal safeguards for investors
column49: giving lending companies the authority to arbitrarily lock consumers’ funds in place
column50: as Celsius has done. Borrowers run the danger of collateral losing value and having to be liquidated
column51: which would result in a substantially smaller return on their investment. Regulators from all around the world are focusing on lending platforms; rules are emerging around deposit accounts
column52: and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) even fined BlockFi $100 million for breaking securities laws. Ultimately
column53: crypto lending can be secure for careful users
column54: but both borrowers and investors face significant dangers. A platform that provides lending and borrowing services that are controlled by smart contracts is known as decentralized finance (DeFi) lending. Decentralized apps (dApps) enable customers to link a digital wallet
column55: deposit collateral
column56: and instantly access funds. DeFi loans are instantaneous. DeFi lending enables customers to deposit cryptocurrency using a digital wallet and begin earning interest right away
column57: with the interest often compounding every minute. The majority of DeFi lending platforms mandate overcollateralization
column58: requiring deposits of at least 110% of the loan amount. The deposit of collateral receives income even when it is tied to a loan
column59: which is how DeFi differs from centralized systems. Users can earn a large amount of interest on their crypto deposits when they make them on a lending platform
column60: often more than they can at regular banks. The money that is deposited is loaned to borrowers who cover a portion of the interest
column61: and it can also be invested in other ways to increase yield. Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency

column1: 520::https://theconversation.com/centrelink-data-matching-problems-show-the-need-for-a-government-blockchain-71156::The Conversation::article::Centrelink data-matching problems show the need for a government blockchain::The problems with Centrelink’s data-matching system stem from reconciling datasets held by different agencies. What if we used a blockchain to create a single source of data?::Governments across the globe are experimenting with the blockchain
column2: the technology behind Bitcoin
column3: as a way to reduce costs and provide more accountability to the public. In Europe alone
column4: the United Kingdom
column5: Ukraine and Estonia are experimenting with blockchains to fight corruption and deliver public services. Australia
column6: too
column7: is looking at what a blockchain might achieve. The recent problems with Centrelink’s automated data-matching system show precisely where a government blockchain would fit in. Rather than siloing our data in government agencies
column8: we could create a single source of information. This would speed up our interactions with government
column9: while reducing errors and fraud. The blockchain is a kind of public database
column10: one stored simultaneously on a bunch of different computers. When a new transaction occurs it is verified (otherwise known as “mining” or “consensus”)
column11: encrypted and added to the database. The most famous example of the blockchain is Bitcoin
column12: a crypto-currency built upon the blockchain. However
column13: the blockchain is suitable for many other applications
column14: not just financial transactions. For example
column15: the blockchain could be used to authenticate that a diamond has not come from an illict source
column16: or for buying and selling property. For the government’s purposes
column17: the killer feature of the blockchain is that it is a way to record transactions so that they are transparent and cannot be altered or tampered with. When used to track fish through a supply chain
column18: for instance
column19: it allows customers and restaurants to follow where the fish has been and have confidence in the data. When applied to a government context
column20: these capabilities could be useful for collecting tax
column21: delivering benefits
column22: or regulating business. From the public’s point of view
column23: this could enable us to track government spending
column24: eliminate fraudulent transactions
column25: reduce errors in data processing and speed up service delivery to almost real time. It could be useful almost anywhere records are kept. All the while the public could be more confident about the accuracy and integrity of the data being held. The Australian government makes benefit payments and provides support services through Medicare
column26: Centrelink and Child Support services. It also collects information through numerous other agencies
column27: such as the Australian Tax Office. A government blockchain could record the transactions about a citizen and link together information about health
column28: welfare and child support. The information would be entered only once into the blockchain by any one of these agencies. There would be no need for the data to be re-entered or matched again. Thus errors that occur in data processing as information is passed on down the line will be eliminated
column29: avoiding some of the issues with the current Centrelink system. Further
column30: once data is entered it cannot be altered or changed in any way without proper authentication. Any authorised officer within the government could then access the information in the blockchain
column31: avoiding a paper-pushing exercise between government departments. All of your data would be in one place. We could go even further
column32: as the blockchain would also allow other services to be processed through an app
column33: as the UK is trialling with welfare payments. The overall cost savings
column34: reduction in bureaucracy and increased responsiveness to helping people in need could be immense. All we need is the government to invest in its own blockchain. The essence of a blockchain is to reduce the reliance on centralised systems (such as the government)
column35: replacing it with a system with inherent accountability
column36: transparency and trust. The original blockchain concept achieved this by being open
column37: like the internet (also known as unpermissioned)
column38: relying on independent
column39: anonymous “miners” to validate transactions. This guarantees the integrity of the data as no-one knows who the miners are to bribe or bully them into underhanded actions. However
column40: some might view a government-run
column41: “permissioned” blockchain with suspicion. The trust of the public would need to be gained. A government blockchain would not be open
column42: and we would have to rely on the government to approve all of the transactions. This negates some of the benefit offered by a blockchain. The legitimacy and trust would have to come from the government itself. Thus a government-run blockchain would not be without its challenges. But if an Australian government blockchain is developed and allowed to succeed
column43: then the potential benefits could be enormous. Society as we know it will be disrupted!::2017-01-13T05:07:21Z::Blockchain

column1: 521::https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2024/05/16/ether-bitcoin-ratio-slides-to-lowest-since-april-2021-heres-why/::CoinDesk::article::Ether-Bitcoin Ratio Slides to Lowest Since April 2021. Here's Why::"Ether is a 'lightning rod' for negative sentiment from crypto native and external players and has several weak spots
column2: one observer said.::The ratio between ether (ETH) and bitcoin’s (BTC) dollar-denominated prices continues to slide, extending year-to-date losses as suggested by the bearish death cross pattern a month ago. ETH/BTC slipped to 0.04563 on crypto exchange Binance soon before press time, reaching the lowest since April 2021, according to charting platform TradingView. This year, the ratio has declined nearly 16%, indicating a bias for bitcoin or the leading cryptocurrency by market value. The slide to three-year lows follows reduced demand for exchange-traded products (ETPs) tied to ether. According to Bloomberg data quoted by ETC Group in its weekly report, global ether ETPs registered net outflows of around $63.5 million last week, with Hong Kong-listed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) losing the most. Meanwhile, bitcoin ETPs raked in $92.5 million last week. Several factors, including competing layer 1s and lingering uncertainty about the debut of spot ETH approvals in the U.S, are likely responsible for ETH falling out of investor favor. “The approval of spot bitcoin ETFs in the U.S. has reinforced bitcoin’s store-of-value narrative and its status as a macro asset. On the other hand, open questions about ETH’s fundamental positioning within the crypto sector remain. Competing layer-1s (L1s) like Solana detract from Ethereum’s positioning as the 'go-to' network for decentralized app (dApp) deployment,” Coinbase Institutional’s Research analyst David Han said in a note Wednesday. Solana’s share in total decentralized exchange volumes has grown tenfold from 2% to 21% in one year, eating into Ethereum's market share. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) green-lighted nearly a dozen spot BTC ETFs in January. Since then, these funds have drawn roughly $12 billion in net inflows, according to data source Farside Investors. Approval of spot ETFs tied to ether will open a similar pool of capital for Ethereum’s native token, although it’s unclear when the SEC will approve it. Traders on decentralized betting platform Polymarket see just a 10% chance of the SEC approving a spot ETF on or before May 31. The regulator has until May 23 to decide whether to approve or reject VanEck’s application to launch a spot Ethereum ETF. The deadline for BlackRock’s application is June 23. According to finance lawyer Scott Johnsson, the SEC is looking for reasons to deny ETH ETF applications by BlackRock and others on grounds that they have been improperly filed as commodity-based trust shares and do not qualify if they hold a security. Ilan Solot, co-head of digital assets at Marex Solutions, said ether is a lightning rod" for negative sentiment from crypto native and external players and has several weak spots. “Capital gets fragmented. There are proportionally greater numbers of ways to get exposure to the ecosystem through the many Layer 2s tokens (OP
column3: ARB…) and native protocol tokens in each one. The capital gets fragmented
column4: Solot said in an email. Solot added that strong anti-ETH sentiment from [rival] Solana community and Bitcoin propounders is driving negative ether narratives and the high beta cryptocurrency is a perfect vehicle" for external players to express bearish view given it trades on traditional exchanges such as the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Lastly
column5: Ether recently turned inflationary
column6: reversing the bullish deflationary supply trend seen consistently since its parent network Ethereum transitioned to a proof-of-stake consensus ecosystem in September 2022. Edited by Parikshit Mishra. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 524::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-articles/price-of-bitcoin-what-influence-btc-price-7304/::Coinatory::article::Price of Bitcoin: 6 main factors influence the BTC price::Discover the key factors that impact the price of Bitcoin. Learn about the various economic
column2: political
column3: and technological factors that can affect it.::Bitcoin (BTC) is a cryptocurrency that Satoshi Nakamoto
column4: its unidentified creator
column5: created in 2009. A blockchain keeps track of all transactions
column6: displaying each unit’s transaction history and demonstrating ownership. Bitcoin is not backed by a government or issued by a central bank like conventional currencies are. Because Bitcoin is not a corporation
column7: investing in it differs from investing in stocks or bonds. As a result
column8: there are no corporate balance sheets
column9: Form 10-Ks
column10: fund results
column11: or other conventional tools for selecting an investment to analyze. Learn about the factors that influence the price of bitcoin to justify better your decision to invest in it. The monetary policy instruments
column12: inflation rates
column13: and economic growth measurements that generally affect the value of a currency do not apply to Bitcoin because it is neither issued by a central bank nor backed by a government. Bitcoin acts as more of a commodity being used to store value
column14: so the following factors influence its price: The supply of an asset is a key factor in setting its price. An asset in high demand is more likely to have high pricing than one in a large supply
column15: which will have low prices. Since there will only be 21 million manufactured and only a certain number made year
column16: the supply of Bitcoin is typically well publicized. Its protocol only permits the creation of new Bitcoin at a fixed rate
column17: which is intended to decrease over time. Bitcoin’s future supply is
column18: therefore
column19: dwindling
column20: which adds to demand. This is similar to a reduction in corn supply if harvests were to be reduced every four years until no more was harvested
column21: and it was publicly advertised that this would happen—corn prices would skyrocket. Both regular people and big investors are starting to like bitcoin more because it’s getting a lot of attention in the news
column22: from people who give investment advice
column23: and from business owners who say bitcoin is valuable now and will be in the future. Countries like Venezuela
column24: where money is losing its value fast
column25: also like bitcoin a lot. People who need to move large amounts of money secretly or for illegal reasons also prefer it. This means that more people want bitcoin
column26: but there won’t be as much available in the future
column27: which has made its price go up. However
column28: the price of bitcoin still goes up and down a lot. For example
column30: its price went up a lot
column31: then it fell and stayed low for a while
column32: and then in 2021
column33: it quickly went up and down again. Similar to other commodities
column34: production costs are a major factor in setting the price of bitcoin. Research suggests that the price of bitcoin in cryptocurrency marketplaces is closely correlated with its marginal cost of production. The production cost for Bitcoin is essentially the sum of the direct fixed expenses for the infrastructure and electricity needed to mine the cryptocurrency and an indirect cost associated with the algorithm’s degree of difficulty. A network of miners competes to decipher an encrypted number in order to mine bitcoins. The first miner to accomplish so receives a reward of newly created bitcoins as well as any transaction fees earned since the last block was located. It takes a lot of processing power to use brute force to solve the hash in order to unlock a block and receive a reward. The miner will have to spend a lot of money on numerous pricey mining equipment. Also
column35: the bitcoin mining process uses a lot of electricity. According to estimates
column36: the bitcoin mining network consumes more electricity than certain small nations. Despite the fact that Bitcoin is the most well-known cryptocurrency
column37: there are hundreds of other tokens competing for capital. By 2022
column38: Bitcoin will control the majority of cryptocurrency marketplaces. But with time
column39: its power has diminished. Almost 80% of the total market capitalization of cryptocurrencies in 2017 was made up of Bitcoin. The proportion fell to less than 50% by 2022. The fundamental cause of this was growing acceptance of alternative currency and their potential. For instance
column40: due to a rise in decentralized finance
column41: Ethereum has become a fierce rival to Bitcoin (DeFi). Ether (ETH)
column42: the cryptocurrency that serves as “gas” for transactions on its network
column43: has attracted investment from investors who see its potential for redesigning the rails of contemporary financial infrastructure. The popularity of other cryptocurrencies has increased as they are continually being introduced. Other coins like Tether
column44: Ethereum
column47: and Solana are reducing the market share of Bitcoin. Competition has drawn investors to Bitcoin even as they have taken some of their dollars from the ecosystem. As a result
column48: there is now more demand for and knowledge about cryptocurrencies. Bitcoin has profited from the attention as a type of standard-bearer for the cryptocurrency ecosystem
column49: and its prices have stayed high. Bitcoin came out after a financial crisis caused by weak rules in the trading of complex financial products. The world of cryptocurrencies is known for not having many rules and being open across countries because it’s not regulated yet. The fact that Bitcoin doesn’t have strict rules has its good and bad sides. It can be used anywhere in the world without the usual government restrictions. However
column50: governments and other groups are still trying to figure out how to regulate cryptocurrencies. There’s a chance that new rules are coming
column51: but it’s not clear how they will affect Bitcoin’s price. For example
column52: decisions by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) can influence Bitcoin’s value. When the SEC approved the first U.S. bitcoin-related ETF
column53: Bitcoin’s price shot up to $69
column54: 000 in October 2021. But a few months later
column55: its price dropped to around $40
column56: 000. China’s ban on Bitcoin trading and mining in September 2021 also affected Bitcoin. It led to a decrease in its supply and demand. Prices fell from about $51
column57: 000 at the beginning of September to around $41
column58: 000 by the end of the month. However
column59: prices went back up as the mining operations moved to more crypto-friendly countries and got back to business. News about Bitcoin can make its price go up or down
column60: as it tries to keep investors and others interested. When anything changes with things that affect Bitcoin’s price
column61: the news spreads fast. So
column62: good news usually makes Bitcoin’s price go up
column63: and bad news can make it go down. One big thing that changes cryptocurrency prices is how investors feel about it. This feeling is shaped by how much Bitcoin is available
column64: how much people want it
column65: how much it costs to make it
column66: what other cryptocurrencies are doing

column1: 525::https://cryptobriefing.com/sothebys-debuts-bitcoin-ordinals-auction-bitcoinshrooms-collection/::Crypto Briefing::article::Sotheby's debuts Bitcoin Ordinals auction with BitcoinShrooms collection::Sotheby's pioneering Bitcoin Ordinals auction runs through December 13
column2: 2023.::Join the hunt for $12
column4: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Renowned art auction house Sotheby’s is making history by hosting the first public sale of works from a Bitcoin Ordinals collection. The inaugural series titled “BitcoinShrooms” was created by pseudonymous digital artist Shroomtoshi. Bitcoin Ordinals are the NFTs of the Bitcoin blockchain
column5: taking advantage of its decentralized
column6: censorship-resistant design and infrastructure. While similar to Ethereum NFTs in some ways
column7: Bitcoin Ordinals benefit from Bitcoin’s decentralization and user sovereignty over its assets. We're thrilled to present our inaugural Bitcoin Ordinals sale
column8: featuring @BitcoinShrooms 🍄 pic.twitter.com/UkX5jsfKLh — Sotheby's Metaverse (@Sothebysverse) December 6
column9: 2023 Ordinals represent a proof of concept within the Bitcoin network and are often referred to as “digital artifacts” rather than NFTs which are
column10: by design
column11: non-fungible. The process involves inscribing satoshis
column12: the smallest units of Bitcoin
column13: with digital content or machine-readable language
column14: reflecting Bitcoin’s immutable nature. This approach contrasts with traditional NFTs
column15: especially regarding the lack of required royalty payments for sales. Consequently
column16: Bitcoin Ordinals represent a significant deviation from conventional NFTs
column17: often sparking debate within various Bitcoin communities. “Digital artifacts are permissionless. An NFT which cannot be sold without paying a royalty is not permissionless
column18: and thus not a digital artifact
column19: ” the project’s documentation explains. The Bitcoin Ordinals project was begun by blockchain developer Casey Rodarmor
column20: who hinged on the permissionless design of the Bitcoin blockchain as an initial concept to create digital artifacts. The online auction
column21: open now through December 13
column22: marks the public debut of these unique and probably rare pixel art pieces that offer a whimsical yet educational guided tour of Bitcoin’s cultural and technical revolution. The BitcoinShrooms collection’s standout pieces decode complex Bitcoin concepts like private key derivation and mining incentives through retro-themed pixel art mushrooms and clever cultural Easter eggs. Estimates for top works range between $20
column24: 000. “The BitcoinShrooms collection is a pixelated recap of the first 13 years of Bitcoin
column25: a homage to the 8-bit style of art that expresses a slight nostalgia for the 90s
column26: a way to soil 10s of thousands of SSDs spread across the world with my art (->next level cyber-vandalism
column27: ” said Shroomtoshi. The BitcoinShrooms sale enters a heated climate around the purpose and evolution of Bitcoin. Miners have prioritized maximizing transaction fee revenue lately
column28: making them unlikely to restrict ordinal inscriptions despite complaints. On the other hand
column29: Bitcoin developer Luke Dashjr sparked renewed debate by publicly decrying ordinals and other inscription projects as “spam attacks” on the Bitcoin network. Notably
column30: Bitcoin has recently surpassed Ethereum in terms of average transaction fees. This change highlights the growing interest and activity in the Bitcoin network
column31: especially in the context of how Ordinals and other blockchain innovations have emerged of late. Share this article The information on or accessed through this website is obtained from independent sources we believe to be accurate and reliable

column1: 526::https://theconversation.com/how-blockchain-will-transform-our-cities-69561::The Conversation::article::How blockchain will transform our cities::If you think the internet has changed your life
column2: brace yourself for the next digital innovation that’s set to transform our world.::Many trends on the horizon offer opportunities that could transform our cities. From self-driving vehicles and the sharing economy through to cloud computing and blockchain technologies
column3: each of these trends is quite significant on its own. But the convergence of their disruptive forces is what will create real value and drive innovations. Take blockchain and the sharing economy as an example. Bringing these two forces together can potentially disrupt established companies like Uber and Airbnb. The success of these companies is largely due to their ability to make use of existing assets people owned
column4: that had been paid for
column5: but from which new value could be derived. Effectively
column6: these companies set up digital platforms that harnessed “excess capacity” and relied on other people to deliver the services. The same applies to other so-called “sharing economy” companies that merely act as service aggregators and collect a cut off the top. In the process
column7: they gather valuable data for further commercial gain. But can this business model be challenged and enhanced for the benefit of those who are delivering the service and creating the real value? Can technology be used to bypass the third party and allow direct peer-to-peer collaboration within a distributed governance structure? What could a “peer-owned” and “peer-run” marketplace look like? Blockchain technology could just be the answer. You can think of blockchain as the second generation of the internet – a transformation from an internet of information to an internet of value. Blockchain allows suppliers and consumers – even competitors – to share a decentralised digital ledger across a network of computers without the need for a central authority. The assets that can be described on the blockchain can be financial
column8: legal
column9: physical or electronic. No single party has the power to tamper with the records – sophisticated algorithms keep everyone honest by ensuring data integrity and authentication of transactions. But the impacts of blockchain go well beyond financial services and transactions. Its real value is in establishing trust-based interactions and accelerating the transfer of governance from centralised institutions to distributed networks of peer-to-peer collaboration. The impact can be profound: a centralised institution acting as intermediatory in a transaction of value is now at risk of being disrupted because the same service can be provided on the blockchain through peer-to-peer interaction. Blockchain gives service providers a means to collaborate and derive a greater share of the value for themselves. Smart agents on a blockchain could do just about everything provided by a service aggregator. The technology’s trust protocol allows autonomous associations to be formed and controlled by the same people who are creating the value. All revenues for services
column10: minus overheads
column11: would go to members
column12: who also control the platform and make decisions. Trust is not established by third parties
column13: but rather through an encrypted consensus enabled by smart coding. We already have examples of this technology in action. Arcade City
column14: a global community of peer-to-peer services
column15: is planning to offer a ride-sharing service on the blockchain. To catch a ride
column16: the user buys digital currency (known as tokens)
column17: creates an offer and commits funds for the ride. A driver claims the offer
column18: matches the funds to signal their commitment to provide the service
column19: and picks up the passenger. The blockchain releases the funds as soon as the user acknowledges completing the ride. Arcade City has a city council
column20: which will overlook the system for three years until it is fully decentralised and up and running. The same concept of using distributed public record technology can be applied to a wide range of urban applications. For example
column21: an energy startup in Perth is looking to trial a peer-to-peer technology solution that would allow consumers to offer excess energy
column22: available through their solar panels
column23: on the blockchain. Clever code matches the suppliers with consumers without the need to go through the energy provider. The blockchain technology and ecosystem around it are evolving rapidly
column24: and are probably raising more questions than answers. How do we establish a system of transparent governance to ensure the longevity of the blockchain? What about security
column25: speed
column26: cost and
column27: more importantly
column28: regulations? As with other disruptive technologies
column29: there will be winners and losers. If the technology is successfully managed for scalable growth
column30: it could very well disrupt established norms and transform our societies. Large layers of data generated by consumers today
column31: which are controlled by hubs
column32: can become public. In a world driven by blockchain
column33: consumers can monetise their own data to derive greater value. By knowing when and how to take advantage of this technology
column34: we have an opportunity to transform the digital platforms for tomorrow’s cities. The blockchain becomes the city’s operating system
column35: invisible yet ubiquitous
column36: improving citizens’ access to services
column37: goods and economic opportunities. Today
column38: the technology is yet to mature. It remains to be seen if the expectations can live up to reality. But
column39: in many ways
column40: this is quite reminiscent of the internet in the mid-1990s. Not many people would have predicted its significance back then. Had we understood the impacts of the internet 20 years ago
column41: what could we have done differently to create more value? That is where we stand today with blockchain. The power of this transformation will become more compelling as the hype settles down and we begin to unleash the possibilities.::2016-12-13T19:04:57Z::Blockchain

column1: 527::https://www.coindesk.com/consensus-magazine/2024/04/30/its-modding-but-on-steroids-mark-long-on-the-future-of-web3-gaming/::CoinDesk::article::‘It's Modding
column2: But on Steroids’: Mark Long on the Future of Web3 Gaming::Shrapnel
column3: a blockchain-infused first-person shooter game
column4: is expected to be released in 2025. Its creator gives a preview to Jeff Wilser ahead of his appearance at Consensus 2024.::Web3 games have a shaky track record. It’s easy to see the appeal: There are literally billions of people playing games
column5: and most of them do it for free. They spend countless hours — and often their own cash — to create content that grows the ecosystem
column6: and they get nothing while the gaming companies get everything. Web3 games
column7: in theory
column8: give power (and equity) to the players. Or
column9: that was the pitch in the last bull cycle
column10: when Web3 games like Axie Infinity seemed to create new economies and even lift players from poverty. Then prices tumbled
column11: games crumbled. Can Web3 games make a comeback? Mark Long is a speaker at Consensus 2024
column12: in Austin
column13: Texas
column14: May 29-31. Now at least one thing is different: Top-tier gaming talent has entered the Web3 space
column15: focused on creating games that are actually a blast to play
column16: not just a means to grind out crypto. “It’s very important that it’s a great game
column17: period
column18: whether for Web2 or Web3
column19: ” says Mark Long
column20: CEO of Shrapnel
column21: the blockchain-infused and “moddable” first-person shooter game
column22: which is expected to be released in 2025. (Modding refers to the ability of gamers to modify aspects of the game experience.) Long knows about building great games. He’s the former head of Xcloud
column23: a game-streaming service
column24: at Microsoft
column25: the former head of publishing at HBO Interactive
column26: and he’s produced over 32 games in his 26-year career. And now he’s bringing that savvy to Web3. Long opens up about the extra challenges in creating a Web3 game (the wrong tweak to a database can cost players millions)
column27: what gamers can expect from Shrapnel (“modding on steroids”)
column28: and why he views Consensus as the most “scholarly” crypto conference. Interview has been condensed and lightly edited for clarity. What’s the vision of Shrapnel? What are you trying to pull off? Mark Long: So
column29: I love triple-A shooters. I just love all shooters; I play all of them all the time. But what I love more is actually modding shooters. And I mean
column30: going all the way back to Doom 2 and Quake and Half-Life. You're speaking my language. I still remember the keyboard shortcut to pull up the shotgun in Doom. Yes! So even though I was making games in the studio during the day
column31: at night I would come home and mod those type of games. And if I got 11 people to play my map
column32: I'd be thrilled. Right? Which is ridiculous because I'm making games for millions of players. But this is something very personal. I get a personal joy from modding a game that I really like. So
column33: fast forward to the Roblox
column34: Minecraft
column35: Fortnite era. Kids start off making their own content in Minecraft
column36: and they age into Roblox
column37: and so they become more proficient. And with Fortnite
column38: 50% of the engagement is made by other players
column39: which is stunning. But when you turn 18 to 35 years old
column40: there's nothing for you to age into. And I don't think young players are going to stop wanting to make their own games. And our theory is if you gave them the same professional level of tools that we have
column41: they'd actually make some pretty cool shit. So
column42: that's what Shrapnel is. It's an extraction first-person shooter based on Web3. And it’s a free
column43: frictionless database technology that allows us to seamlessly attribute all these contributions that players can make to a game
column44: and then reward them for it. How so? You’ll be rewarded for your contribution. And in our world
column45: that can be a lot of things. You can modify our maps — just use all our static meshes and modify them. You can do character skins. You can do character customization. Make emblems
column47: of course
column48: you just mint those. And then I could sell
column49: trade
column50: rent
column51: stake all those items. That's what I'm really excited about. It's modding
column52: but on steroids. Let’s talk about Web3 gaming more broadly. Taking Shrapnel out of the equation
column53: why do you think there haven’t yet been any great Web3 games? So
column54: all these games were put into production in the last bull cycle
column55: right? And they’re just now coming to the public in early access or open beta. But I'd argue there are a handful of really good games out there that I'm excited to play. There’s MetalCore
column56: the mech shooter. There's Wildcard
column57: the card-battler game by the husband and wife team that did Words with Friends. I like Dead Drop. I like Off the Grid
column58: which has art direction by Neill Blomkamp. I fucking love Neill Blomkamp. So the short version is there are a handful of games that actually are going to be really good and break through
column59: and then of course there’s Shrapnel. Fair enough! There are some good games. But those seem to be the outliers. I think part of your lament for the earlier Web3 games is because of two reasons: A lot of the teams are not game development teams
column60: they're crypto development teams. Right? And two
column61: it’s production values. They haven’t had the money to put into the game to make it really great. What’s extra challenging about building a Web3 game
column62: compared to a traditional video game? What are the additional wrinkles caused by decentralization? Great question. I want to start by saying that it’s very important that it’s a great game
column63: period
column64: whether for Web2 or Web3. It’s easy to lose track of that. But to answer your question
column65: one simple thing comes to mind. Think about working on a database in a game. Think about
column66: for example
column67: all the items I can collect for my character — my gear
column68: my helmet
column69: my weapon
column70: all that stuff. You have a pretty complex database and it has to provide for all this attribution. If I make a mistake in normal development
column71: you just reset the database and then start over again. But here with web3
column72: that has real-world value. Right? So if we fuck up and I delete your $1
column73: 000 worth of stuff
column74: I can't claim that I'm World of Warcraft and you never really owned it anyway. That’s a huge problem. So we have to be especially meticulous as we integrate any Web3 component. Then there’s the problem of potential exploits — things that we miss could create a disaster for the economy. It takes longer to integrate the Web3 component. The code has to be audited at a level that game code never normally needs to be audited. That was all brand new to us. It slows down our roadmap. But as we get better at it and there’s more tooling APIs and SDKs available
column75: it will just get better and better. For many who are only casually following the Web3 gaming space
column76: they’ve heard of the boom-and-bust cycle of “Play to Earn.” There are concerns that this model is not sustainable — it only works when the token price is rising
column77: but then
column78: if the price falls
column79: the economy collapses. What’s the solve for this? What’s the trick for making Web3 games viable for the long-term
column80: and not relying upon price appreciation? So I would probably guess that for the economies that you’re thinking about that collapsed
column81: they’re kind of pyramid economies where you have to have a large number inflowing at the bottom
column82: and they grind and level-up assets or characters that then get sold to the person above them who’s also grinding. You need lots coming in at the bottom to do that. And then when the community collapses or the token price collapses
column83: nobody's playing because it's a fun game — they’re there to make money off it. So they abandon it. Ah
column84: so the trick is the game quality itself… What we think will happen in game economies like Shrapnel is the more players you have
column85: and the more engagement you have
column86: the more they’re using the token in-game. That’s driving the need for the token and it kind of has a burn effect. It’s consuming the supply
column87: and that means there's more buy pressure than sell pressure. If I hear you right
column88: it sounds like you’re saying there needs to be actual legit utility in these tokens. It’s not sham utility. People are using it. They're using it because they want to play the game and have fun. So the game needs to be good
column89: period. Am I getting that right? Yeah. Let's just use a rough order of magnitude example. The average paying player in Web3 might be $100 a month versus $10 a month on Web2. So every one of those new Web3 players adds $100 of consumption. Remember
column90: the economy is in the token
column91: so they are spending $100 of the token. Okay
column92: last couple of questions are about Consensus itself. What’s your favorite Consensus memory? Well
column93: you know
column94: last year we demoed the game for the first time at Consensus. We were right at one of the main entrances
column95: and by the end of the first day
column96: they had just moved the bar to our space because so many people wanted to play the game
column97: and were excited to get their hands on it. What are you most looking forward to at Consensus this year? It’s a really well-curated conference. I would call it a scholarly conference
column98: where the panels are well-vetted. Love it
column99: and thank you. On a less scholarly front
column100: what’s the best Consensus side-party? It'll be ours. Good answer. See you there! Edited by Benjamin Schiller. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column7: ” enabling users to sign transactions on supported blockchains from a single NEAR account. Chain Signatures enables accounts and smart contracts on NEAR to sign transactions for different chains. At launch

column12: according to the team. By enabling Chain signatures
column13: DeFi protocols can utilize assets from other chains without requiring a cross-chain bridge. This is possible because Chain Signatures are designed to be account-based rather than bridge-based. Read more: NEAR Foundation applies for .near top-level domain According to Kendall Cole
column14: director of research and development company Proximity Labs — which supports projects on NEAR and Aurora — Chain Signatures can potentially unlock new use cases for DeFi protocols. “Users can use XRP as collateral to borrow USDC
column15: or trade DOGE for SOL. This is particularly innovative for non-smart-contract chains like Bitcoin
column16: DogeCoin and Ripple because none of the major bridges support these chains today
column17: ” Cole said. NEAR protocol documents show that Chain Signatures link NEAR account addresses to other blockchains using an Additive Key Derivation. This mechanism enables the single master key to be derived into multiple subkeys. When a user wants to transact between different blockchains
column18: a deployed multichain smart contract will make a signature request for the transaction on the target blockchain network
column19: and a Multi-Party Computation (MPC) service will sign the transaction. Read more: MPC wallets have a trade-off. Is it worth it? Once the signature is obtained
column20: the smart contract will return it to the user
column21: allowing the user to send the signed transaction to execute it on the target blockchain. “Smart contracts on NEAR will be able to custody assets on any chain (since they can sign transactions on any chain via chain signatures)
column22: and maintain user balances similar to how single chain lending protocols or DEXs do now
column23: ” Cole explained. The Chain Signatures MPC network will be launched in partnership with EigenLayer
column24: which will secure the network using its restaked ETH. At launch
column25: there will be ten node providers
column26: including a handful of Actively Validated Services (AVS) infrastructure providers. “Post-launch
column27: EigenLayer will be used to provide economic security to the network and transition the MPC network to a permissionless version. To participate in the MPC network
column28: prospective node operators will need to re-stake their ETH and will be penalized if they maliciously authorize any transactions that did not originate from a NEAR account
column29: ” Cole explained. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column1: 530::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-articles/the-secret-of-arbitrage-trading-7095/::Coinatory::article::Increase your profits with arbitrage trading - check out these examples!::Are you ready to take your cryptocurrency trading to the next level? Don't miss this essential guide to arbitrage trading.::Arbitrage trading is the simultaneous purchase and sale of a single asset or a group of related assets in various markets with the goal of making a profit from minute variations in the asset’s quoted price. It takes advantage of brief fluctuations in the cost of identical or comparable financial products on various markets or in various forms. Arbitrage exists as a result of market inefficiencies
column2: and it both exploits those inefficiencies and resolves them. Any time a stock
column3: commodity
column4: or piece of currency can be bought at one price on one market and simultaneously sold at a higher price on another
column5: arbitrage can be used. The circumstance offers the trader the chance to profit without taking any risks. Arbitrage offers a way to make sure that prices don’t diverge significantly from fair value over an extended period of time. With advancements in technology
column6: it has become extremely difficult to profit from pricing errors in the market. A lot of traders have automated trading programs configured to track changes in similar financial instruments. Any ineffective pricing structures are typically addressed quickly
column7: often within a few seconds
column8: and the opportunity is lost. As a simple illustration of arbitrage
column9: think of the following: on cryptocurrency exchange A
column10: token X is currently trading at $20; on cryptocurrency exchange B
column11: it is currently trading at $20.05. A trader can buy token X on cryptocurrency exchange A and immediately sell the same token X on cryptocurrency exchange B to make a profit of 5 cents per coin. The trader can continue to use this arbitrage until cryptocurrency exchange A runs out of this token or until exchange A or exchange B specialists adjust their prices to eliminate the opportunity. A trickier example can be found in currencies markets using triangular arbitrage. In this case
column12: the trader converts one currency to another
column13: converts that second currency to a third bank
column14: and finally converts the third currency back to the original currency. Assume you are given the following exchange rates for your $1 million: USD/EUR = 1.1586
column15: EUR/GBP = 1.4600
column16: and USD/GBP = 1.6939. There is a chance to make money by arbitraging these exchange rates: From these transactions
column17: you would receive an arbitrage profit of $1
column18: 384 Trading called “arbitrage” takes advantage of the minute price differences between identical or similar assets in two or more markets. The arbitrage trader buys the asset in one market and sells it in the other market at the same time to pocket the difference between the two prices. The following is a list of some of the most common questions we get asked about our services. Arbitrage traders
column19: or arbitrageurs
column20: typically work for major financial institutions. It typically entails trading a sizeable sum of money
column21: and the split-second opportunities it presents can only be recognized and taken advantage of with extremely sophisticated software. The practice of buying and selling shares of stocks
column22: commodities
column23: cryptocurrencies
column24: or currencies on various markets in order to take advantage of the inevitable fluctuations in their prices from minute to minute is known as arbitrage. However
column25: the term “arbitrage” is also sometimes used to describe other trading activities. One tactic that is well-liked among hedge fund investors is merger arbitrage
column26: which entails purchasing shares of companies prior to a merger that has been announced or is anticipated. Arbitrage traders improve the efficiency of financial markets by working to increase their profits. As they buy and sell
column27: the price difference between identical or similar assets narrows. Assets with a lower price are sold
column28: while assets with a higher price are not sold. In this way
column29: arbitrage eliminates market pricing inefficiencies and increases market liquidity. Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency
